B.M.
Homonym Number:

Sense Number:
Definition: board measure
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1923
Source:  Small Sawmills
Author:  MALFROY
Vol / Page:  38
Edition:
Quote:  B.M. .. Board measure - a term expressing the board foot content of round or manufactured timber, and for expressing the volume of logs, trees, or stands in terms of the estimated amount of timber which may be cut therefrom. `Board foot' is a unit of measurement represented by a board 1 ft. long, 1 ft. wide, and 1 in. in thickness, or its equivalent

babaco
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: A hybrid papaya, Carica pentagona, originating in Ecuador; with large yellow-skinned fruit up to 30 cm long and 10-12 in cross-section, with rather acid, almost white and distinctly fragrant flesh.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Lexicographical & Linguistic Studies
Author:  BURCHFIELD
Vol / Page:  192
Edition:
Quote:  babaco /b |b k u/. N.Z. & Austral. [S. Amer. Sp.

(Ecuador).] A bright yellow marrow-like fruit, C<i>arica heilbornii pentagona</i>, usu. about 30 cm. long, with a faceted exterior and with a texture like that of a coarse melon.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1921
Source:  Arkiv for Botanik
Author:
Vol / Page:  XVII. XII.4
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Carica pentagona</i> is called `babaco' by the natives and is regarded as a great delicacy.


Notes:  O. HEILBORN

Date:  0/0/1924
Source:  Contr. National Herbarium (US)
Author:
Vol / Page:  XXV. V. 126
Edition:
Quote:  Because of its large fruits .. and because of its habit of producng seedless fruits, the <i>babaco</i> is worthy of attention in other countries.
Notes:  W. POPENOE

Date:  0/0/1976
Source:  Tanaka's Cycl. Edible Fruits
Author:  T. TANAKA
Vol / Page:  135
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Carica pentagona</i> .., `Babaco'. The flesh of fruits are nearly white, acid; eaten cooked, preserved or used in sauce. Ecuador & adj. territory.

Author:
Vol / Page:  24
Edition:
Quote:  The babaco story began in 1977 when Dick Endt, a nurseryman from Oratia, near Auckland, introduced the first privately grown species into New Zealand........ The babaco belongs to the Caricaceae family, more commonly known as the papaya family.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  Delectable Fruits Cookery
Author:  BURTON
Vol / Page:  41
Edition:
Quote:  BABACO... is a hybrid between two papaya (pawpaw) species, <I>Carica pubescens</i> (mountain papaya) and <i>C. stipulata</i>. . . first brought to the attention of the rest of the world by the botanist Heilborn, who named it <i>Carica pentagona</i>, meaning five-sided. The Ecuadorian name babaco (pronounced as in banana) has been retained in New Zealand.

Quote:  When the All blacks confront France in the one-off rugby international at Jade Stadium on Saturday, it will be 17 years to the day that the "Baby Blacks" were born.  That was the name given to a New Zealand team stripped of All Blacks by the controversial and unauthorised Cavaliers tour to South Africa earlier in the year, and thrown against a French team brimming with caps and confidence.

Author:
Vol / Page:  III/449
Edition:
Quote:  In legal history [Minnie Deans] has been known, with approximate accuracy, as the Winton Baby Farmer. Under the guise of benevolent motive she received unwanted children and apparently destroyed them... For a premium, never very large, Minnie Dean adopted unwanted infants, but the payment of the fee invariably marked the disappearance of the child into the care of a "lady" whose name or abode was never disclosed.

That this evil exists there can be no doubt; and it appears that children, either by advertisement or otherwise, are placed in most unsuitable  homes, where it is perfectly well understood that the sooner the child dies the better pleased all concerned will be.

Edition:
Quote:  Next off the block is likely to be commercial cultivars of actinidia arguta, which produces small, hairless grape-sized fruit. Already sold in Japan as "baby kiwifruit" since 1995, it has been targeted by Hortresearch breeders who want to carry the thin skin, high sugar content and flavour over into new cultivars.

Date:  22/11/1957

Author:
Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  From being a mere shed, the bach has become a place at the seaside, and today many a bach has a refrigerator and wall-to-wall carpets.
Notes:

Date:  19/10/1996
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  26
Edition:
Quote:  The bach, these days, tends to be the name given to any smallish holiday house by the beach, no matter how sophisticated. But, in the past, it meant a small home, built by the owner - away out on the edge - by sea or river. Usually it was occupied for just a few summer weeks each year... The great building boom for the archetypal bach was after World War I, with another boom of more gentrified, less interesting baches after World War II.
Notes:

Date:  19/6/2004
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  94
Edition:
Quote:  I've never set foot inside a bach. If it was a common experience - the new coat of paint on the windowsill, the towels hung over the front porch to dry, the tattered books - then I have only known it as a myth, as a New Zealand that existed as an advertisement of itself.

Date:  8/2/2003
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  27
Edition:
Quote:  All six share similar design features, if that is what you call the elements comprising a traditional bach. Low-pitched roofs, corrugated iron walls and recycled timber fascias are standard construction. Some have tiny gardens of hardy coprosma, flax and ice plants scratched out of the rocks. Each has a water tank, various structures to hold firewood and fishing gear, some have a boat shed or a TV aerial and each has a chimney or flue of some kind.
Notes:

Date:  12/5/1984
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)

bachelorise
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: to live alone as a bachelor, to `do' for oneself (often in the temporary absence of a spouse); to share living quarters, domestic chores and expenses, usu. with a person of the same sex. Often bachelorise with.

Quote:  Backblocks or backcountry: In the South Island that country beyond the river gorges is termed back country, as differing from front country which consists of those hills through whose gorges the same rivers wend their way. Backblocks is the equivalent North Island term though the nature of the rivers does not define them so neatly.

back country
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: [The hinterland of settled districts: US 1746 (OED), AND 1802; of a part 1849; of a settled dist. or station 1887.] The remoter parts of a farm or other area, away from the sea or other means of access.  Also called backblocks.  Compare front country. a. Usu. with def art., a hinterland, beyond settlements, or sparsely settled, remote from coastal or other means of access, often regarded from the point of view of its farming use or potential. In Canterbury, country towards the Southern Alps (cf front country). In later use, backblocks.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: up-country, cf. front country
Pronunciation: -
Notes:

back delivery
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:

back to the mat
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: in phrases: return/go back to the mat, get back on/to the mat: of a Europeanised Maori, to figuratively resume Maori dress; to return to Maori customs and way of life; to go native (cf. go back to the bush, bush)

back up

Word Class: verb
Sense Number:

backblockedness
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a state or quality of living in an isolated rural area.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/2002

backbone of the country
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: the principal supporter of the New Zealand dependent economy [an expression subscribed to by rural folk who declare that farmers and farm produce are the principal supporters of the New Zealand economy, i.e. the backbone of the country, keeping all citizens fed, clothed, and housed].


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural

Source:  Practical Dredgeman's Manual
Author:  KITTO
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  Take the end [of the line to be the headline] ..; make it fast to the backer or whatever you are going to fasten it to; return to the boat, ... and all is ready to start to lay [12] the line. Date:  0/0/1956

Author:  DARE
Vol / Page:  165
Edition:
Quote:  I even managed to make him `back' the sheep, a job a great many dogs will refuse. When sheep are being driven into the woolshed, there is a great tendency for them all to get jammed up and no amount of barking will make them move, and it is at this moment that a `backing dog' is needed.
Notes:

Vol / Page:  126

Quote:  You wouldn't notice Dan, the yellow backing dog until the mob got boxed at a gate way ... He'd be up over their backs barking.

Vol / Page:  1/493
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Backing and Yard Dog</i>: Usually this is a `huntaway' or `handy dog' trained to run over the backs of tightly packed sheep and to walk back through a mob in the yards to keep them moving ahead. It is a useful dog for loading and unloading sheep.

As each cow is taken in to be milked, another fills up the space it has left and there are no delays in milking. The gate is controlled by the milker, who can bring in the next cows without having to leave those already being milked.

bag
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 8
Definition: a hole dug under the grain-outlet of a threshing-machine to facilitate the filling, ramming, and sewing up of the grainsacks; bag-rammer, bag-sewer.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: also baggie
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1984
Source:  Knapdale Run, The
Author:  KERSE
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  c1900] Sheets were placed under the [threshing] mill to catch any seed that leaked out and the bag hole men would dig out the bag hole so that the bags could be rammed full. ...

The usual gang for stack threshing [c1900] was 12 men. The boss kept steam up and attended to the mill adjustments and lubrication, three men worked in the bag hole, the bag-rammer, the bag-sewer, and the bag-carrier; two men were on top of the mill, a band cutter and a man to turn the sheaves to the band cutter.
Notes:

Edition:
Quote:  'A good deal was said in Court on Tuesday during the hearing of a case about threshing-machines, and no little amusement was caused by a list given by one witness of the 'technical' names of titles of some of the workmen employed about them.  'Chaffy' and 'baggy' raised a smile merely, but 'straw walloper' tickled everybody except the witness, who glanced around with an air of pity on the laughing faces of those who were ignorant of the designation of the man who attends to the straw elevator.  Some machines, it appears, boast of two 'straw wallopers', others are content with one'.
Notes:  Otago Witness quotes Timaru Herald 3 Sept 1884 p 2.

Notes:

Date:  5/11/2003
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  B9
Edition:
Quote:  [Hdg] Kiwi bagmen not too down and out. Journalists reporting on the National Party leadership scuffle swooped on the oddly Kiwi word "bagmen" to refer to the candidates' chief lobbyists in caucus... Elsewhere a bagman can be lot of things, all pretty well removed from getting in the vote for Bill or Don. In Oz it's an alternative to swagman.  Elsewhere, it is a commercial traveller. Elsewhere again, and more sinisterly, it is one who collects racketeers' money. In a list of Post Office workers, it appears with porters. The <i>New Oxford Dictionary of New Zealand English</i> reckons it's a man who helps fill sacks of grain. The nearest to our special meaning is a Canadian reference to "political fundraiser".

This being repeated a few times with each cow, is generally sufficient to teach them to walk in of themselves afterwards

when driven up to the bail.

Author:  CAMPBELL
Vol / Page:  1/3/42
Edition:
Quote:  [The bush rangers'] mode of proceeding was something after this fashion: on arriving they collected all the inmates of the house .. and placed a sentry with a loaded gun over them, with the instructions to shoot, without compunction, any recreant individual who dared to stir `a --- inch', in the delicate language employed. This was termed `baling up'.

Quote:  <I>Baldy! </I>I refuse (cf English schoolboy's `fain I'): NZ juvenile: late C19-20. B., 1941. No hairs on one's head: nothing to offer.

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author:  TURNER
Vol / Page:  158
Edition:
Quote:  ... the way to ask for a truce in a game is to call Pax ... At the school I went to, the word was <I>Fritz</I>, and the truce was terminated by the call <I>Fritz all over</I>, but we knew that some schools used <I>Fans</I> (from south-west English dialect <I>fain I</I> or <I>fainits</I>?. Apparently some New Zealand schools use or have used<I> baldy</I> which sounds like a variant of English <I>barley. </I>

Quote:  <I>Bale</I>: Package of wool in a regulation wool pack, weighing at least 100 kg. Maximum packed weights allowed under regulations are 181 kg for fleece and lambs wool and 204 kg for oddments.

Balkan Tap
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a wartime condition of madness (facetious)
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  15/9/1918
Source:  Kia-ora Coo-ee
Author:
Vol / Page:  Second Series 3/12
Edition:  1981
Quote:   In this land two infections assail all comers and vie with one another for first place. These are known as Malaria and Balkan Tap respectively. On the first we need not dwell, but a little information about the latter may be of interest. A similar infection has been met with elsewhere, and in Gyppo Land is known as `magnune', whilst away in our own sunny island I think `dippy' about covered it. Here we have a more or less insidious form of the disease, and no one with six months' residence to his credit may hope to escape. There are two varieties of the disease, malignant and benign. In the latter form the symptoms are easily recognised, and are amenable to treatment; but with the malignant type the victims, quite unconscious of infection, blindly affirm their condition to be normal, This form of the malady has several unfortunate features and is incurable. The percentage in our unit is very high.
Notes:

Quote:  He lit a candle, and dropped it into the Ballarat lantern, and away they went. [fn] For the benefit of the unitiated, I may explain that a `Ballarat lantern' is formed by knocking off the bottom of a bottle, and putting a candle in its neck.

The practical sealers believed that the stones served to adjust the buoyancy of the animals and referred to the stone-filled stomach of the fur seal as the `ballast bag'.

ballies

See:

Citations
Date:  0/0/1984
Source:  NZ Yesterdays
Author:  KEITH & MAIN
Vol / Page:  288
Edition:
Quote:  Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles.
Notes:

balloon

Sense Number:

Citations
Date:  10/3/2003
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  C2
Edition:
Quote:  However, the balloon is down for both stocks. In the days before modern communications at the races, a balloon signalled that the tote was open. When it went up it was a sign that the tote was closed and the horses were ready to race. And as very punter knew, when the balloon fell your money remained at risk until the race ended and the winner was declared.

balloonfish
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]

Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  378
Edition:
Quote:  GLOBE-FISH <i>Contusus richei</i> (Freminville) ... It has several other popular names such as Balloon-fish and Mouse-fish. In America it is known as Rabbit-fish and Stink-fish. The most humorous name is that of Publican-fish. The names Globe-fish and Balloon-fish were given because of the animal's habit of inflating itself with air to such an extent that the body was like a lamp globe or an inflated balloon.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  28

Balmoral oak
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Pinus radiata logs or timber; aka Pinus horizontalis
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: -
Pronunciation:
Notes: ca1954 (R.Mason) used by A.L. Poole, a humorous name used in the NZ Forest Service for <i>P. radiata</i> timber, esp. in Canterbury. The Balmoral State Forest in Canterbury was heavily damaged by wind in the early 1950's, and the pine windfalls provide a plentiful (but hard to dispose of) source of timber.

banded
Homonym Number:
Word Class: adjective
Sense Number:
Definition: As a distinguishing epithet in the names of birds and fish (`having a band of different coloured feathers or scales; or having characteristic band rather than blocks of colours'): bellowsfish, blenny, dotterel, galaxias, kokopu, moki, parrotfish, perch, rail, pigfish, rockcod, seaperch.

Sense Number:

banded rail
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: katatai, moho; occas. New Zealand banded rail; a now scarce ground-dwelling swamp bird, similar to but smaller than the weka, with long toes, short tail and black and white striped underside.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1881
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  13/196
Edition:
Quote:  In shape, [the family Trachypteridae] are usually long, deep, and very much compressed and flattened on the sides, so much so that their local appellations always embody some idea of these peculiarities - such as ribband-fish, lath or deal fish, band fish or blade fish, and also oar-fish.

bandicoot
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: [AND 1896 potatoes] To steal potatoes by removing the tubers without disarranging the haulms; to rabbit.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  Personal Communication
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Jane Godfrey, My father used to tell (c 19..) us to bandicoot about a bit when he wanted us to dig out bits of earth (say around a post) with our hands, sort of pulling the earth towards the side of the hole, softening it, etc.
Notes:  AC1898; nf W3

Date:  0/1/2004
Source:  Onslow Historian
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 34(1/2) : 6
Edition:
Quote:  Another was also proud of the growth of his potatoes but highly amazed and full of anger when upon digging them up he found virtually nothing underneath. He was unaware that some bright sparks had on one night bandicooted his spuds. Bandicooting as it was called, was done by scratching away the dirt from the spuds, taking them from underneath the tops and replacing the mulch and everything looked normal.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1976
Source:  Water Joey
Author:  ANDERSON
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  No wonder they raided the farmer's orchards, pinched his eggs and bandycooted his potatoes and vegetables.
Notes:  1977 edition

bang slap
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: in collocation, as a noun or av, an intensifying elaboration of bang: e.g. I ran bang-slap into it.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1922
Source:  Stories
Author:  MANSFIELD
Vol / Page:  488
Edition:  Alpers 1984
Quote:  `... You see, with a thing like a marquee, ... you want to put it somewhere where it'll give you a bang slap in the eye, if you follow me.' Laura's upbringing made her wonder whether it was quite respectful of a workman to talk to her of bang slaps in the eye.

banjo
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:  a shovel [f. the shape]; also attrib banjo shovel.


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/1/2002
Source:  NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 55/96
Edition:
Quote:  The 200 men who started work on the Te Anau-to-Milford road in 1929 were armed with tools ancient Egyptians would be flattered to see still in use: wheelbarrows, picks, and round shovels the locals call "banjos."
Notes:

Date:  22/3/1912
Source:  Maoriland Worker
Author:
Vol / Page:  54/9/2
Edition:
Quote:  He performed the herculean(?) [sic] task of turning the first sod of the Waihi-Tauranga railway, with a specially sand-papered and varnished `banjo' of rather less than the orthodox No. 5 size.

seeing his boss using a `banjo' that he lay down and died.


Notes:  1977 ed.

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Speaking a Silence
Author:  HUNT
Vol / Page:  133
Edition:
Quote:  And they'd go down the mine, ... scrape the coal down and load it into the skips by hand with great big `banjo' shovels. Then there were the old `pit-spiders', steel hooks you'd jab into the mine wall and hang your lamp on.


Notes:

Date:  1/3/1986
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  Not for me the noisy proline/ but the quiet of the auger and fang-spanner - / long tom and jim crow,/ strumming on the old banjo./ ...  [fn] long tom: long blade used for placing measured amount of gravel under sleepers jim crow: large horseshoe-shaped tool, with screw, used for bending rails banjo: shovel
Notes:  David George `Euchre Weather'

Source:  Armageddon or Calvary

Edition:

Notes:  Glossary

Date:  0/7/2004

Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 68/50
Edition:
Quote:  Despite all the advances in mining technology that have happened since men hewed the coal seams in these hills with picks and the broad, rounded shovels known as "banjos" a centruty ago, the traditional eight-hour shifts have been kept: day shirt (7-3), night shift (3-11) and dog shift (11-7).

hard slog at the face with a pick, the

laborious shovelling with the wide-

mouthed banjo. <i>Ibid.</i>. 128 You filled the tub [with coal], shoving the big banjo into the soft heap at your feet ... <i>Ibid.</i> (Glossary) 242 banjo coal shovel

bank and bank
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: of a river, in flood; cf. banker.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1863
Source:  First Year in Canterbury Settlement
Author:  BUTLER
Vol / Page:  vi/79
Edition:
Quote:  Sometimes, perhaps half a dozen times in a year, the river is what is called bank and bank; that is to say, one mass of water from one side to the other.
Notes:  1860 in 1863 Butler First Year vi 79

Date:  30/1/1864
Source:  Chudleigh Diary
Author:
Vol / Page:  120
Edition:  1950
Quote:  I heard the Rakaia was bank and bank so I went to Harman's to see O.Brien.
Notes:

Date:  9/9/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>bank and bank</i>. A river runs bank and bank when all the streams join into one; i.e., when in high flood (Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p. 73). Hence a banker. The expressions were probably introduced by the shagroons. [Morris Austral English] gives a banker as meaning a river full to the top of its banks. New Zealand rivers, of course, do not get as full as that.
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Bank of New Zealand
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  25/6/1887
Source:  Auckland Weekly News
Author:
Vol / Page:  22
Edition:
Quote:  I take a good deal more notice of the Bank of New Zealand than I do of the other banking institutions. It is for the reasons that it is our own national establishment, and every man, woman, and child, is interested in its welfare and affected by its management. Virtually, it belongs to the public; the shareholders, nominally the proprietors, are merely trustees. My view may be extreme on this point but I believe the day is not far distant when the people of New Zealand will take possession of that bank in their own name, and tax all the others out of the country - a protection policy that would pay well.

Quote:  Banker: In other countries a banker is a river threatening to overflow its banks. But in New Zealand, many of whose rivers have several streams meandering about the same bed, these rivers become bankers, or bank-and-bank, when the spate is sufficient to cause all the streams to unite.

Vol / Page:   V/30/183
Edition:
Quote:  Kapanga River Diggings,/ Coromandel harbour,/ 4th November, 1852. ... the annexed tabular report of the work at this Gold-field since my arrival. ... wherever I and the Messrs. Ring have `prospected' on the Kapanga ..., we have found gold, and that the greatest number of flakes in the prospecting dish, appeared upon washing some earth yesterday at a bar about half a mile lower down the stream ...; and below all the present diggings.
Notes:  (Heaphy's Report)

Date:  10/12/1852
Source:  NZ Government Gazette
Author:
Vol / Page:  V/30/187
Edition:
Quote:  Wednesday, Nov. 3./ How employed/ Down to bar at junction of path and stream, ... setting `Tom', &c. Digging and washing./ Remarks/ The earth passed through the `Tom' was top stuff, incidental to opening a new bar.


Notes:  (Heaphy's Tabular Journal)

bar
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1906
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  38/22
Edition:
Quote:  In the Thames district the distance between the numerous parallel veins which traverse the goldfield seldom exceeds 200 yards, and in almost every instance the veins are separated from each other by a narrow belt of hard unaltered andesite. These hard bands, or `bars' as the miners term them, possess the same general strike and dip as the veins ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin
Author:
Vol / Page:   4(NS):101
Edition:
Quote:  The country rock separating two veins approximately parallel with each other has, in certain instances, been found to grade laterally from the vein-wall, where it assumes a highly propylitic facies, to a median rib of dark and only slightly altered rock. These ribs or dyke-like masses are the `hard bars' of the miners. In some cases, however, these `hard bars' are probably due to dykes. <i>Ibid.</I> 111The `hard bars' of mining terminology are in most cases merely remnants of less-altered rock, but occasionally as in the case of the `bar' mentioned in the Golden Pah mine, they owe their existence to intrusives.
Notes:  (Fraser and Adams, Coromandel)

Date:  0/0/1948
Source:  NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin
Author:
Vol / Page:  42(NS):39
Edition:
Quote:  Further, the `hard' bars most probably interrupted the shoot, more of less horizontally.
Notes:  (Gage, Reefton)

Date:  0/0/1984
Source:  Gallipoli: the New Zealand Story
Author:  PUGSLEY
Vol / Page:  76
Edition:
Quote:  Those inflicted with venereal disease were treated as criminals.(?) A large venereal disease hospital was established near the Australian lines and run by the Australians for both Australians and New Zealanders. It was surrounded by barbed wire and guards to prevent men breaking out. Men unfortunate enough to be so caught earned the sobriquet `barbed wire' soldiers: `and it was rumoured that there were sufficient officers and men to form a whole battalion from colonel down - not omitting the padre.'
Notes:  [c1914]

Barber
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the prevailing Greymouth wind; a cold, cutting wind [ADD the vapour rising from the water on a frosty day: 1895: Can., NB, NS, Nfdland: DARE A winter storm in which frozen ice crystals are driven by fierce winds. 1832, 1889 Farmer (Cn.), 1889 St Laurence, Nova Scotia New England coast, 1982 strong wind that carries precipitation which freezes beard etc: DNfE 1. Cold mist or vapour arising from the sea on a frosty day; frost-smoke 1836 2. A sharp, stinging wind 1879: OED2 1c transf. Applied colloq. to a bitterly cold wind which seems to `cut' the face. Chiefly Can and NZ. Also = frost-smoke (cf Frost n 7c 1830 Can); 1933 NZ cf J Angus Gloss of Shetland Dialect: Barber, a haze which rises from the surface of the water with very keen freezing.] Often constr. with def. art., a keen, cutting wind (often with mist or fog). NZ orig. a West Coast, SI use, but by the 1950s fairly gen. in other parts of the SI, but not heard or recorded in the North: popularly derived from its being, e.g., `close cutting', `as keen as a razor',
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1908
Source:  With the British Rugby team
Author:  BARR
Vol / Page:  75
Edition:
Quote:  They have a prevailing wind at Greymouth

called "The Barber" which sweeps down the

Otira Gorge and smites the inhabitants

hip and thigh... a keen biting wind which

cuts like a sabre-thrust, nips like an

ant, and stings like a whip-lash.`What do you think of `The Barber'?' in Greymouth is synonymous with `What do you think of our harbour?' in Sydney ...
Notes:

Quote:  A very bitter cold wind which blows down the gorge of the Mawhera and afflicts the river front, railway station, and adjacent streets of Greymouth. The miners and drovers used the word in the 'sixties, and it is still in use. (C.[1890-1910])
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Date:  0/0/1951
Source:  Letter
Author:  PUGH-WILLIAMS
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  A very cold, slow-moving wind that comes down to Greymouth from the inland of a winter evening and then recedes the following day. It brings foggy conditions and is most unpleasant. I am unaware of its origin but locals inform me that it is nowhere as bad as some 20 years ago, their theory being that so much of the bush is cut out with the result that rain-saturated foliage is not exposed for fog-generating.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1963
Source:  Coal Flat
Author:  PEARSON
Vol / Page:  393
Edition:
Quote:  This day was clear. There was a frost on the grass in the morning, and a `barber' - the keen wind and night mist blowing down from the Grey Valley - was pushing across Blakestown ... and disappearing over the sea.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author:  TURNER
Vol / Page:  163
Edition:
Quote:  There are several local names for winds, the <i>doctor</i> in Perth, ... the <i>barber</i> in Greymouth, N Z, a very cuttng wind, the Canterbury <i>nor'wester</i> resembling the European <i>Fo[diereis]hn</i> wind, ... and the<i> three-day sou'wester </i>in New Zealand, a form of the <i>southerly buster</i>, a name used in both Australia and New Zealand, probably more often in the shortened form a [sic] <i>southerly. </i>

barber's pole
Homonym Number:

Sense Number:  1

Barcoo
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: occas. previously used in NZ with some of the senses of boohai.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1960
Source:  Memories of Maoriland
Author:  SCRYMGEOUR
Vol / Page:  157
Edition:
Quote:  Another memory that lingered on the trip, was that from Napier to Gisborne, to inspect a property known as `Te Rapa' and nearby was a `pubbery' (certainly not a hotel, for anybody would wonder why the Licensed Victuallers Association ever granted a licence for meals or liquor to be dispensed), and was typically designated `The Trap'. Truly, this pubbery was just short of shanty, typical of the `Outer Barcoo', but where Maories, their Wahines, or broken down `Remittancers' could drown their sorrows, wander into the `arms of Bacchus' or chase pink elephants.
Notes:

barebelly
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a sheep that has lost all or most of the wool from its underside, a sheep with defective wool-growth caused by a break in the fibre structure, hence shedding on belly and legs; a sheep with (much of) its belly-wool scraped off or shed.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1875
Source:  Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author:  MEREDITH
Vol / Page:  143
Edition:  1935
Quote:  When the word is given to start, the shearers go into the `catching-pen' and feel over the sheep, select one, carry it out on to the shearing-floor, and commence shearing. Naturally, the easiest-shorn sheep -- `bare-bellies' and `bare points' -- are selected first. It is amusing to watch the tactics of some of the shearers to dodge the Kapara (Cobbler) the last sheep in the pen, which, presumably, is the worst shearing sheep of the lot.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1878
Source:  Boy Colonists
Author:  ELWELL
Vol / Page:  109
Edition:
Quote:  The [merino] ewes have many of them at shearing time no wool on the legs or under the belly, and hence are called `bare-bellies'. Of course these `bare-bellied' ewes ... are quickly shorn.

Quote:  <i>bare belly</i>: A sheep with defective wool growth caused by a break in the fibre structure. This causes the wool to fall off the belly and legs and is more common in ewes. These sheep are sometimes called `Rosellas'.

barking-up
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:  cit. 1966
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Boss's Story, The
Author:  NEWTON
Vol / Page:  185
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Barking-up:</i> During the course of his mustering work the musterer frequently gets his team to bark while at heel (i.e. alongside him) the object being to frighten sheep along without actually running a dog. This is known as `barking-up'. On the free-running sheep this obviates a lot of work.
Notes:

bark-up
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a situation where a musterer stands at a vantage point and instructs his/her dogs to bark, to reveal presence and movement of sheep and/or to show his position to other musterers.

Barnes dance
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Pedestrians scurrying across a street diagonally as soon as the indicator says `Go' or `Cross': at crossings where all traffic halts: Aust. and N.Z. since ca. 1950. The former was named after Commissioner Barnes of New York City - the inventor of the buzz crossing: origin of the latter, obvious. A pedestrian crossing which stops all vehicular traffic and allows pedestrians to cross the roadway in any direction,
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: 1988 p.c. J.E.P. Thomson Heard in Dunedin for a `pedestrian crossing', thought by some to be a Dunedin coinage after a Barnes in the Dunedin traffic department.

Quote:  [sc. traffic light], The taxi crawled along Princes Street [Dunedin], stopping at every Barnes' Dance traffic light, turned west at the Exchange and up Rattray and McClaggan Streets.

Quote:  Baroona is a funny name for a beer... it is associated with seasickness in the minds of many who squatted in its scrawny, diesel-filled guts, while it pitched and rolled its way across the Waitemata in search of Waiheke Island. <i>Baroona</i> was that ferry, now it is the name of Waiheke Island's one and only beer. There was a time when the residents of some Hauraki Gulf slands referred to the need to regurgitate after a bout of over-indulgence as "gotta have a baroona".

barrack
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: Noisy chaff, cheek (usu.good-humoured) cf baragin
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Barrack v and n, and derivatives are borrowed from Australian  usage; barracker n, a supporter of a sports team is the earliest  recorded NZ use ; with barracking vbl n `chaffing' also early. The verb is recorded from early in the 20 century mainly from Truth. -->The two senses probably have separate derivations: v1 `to support', `cheer for', from N.Irish (EDD) barrack, `to brag, be boastful of one's fighting powers': the example given from Antrim: ` `One boy will say of another `He's only barracking'. v2 `to chaff; attack with words' from an Aboriginal negative  barak; in Australia and New Zealand often found as borak, and  anglicised and folk-formed to borax (cf POKE BORAX). -->but cf the curious usage: -->1668(?) Dryden `A Defence of an Essay of Dr. P.' ed D. Nicol Smith 133 ... and that in some authors reserare was to shut as well  as to open, as the word barack, say the learned, is both to bless and curse.

The barrackers set the music for the game.

barrack
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number: 2
Definition: to support noisily, to applaud (one's own team).1890 b. transf. argue for a cause 1897 (barrack for drunks).] [Where the action of the verb is directed against the object.]
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Vol / Page:  86
Edition:
Quote:  <i> barrack 2 vb. Brit. & Austral. inf. 1.</i> to criticize loudly or shout against (a team, speaker, etc.); jeer.
Notes:  [1986 NZPOD 55; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 40],



Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  2017
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Bar&#769;.rack</i> (b&abreve.r&#769;.rak), <i>v. i</i>. [Said to be fr. aboriginal <i>borak</i> banter, badinage; but cf. Prov. Eng. <i>barrack</i>brag, <i>barracker</i> a braggart. See BARRACK, v. t., BORAK, <i>n. 1</i>. To cheer, shout, or make a din, by way of partisan encouragement or derision, especially at a football game.<i> </i>2. To give partisan support in any way; as, to <i>barrack</i> for the school. [Colloq.]

barracker
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: [AND merely `one who barracks' 1889 (in a football club); M 1893; AC 1892; W3.] (Enthusiastic) Supporter; (and in a weakened sense) (vociferous) spectator (esp at sports gatherings, esp. rugby union).

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1929
Source:  Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.
Author:
Vol / Page:  1
Edition:
Quote:  <i> ~ n</i>. shouting and cheering in chorus with a view to encouraging or discouraging one of the participants in a game, such as cricket. - <i>barracker n.</i>- to barrack for v.i. to clamour for; to support or discourage noisily. [Abor. borack, chaff at another's expense]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1974
Source:  Australian & NZ English [TS]
Author:  SYDER & HODGETTS
Vol / Page:  37
Edition:
Quote:  Vigorous vocal support during the match for one of the teams: In a contest , e.g. cricket or football, or to one of two opponents in a contest, of physical skill. `Barracking' also includes sternly-voiced rebukes to the opposing team if they do not play fair, but also some fair praise for them at the moment of a fine display of skill. .in 4;`Come on, the Magpies. Go,man, go!' or `Get off his back! Get off his back. The bastard. See that. Oh! Oh! All he needs is a pair of spurs!'

[The Southern Kingfish is] Called Hake in southern fish shops but bears no resemblance to the traditional English Hake which is far less oily. Tasmanian kingfish, barraconda and `tikati' (Maori) are other names.

Notes:

barracouta
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: 1. Thyrsites atun. =manga [the <i>snoek, snook</i> of the Cape of Good Hope]. Freq. spg bar(r)acoota; also barac(o)uta, barrac(o)uda,  benecoota, benecootoo, ?boracoota, ?paracuta . See also barra, coota, king barracouta: contrast barracuda. [AND Leionura atun 1770 Cook, 1835: transf use of w. Indian barracuda, barracouta.] 1. A Southern Hemisphere fish similar but unrelated to the barracuda, usu. with long needle-like teeth. Also called manga. 2. An oblong bread loaf with a raised crust baked in an open tin [f. Spanish barracuda.]


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: see also barra, coota, king barracouta
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations

Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  30
Edition:
Quote:  The barracouta is one of the few fish New

Zealander anglers will encounter with

teeth large or sharp enough to cut

through most monofilament lines with

ease.

Notes:

barracouta
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: A nominal one-and-a-half pound loaf, baked long and narrow in an open-topped tin to give a raised crust which fancifully resembles the (back of a) barracouta fish, and often indented in the middle to enable breaking into two `quarter' loaves; also barracouta loaf.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: also couta
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  7/12/1935
Source:  Christchurch Star-Sun
Author:
Vol / Page:  00
Edition:
Quote:  [Advt] Sunland's Many Varieties. Brought

to you each day by the Sunland Bread

Man... Long Tin.. Concertina or Ring

Loaf.. Vienna.. Barr[a]couta].


Notes:  Check page number

Date:  0/0/1916
Source:  Aloe, The
Author:  MANSFIELD
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  She had a ... plate of butter ... on the table before her and a big loaf called a `barracouta' ... .[fn 162] `barracouta': a longish narrow loaf with a rounded raised crust, fancifully resembling the barracouta  fish (<i>Thyrsites atun</i>).


Notes:  1982 O'Sullivan p. 121

Date:  0/0/1934
Source:  Bread Baking in NZ
Author:  BYCROFT Ltd
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Single or straight Barracuda.

Date:  0/0/1988

Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  <i>barracouta</i> oblong loaf of bread with raised crust, resembling the fish with the fearsome bite; displaced by French loaf.  b. barracouta loaf.

barracouta hook
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1845
Source:  Adventure in NZ
Author:  WAKEFIELD
Vol / Page:  1/183
Edition:
Quote:  At the end of a stick three or four feet long, which [Worser] held in his hand, there was fastened by some three feet of strong line, a piece of red wood four inches long, two broad, and one inch thick. Through the end of the wood a common nail was driven, and turned back so as to form a rude hook. On the approach of the shoal, Worser thrashed the water within his reach with the bit of wood and the end of his rod, whirling it round with great speed ... when one was hooked, a dextrous heave flung him on on the deck with centrifugal force...]
Notes:

Date:  7/10/2004
Source:  Dominion Post

Vol / Page:  B5
Edition:
Quote:  His book included an account of "barrelling", or organised beatings... The cadet said time and place of barrelling would be spread among the cadets, and the staff would disappear. A cadet of the early 1880s, Mike, describes a "lesser barrelling", which involved being tied to a bed, taken outside and leaned up against a wall. Shaving cream, toothpaste, nugget and even excrement were rubbed on the victim who was then hosed off.
Notes:  1980s not 1880s presumably (and he would be very hosed off I should imagine) TD

Edition:

barrier
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a long narrow sandy island lying parallel to a shore and built up by the action of the waves, currents and wind. Also called an offshore bar.


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

barrier

[ed. fn. Correctly, manoao, a podocarp tree also known as Barrier pine.]

Barrier skink
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a rock-dwelling, sun-loving skink found in the Barrier Knob area of Fiordland National Park.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: <i>Oligosoma</i> sp. 'Barrier'  [tag name; formal nomenclature pending]
Citations
Date:  0/11/2008
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  The tag name 'Barrier skink' was given to these skinks.  These 'Barrier skinks' were medium to large in size (reaching up to 81 mm SVL [snout to vent length], 179mm TL, and weighting up to 12.1 g.) they were mainly black dorsally and laterally, with yellowish, green, cream or brown flecks, and white ventrally, with occasional black speckles...
Notes:  http://csl.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/drds304.pdf  Alpine lizard research in Fiordland National Park: February - March 2007. Bell, T.P.; Patterson, G.; Jewell, T. 2008. DOC Research & Development Series 304 NZ Dept of Conservation, Wellington.

Date:  0/0/2009
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Taxonomic resolution and their subsequent conservation for both the Barrier and mahogany skinks were given urgent priority by DOC Southland in May 2007...
Notes:  http://www.landcareresearch.co.nz/research/wildlifeecol/herpetology/projects.asp

Quote:  <i>Barrow</i>.- To shear or partly shear a sheep for a shearer. `No barrowing allowed on the board' was at one time a rule which the Shearers' Union got into the award. Boys often finish or begin a sheep for a shearer, who, of course, is responsible for its being properly shorn. (C.)

Quote:  Then caver ingenuity came to the rescue in the form of Hamilton speleologist Barry Weir. Weir came up with a 100w helmet light set like a cherry in an aluminium throwaway pie dish which when charged will give 20-30 minutes' illumination. These 45c battery-powered devices even provided light when caving divers went underwater ... The device has been so successful it has been used subsequently. The inventor now has his name in lights. Crews in Dunedin refer to them as `Barry lights'.

Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  There are ten native species of rata in New Zealand all in the genus Metrosideros. Four of these form trees (northern rata, southern rata, Bartlett's rata and Parkinson's rata) and the remaining six species are all lianes.
Notes:  http://www.nzpcn.org.nz/page.asp?flora_vascular_flowering_plants_dicots_rata

Date:  0/7/2000
Source:  NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 47/12
Edition:
Quote:  The rarest of New Zealand's 12 species of <i>Metrosideros</i> was discovered less than 20 years ago by Papakura teacher and botanist the late John Bartlett... Like the northern rata, <i>M. robusta</i>, Bartlett's rata usually starts life as an epiphyte perched in the branches of another tree or ponga... Although some of New Zealand's shrub ratas have white flowers, this species is the only tree to have them.
Notes:

Date:  23/10/2004
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  E13

base walloper
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an alteration of gen. military base-wallah (with pun on base `bum'), a soldier, esp. an officer, employed behind the lines at base; a member of Base Staff; base-walloper, -wallower, bludger, bum-buzzard.

Date:  0/9/1947

Author:  DAVIN
Vol / Page:  147
Edition:
Quote:  `The working class can kiss my arse, I've got a bludger's job at last,' sang Smithy to the tune of the Red Flag ... `All the boys sing it whenever they pass Bludger's Hill. ... Makes the base-wallahs mad.' ... `Almost makes a man want to be a base walloper. ... A nice quiet life. Nothing to do except get up in the morning and get the shaving water, make the bed, polish some buttons to keep away from parade, queue for a feed, siesta, tea, a beer at the Naafi in the evening, a game of two-up and so to bed'.

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  <i>base walloper </i>Kiwi version of a base wallah, or military pen pusher; `wallah', Hindi `wala', connected with, was habitually added on to functions to suggest functionary in Anglo-Indian army; here refined by pun on base as bum.

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author:  TURNER
Vol / Page:  132
Edition:
Quote:  In New Zealand, the term <i>bash</i> for a party where drink is the chief attraction is heard (or was, some years ago among Wellington students) and <i>hophead</i> for a person who drinks regularly. The term <i>hophead</i> is (or was) used in convivial greetings, `Hello, hophead', the implication that the person addressed was a persistent drinker being equivalent to calling him a decent joker.

Quote:  <i>Bash</i>: Wild uncontrolled blow by a shearer.

Date:  0/0/1936
Source:  Agricultural Organization in NZ
Author:
Vol / Page:  389
Edition:
Quote:   The relative merits of superphosphate and basic slag for pasture top-dressing are much discussed in certain districts, particularly North Taranaki and North Auckland. Many experienced farmers are firmly of the opinion that slagged pastures have better milk production and fattening capacities than ones treated with superphosphate. How much this may be due to a greater effect from slag, how much to some effect on the mineral content of the herbage, and how much due to management it is impossible to say.

Standing by, the Moree native engaged in taking off the trimmings around the udder, then deliberately swept the glistening steel of his razor shears across the teats of the stud ewe, and deliberately shore them off level with the belly line.

basket fungus
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an unpleasant-smelling fungus, Ileodictyon cibarium, that expands to release a latticed structure from a white sphere (also called devil's purse or stink egg, lattice or net fungus, paruwhatitiri, thunder-dirt).
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: paruwhatitiri, net fungus
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1997
Source:  Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ
Author:  CROWE
Vol / Page:  123
Edition:
Quote:  Basket fungus starts off growing rather like a puffball 3-4 cm wide, but later, when the ball bursts, a white basket-like shape breaks out... The Maori ate the thick gelatinous volva or outer shell when young and before it burst.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1922
Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page:  5/247
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Clathrus cibarius</i>, THE `BIRD-CAGE FUNGUS'. ... This fungus, known variously as `basket fungus,'`lattice fungus,', `Devil's purse,'  `<i>tutae whetu,' `tutae kehua</i>,' belongs to the Phallaceae, a family included in the Basidiomycetes. It is found commonly throughout New Zealand during the late autumn and early spring. [Distribution.- Australia; Chile; ... New Zealand]


Notes:  Cunningham

Date:  0/0/1957
Source:  Dictionary of the Maori Language
Author:  WILLIAMS
Vol / Page:  188
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Matakupenga ... 3. Clathrus cibarium</i>, net or basket fungus. = <i>pukurau.</i>


Notes:

Date:  0/10/1959
Source:  Tararua Tramper
Author:
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  The Maori treated unexpanded plants of the basket fungus as a great luxury.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1929
Source:  Flora NZ
Author:  MARTIN
Vol / Page:  39
Edition:  1961
Quote:   ... the Phalloids to which belong such conspicuous fungi as the SCARLET STINKHORN (<i>Aseroe rubra</i>) and the BASKET FUNGUS  (<i>Clathrus cibarius</i>).  [40]The BASKET FUNGUS or LATTICE FUNGUS spreads its globular latticed network a conspicuous white, slimy structure with an unpleasant odour, that never fails to amaze its beholders. Its miraculous and sudden appearance caused the ancient Maori to term it `thunder dirt'.
Notes:  1961 ed.

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Oxford Book of NZ Plants
Author:  MOORE & IRWIN
Vol / Page:  12
Edition:

basket social
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a social event where food is raffled or sold to raise money
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  11/4/1921
Source:  Mataura Ensign
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  A well attended basket social was held at the residence of Mr. and Mrs. P. Maclean, Kelvin Road, Waimumu on Friday evening, ...
Notes:  in 1966 Barry In the Lee of the Hokonuis 363

Date:  7/6/1952
Source:  Personal Communication
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Basket social: a1949 North Auckland. As I understood it a function for making money. People bring a `basket' (in the sense `Ladies, a basket') of food which is auctioned and often re-auctioned.
Notes:  R. Mason Letter

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  Speaking for Ourselves
Author:  OWEN & PERKINS
Vol / Page:  150
Edition:
Quote:  (Joe Gasparich, Northland kauri country), The way in which the bush people - the bushmen and their wives -

stuck to one another is shown by the way they rallied round in the case of a family that was in need. A common method of raising money was called a `basket social'. A hall would be used for the function, and the

people of the district would be invited to bring along baskets. Now these baskets were made of any material

at all at hand, and it was remarkable the ingenuity and workmanship shown in making them. ... In the basket its maker put a supper, the food cooked at home ... [151] Now on the night of the basket social, all the baskets

would be handed in ... They would then be auctioned, and the purchaser of the basket would have the pleasure

and the honour of having supper with the provider of the basket. ... Now I've seen them pay twelve ... pounds in those days for a basket, just to make sure that the girl of the boy's choice saw that he really meant business. ... Every penny of that would go to the family in need ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1987
Source:  Sing Vila in the Mountain
Author:  BATISTICH
Vol / Page:  146
Edition:
Quote:  Basket socials were always a stir [in Northland c1920s]. ... Basket socials were the nearest we got to bacchanalia - tipsy cake in large doses could have strangely affecting results. The baskets were put up for auction just before the supper waltz; highest bidder got basket and girl - the girl, sometimes it turned out, for life.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1955
Source:  Dim Horizons
Author:  BOSWEL
Vol / Page:  31
Edition:
Quote:  And then the mill workers organized a big basket social for us, and with the money they arranged a grand picnic. <i>Ibid.</i> 153 [pre WW1, Northland bush], A basket social took the form of a dance, with an auction of supper baskets. Each girl would make a pretty basket and fill it with good things for supper. When supper-time came, the baskets were auctioned from the stage and keen was the rivalry and competition for some of the baskets, young blades emptying their pockets and often dipping into their bank accounts in trying to out-bid their rivals.
Notes:  Northland 1890's

Date:  18/7/1918
Source:  Hawke's Bay Herald
Author:
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:
Quote:  A basket social and dance.. for Maori

soldiers.. turned out an unqualified

success.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  Speaking for Ourselves
Author:  OWEN & PERKINS
Vol / Page:  150
Edition:
Quote:  A common method of raising money was called a 'basket social'... The people of the district would be invited to bring along baskets. Now these baskets were made of any material at all to hand... In the baskets, the maker put a supper... Nobody knew who was the owner of the basket. They would then be auctioned.

Date:  0/0/1970

Author:  SORENSON
Vol / Page:  26
Edition:
Quote:  GROPER (two species)  (a) Scientific name: (i)<i> Polyprion oxygeneios</i>  (ii) <i>Polyprion moeone</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) New Zealand Groper; Hapuku (ii) Bass. (c) Other common names: (i) Hapuka, Stone-eye, Blue-nose, Bonita (ii) Deepsea Groper. (d) Principal localities where taken: [Mainly easten coasts, Foveaux, and Chathams] ... [27 Groper and Bass] should not be confused with the Australian and tropical groupers which they resemble superficially.

bastard
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: adjective
Sense Number:
Definition: as a distinguishing epithet in names of plants which resemble (but often cannot match qualities of) their namesakes; or occas. have displeasing or nasty (`bastardly') qualities (e.g. astard-grass): see birch; grass, bastard grass; pine, black; puriri, sandalwood; thistle, nodding; thistle, scotch [check that not deleted in editing]; totara.

Notes:  Graham Fishes of Otago Harbour

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  173
Edition:
Quote:  BASTARD RED COD <i>Physiculus (Pseudophycis) breviusculus</i> (Richardson) The vernacular name of this fish was first given to it by commercial fishmen who, when one was hooked and brought to the surface, would exclaim: ` - another bastard Red Cod!' meaning to say it was not a true Red Cod; the name stuck to this fish and was used by line fishermen of Otago.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/372
Edition:
Quote:  The bastard red cod (<i>Pseudophycis breviusculus</i>) is stouter, a deeper red in colour, and has a rounded tail fin.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collins Guide
Author:  AYLING
Vol / Page:  143
Edition:  1984
Quote:  <i>NORTHERN BASTARD RED COD Pseudophycis breviuscula (Physiculus breviusculus)</i> ... The bastard red cod is similar in shape to the red cod but is much smaller ... <i>Ibid.</i> 144 <i>SOUTHERN BASTARD RED COD</i> (Bearded rock cod)

<i>Pseudophycis barbata</i> ... The southern bastard red cod, known as the bearded rock cod in Australia, is similar to the red cod but does not reach such a large size.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  PAUL
Vol / Page:  58
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Bastard red cods</i> There are two species related and rather similar to the red cod ... they are not easily separated from each other. <i>Pseudophycis barbata</i> occurs round the South Island ... and <i>P. breviuscula </i>around the northern North Island.

Much to `Truth's' deep regret, for it detests having to give the show away, lately, at Miramar, when some road-making or mountain-razing work has been going on, some of them have engaged in the simple yet sinful process of tossing two bright copper pennies, with a bit of wood, popularly known as `the bat' or `the kip' and, therefore, in the eye of the law are hardened criminals.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1926
Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
Author:  HILGENDORF [& CALDER]
Vol / Page:  171
Edition:
Quote:  BATHURST BURR (<i>Xanthium spinosum</i>) `is not uncommon in warm and rich soils from the North Cape to the Waikato, rarer southwards to Wellington,' but occurs only on waste lands and corners of cultivated fields. It is a shrubby annual from 9 inches to 3 ft. in height; ... This plant was introduced about 1890, and caused a considerable scare, owing to the fact that in Australia, and one may suppose particularly at Bathurst, it caused depreciation in the wool estimated at 3d. per pound. It has, however, never caused any trouble here, and is hardly recognised by sheep farmers, even where it is most common ...


Notes:  1967 ed.

Date:  0/0/1928

Notes:

Bathurst burr
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a burred weed, Xanthium spinosum, particularly troublesome in sheep country [also used erroneously for Californian stinkweed, digger's weed (Navarettia squarrosa)].

batten
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: A dropper, orig. and usu. of wood, but also more recently steel, wire, chains or plastic strip, used to keep the wires of a fence at equal distances apart.

Notes:

batten
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: In general sense of a lathe-like piece of timber, not necessarily used for fencing (for board and batten vertically timbered construction, for example); a light strip of wood for fastening or joining items such as fence wires. 2. A thin strip of wood to separate stacked timber.

Quote:  The most important work in mining for precious metals is quartz-reefing; here the system differs little from underground mining in general. ... the ore ... when brought to the surface, is committed to `batteries' or crushing-mills, where the stone is stamped or ground into powder.

battle
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: make pregnant
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1989
Source:  Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  12
Edition:
Quote:  <i>battle</i> make pregnant, merely make love. Vince Boyle of Winton was researching a history of Mossburn when he came across a fellow recalling his wagoning days in 1914 in Northern Southland, and spoke of how he `battled a woman'. He was going to marry her, but a few days before the wedding she had a dentist remove her teeth and sent him the bill. They did not get married. Farmer and Henley describe a battler as one given up to debauchery, which leaves an outside chance that the wagoner merely seduced and failed to fertilise.
Notes:

Author:
Vol / Page:  C6
Edition:
Quote:  In a battle of a different kind - in Wellington on April 3, 1943 - the "Battle of Manners St" erupted when US servicemen refused to let Maori servicemen into the Wellington Allied Services Club. In New Zealand's worst riot, 1000 American and Kiwi troops and several hundred civilians fought for four hours. At least two Americans were killed.

batwing
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1896
Source:  Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ
Author:  HARPER
Vol / Page:  50
Edition:
Quote:   Our camp has not yet been described, and ... it is the simplest and best form of shelter for a party of two, ... It is an invention of Douglas's, and we call it a `batwing'. In the ordinary course of camp life, survey parties can have their loads packed on horseback, and carry tent and fly, with a second smaller fly to pitch at the end of the tent to shelter the fire. We ... [51] could not afford to take such a weighty camp. We therefore pitch an ordinary 6 ft. by 8 ft. canvas tent, on a ridge pole, with an 8 ft. by 10 ft. fly six inches above it; and cut the tent in half along the ridge, and taking away one half, leave the other half standing. This is just large enough to allow two men to lie `heads and tails'. [The side left open, and one side of fly raised 4 ft. in middle, and under this the fire burns so have shelter in wet weather.]


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1957
Source:  Mr Explorer Douglas
Author:  PASCOE
Vol / Page:  39

Quote:
Notes:  >18??Douglas in 1957 pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas 39

bay villa
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: see cit. 1983
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1983
Source:  Personal Communication
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  It refers specifically to the villa type with a bay window on the front facade (and, in larger versions, on a side facade too). It is a term one hears often (in fact I devoted a section to the `bay villa' in an architectural thesis I recently completed). The `bay' refers to the bay window (naturally enough); and also, some say, to San Francisco Bay. It was (and is) a house form common in that city; and it may well have spread to New Zealand from there.
Notes:  C.B.Orsman M.Arch

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Looking Back
Author:  SINCLAIR & HARREX
Vol / Page:  118
Edition:
Quote:  By the later decades of the [19th] century the most popular house was the villa or 'bay villa' - a house of simple design usually with one or more gables thrown [check] out, one or more bay windows, and a veranda.

Author:  STRAUBEL
Vol / Page:  xvi
Edition:
Quote:  The pursuit in coastal waters of black whales was known as `bay whaling',and the procedure followed was for the ships to lie at anchor in a convenient harbour or bay, sending out their boats to cruise in nearby waters for `fish'. <i>Ibid.</i> xviii [dating on NZ coast from about 1829 at Cloudy Bay, and 1835 in Banks Peninsula]
Notes:

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1905
Source:  Where the White Man Treads
Author:  BAUCKE
Vol / Page:  75
Edition:
Quote:  An old-time bay whaling station consisted ... of at least two boats, with their crew of six men each. The headsman, or mate, four ordinary oarsmen, and the harpooner, or `boat-steerer,' who pulled the bow-oar, and drove in the harpoon, and who, when the whale had been struck and `fastened on,' went aft and steered the boat, while the mate took his place, and by repeated lance-thrusts killed it.
Notes:

bayonet grass
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:  Aciphylla spp., an old name for  speargrass or taramea,  contrast <i>A. squarrosa</i> a little later `soft leaved Spear grass',  =spear-grass cf bayonet-plant.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/5/1860
Source:  First Year in Canterbury Settlement
Author:  BUTLER
Vol / Page:  5/72
Edition:
Quote:   The Spaniard (spear-grass or bayonet-grass) `piked us intil the bane' ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1862
Source:  Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland
Author:  VON HAAST
Vol / Page:  25
Edition:
Quote:   ... the giant Aciphylla Colensoi, the Spaniard or Bayonet-grass.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1868
Source:  Contributions to NZ Botany
Author:  LINDSAY
Vol / Page:  49
Edition:
Quote:   The larger species [of <i>Aciphylla</i> ] are familiar to the settlers as `Spear-grass', or `Bayonette-grass', `Wild' or `Bloody-Spaniard', [<i>bloody </i>=?] in allusion to their very rigid, strong, poniard-like, sharp-pointed leaves ... Hence a `Spear-grass Scrub' on the hill ranges is frequently most formidable ... to men and horses, though it forms one of the favourite hunting grounds of the Wild Pig. In the Matukituki Valley, `Bayonette-grass' forms an undergrowth in a dense scrub of prickly thorn ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1869
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/iii/5
Edition:
Quote:  The plains are covered with grasses, the roots of which are gathered into tufts or tussocks, intermixed with the Bayonet grass or `Wild Spaniard'
Notes:  (Hector)

Date:  0/0/1871
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  4/255
Edition:
Quote:  The remarkable genus <i>Aciphylla</i>  comprises the `spear-grass' and `bayonet-grass' of the colonists, so called from their rigid pungent leaves, which occasionally inflict uncomfortable wounds on incautious travellers.
Notes:  (Kirk)

Date:  0/0/1879
Source:  Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland
Author:  HAAST
Vol / Page:  25
Edition:
Quote:  They formed with the gigantic <i>Aciphylla Colensoi</i>, the Spaniard or Bayonet grass, ... which ... most severely punished man and horse.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1899
Source:  Students' Flora
Author:  KIRK
Vol / Page:  207
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Danthonia pungens</I> Bayonet-grass.
Notes:  [check this]

Date:  0/0/1909
Source:  AJHR
Author:
Vol / Page:  C-12
Edition:
Quote:
Notes:  (And) Botanical Survey Stewart Island

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/158
Edition:
Quote:  <i>taramea</i>, a plant (Aciphylla squarrosa and other sp.), spear-grass, bayonet-grass, spaniard: a hill and mountain plant from whose spiny blades the Maori by heat and torsion extracted a valued scent.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

be in
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: to join in; to get started; to be active in; take part in, or one's fair share of, whatever is going on; get stuck in.  (Often an exclam. be in! as an invitation, or in expressions `You gotta be in (to win); you gotta be quick', that is, take your share or somebody else will get it.)

beach
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: The seashore as a place for an outing.. -->1. [W3] In NZ not only the word for `the shore of the sea' (OED2 sb 3 citations connote a littoral and a literal meaning), but also the usual word for British seaside, the beach as a place of enjoyment  or recreation (seaside has an unidiomatic, British association even in children's stories),  cf beach cottage: in early days beach had commercial  connotations: cf The Beach, beach trader.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

Quote:  Note, In speaking of Mercury Bay I had forgot to mention that the Mangrove trees found there produce a resinous substance very much like rosin, something of this kind I am told is found in both the East and West Indias. We found it first in small lumps upon the Sea beach, but afterwards found it sticking to the Mangrove trees and by that means found out from whence it had come.

beach
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: as The Beach. An obs. name for what became Lambton Quay, Wellington,  cf the early 1840 Wellington use of beachcomber @n.

Cheerful, has beguiled and smuggled from the [Wellington] beach, four to five young females to carry with him to the Chatham Islands, to locate them ... amongst the reckless set who form the members of a whaling gang ...

Origin: [none]

Register 2:
Domain: [none]

See: contrast bank claim
Pronunciation:

Citations
Date:  18/7/1863
Source:  Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page:  7
Edition:
Quote:  Arrow Township, 10th July. - ... Huts, tents, wheels, sluice-boxes - everything on the beach and river claims have been swept off by the torrent, ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1873
Source:  Wild Will Enderby
Author:  PYKE
Vol / Page:  Bk I iv 17
Edition:
Quote:  The Dunstan gold workings were of two kinds - technically known as `beach claims' and `bank claims'. The latter were on the gravelly river banks which the miners sluiced away bodily for the golden grains ... The former were on the sandy margins of the river, and were often extended by means of `wing-dams' and other ingenious devices far into the rushing waters. In these claims the gold was found lodged in `pockets' or fissures formed by the slate bars ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  West Coast Gold Rushes
Author:  MAY
Vol / Page:  170
Edition:  1962
Quote:   Collet's quicksilver plates rapidly became common on the beach-claims although they did not completely supplant the simpler cradle and sluice-box. <I>Ibid.</I> 244 It was a matter of nice judgement. The digger recognized four classes of payable ground: `tucker ground' kept him in food with nothing to spare; a `wages claim' gave him a pound or two above living expenses; a `riser' was a rich claim; and a `piler' or `homeward bounder' the richest of all. Probably most of the `pilers' were beach-claims, where the leads were shallow and rich, the outlay small and provisions cheap because of easy access.
Notes:

These men are called `Beach Rangers;' most of whom have deserted from, or have been turned out of whalers for crimes, for which, had they been taken home and tried, they would have been hanged; some few among them ... had deserted from their ships, and were then leading a mean and miserable life amongst the natives.

beachcomber
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: A prospector or miner who works black-sand beaches for gold, a new goldfields formation from beach n.  (cf beach claim), and comb @v and comber @n,  (cf beacher); and perhaps associated with the  older beachcomber 1. above.

Notes:  Jim Cameron writes : <i>Beachcomber</i> may have a wider meaning than is given in DNZE sense 2 (a person who searches beaches for interesting or valuable objects) and be applied to a person who simply frequents or lives at the beach.

beachcombing
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: used to connote the irresponsibility associated with beach-combers n1..


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/5/1840
Source:  Letter
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  While putting up a printing office [in Port Nicholson] I picked up two wanderers, who I engaged to saw ... I adopted them because they were shaved and clean. ... They appeared to me to contrast to great advantage [?with] the regular `beach comber'. I write the phrase large because I think it is [???new] to you. It is appropriate to the class. Its meaning I assume is evident. The `beach combing' class is large. The fellows are daring, dirty, requiring much excitement, accustomed to work on shore and on board, generally about the beach, and take what they find without any very strong sense of doing that which is improper.
Notes:  1840 May 15 S. Revans to H. Chapman [TS] Letters 42



Date:  0/0/1853
Source:  New Zealand and Its Six Colonies

Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Except among the old whalers and the `beachcombing population' marriages with native women seldom take place.

Date:  0/0/1961
Source:  Hang on a Minute, Mate
Author:  CRUMP
Vol / Page:  61
Edition:
Quote:  I remember when I was beachcombing up in the Bay of Islands ... What, just living off the beach, Son? ... Yeah. Bit of fishing and mussel-picking, sheep-stealing and garden-raiding when a man felt energetic or hungry.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1948
Source:  Julius Von Haast
Author:  VON HAAST
Vol / Page:  528
Edition:
Quote:  Generally the greater portion of the sand is removed, but in favourable spots, sheltered either by a

slight indentation in the coast-line, or by some large pieces of drifted timber, its heavier particles remain; these consist [529] of black iron-sand (both magnetic and titaniferous oxide of iron) associated with small garnets and with gold. These black layers are often one or two inches thick, and repose upon coarse quartzose sands. As soon as a storm has subsided, the `beachers' or `surfers' as they are called, examine the coastline near their houses. When they come upon one of the rich spots, the fine particles of gold being often visible to the naked eye, they at once remove the black layer of sand out of the reach of the tide, and wash it when convenient.


Notes:  Quote from 1868

Date:  15/5/1840
Source:  Letters
Author:
Vol / Page:  42
Edition:
Quote:  While putting up a printing office [in Port Nicholson] I picked up two wanderers, who I engaged to saw ... I adopted them because they were shaved and clean. ... They appeared to me to contrast to great advantage [?with] the regular `beach comber'. I write the phrase large because I think it is [???new] to you. It is appropriate to the class. Its meaning I assume is evident. The `beach combing' class is large. The fellows are daring, dirty, requiring much excitement, accustomed to

work on shore and on board, generally about the beach, and take what they find without any very strong sense of doing that which is improper.


Notes:  1840 May 15 S. Revans to H. Chapman [TS] Letters 42

Date:  21/12/1912
Source:  Hutt Valley Independent
Author:
Vol / Page:  3

Date:  22/5/1844
Source:  Diary
Author:  TUCKETT
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  At each place which I have visited, I have been assured that the Maories are dying rapidly - `perishing like rotten sheep,' these people often say; thus at Kurreroo or Molineux, where there are now half-a-dozen natives, they say that formerly, and at no remote period, about two generations previous to the present, there were above a thousand; and in many other places within the last sixteen years, which is about the extent of the experience of the older beachers, there has been, in many places, a corresponding diminution of numbers. If this is an unexaggerated statement, it is a very distressing one to reflect on. Since Dr. -- visited this settlement, one of the residents, Mr. --, an educated man, has opened a school for half-bred or any other children, and the progress which the children have already made is very encouraging.
Notes:  1844 May 22 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 223

Author:
Vol / Page:  29/4, 5
Edition:

[5]  This highlights the necessity for workers in areas other than the Trans-Antarctic Mountains to endeavour to see the type Beacon, and conversely those workers familiar with the type Beacon should try to see what is regarded as the Beacon in other areas, particularly the Antarctic Peninsula.

beamer
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: [Cf OED2 beaming 2. (Tanning) 1885 `"Beaming", or unhairing, derives its name from an inclined convex wooden form called a "beam", on which the hide is spread during the operation.': also beam v. 4.; cf EDD beam sb1 5. a fleshing-beam.]


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1940
Source:  Rakiura
Author:  HOWARD
Vol / Page:  40
Edition:
Quote:  Incoming skins are sorted to arbitrary standards - wigs (old males), clap-matches (females), bulls, yearlings, grey or silver pups (under one year), black pups. If the cargo is intended for the European or American market, the skins are removed from the animal with an inch of blubber adhering, and in the final simple treatment are washed, heavily slated, and then folded or `booked' into rectangular shape for packing. Skins destined for China, however, are treated with more preliminary care. They are taken as cleanly as possible, and after careful washing are sent to the `beamer' to be thoroughly scraped free of the last remaining particles of flesh and blubber.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Loughnan Glossary
Author:
Vol / Page:  6
Edition:
Quote:  beat: (i) that area which a musterer is detailed off to clear. An easy beat is one of the easy walking, usually the bottom or top beat, though the latter may entail a long initial climb. A hard beat is usually one of the middle beats and very often includes bluffs and also much need to run dogs on the blind.
Notes:

Quote:  Boy was certainly the fastest sheep dog I have ever seen. He put in a splendid hunt, which would have been a bad head if the sheep had not been so fast, and hunted them all on to the next man's beat. <i>Ibid.</i> 18 I was two beats from the top, and there was shingle all the way. It slid continuously, and all the time I had to bear up hill, to keep a level track. However, we got off `the hill' quite early, put the sheep across Cat Creek at Tarndale, and raced for the homestead.

beaut
Homonym Number:
Word Class: adjective
Sense Number:
Definition: superior, excellent or admirable; corker, grouse, neat (in predicative use difficult to distinguish from the noun).

Vol / Page:  12

Quote:  <i>beaut</i>:; BEAUTIFUL in the sense of `that was a beautiful dive into the swimming bath ', or she's a beaut horse or sheila, etc. ... Note that unfamiliar words in New Zealand are likely to be contractions offamiliar ones, as beaut for beautiful, or speedo for speedometer, or park for parking place (see: park).
