beaut
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: (?SI); often, esp. in Otago-Southland, the  collocation wee beaut is used idiomatically as a familiar term of admiration, encouragement, etc. where gen. NZ usage might prefer little beaut, see wee aj.

Notes:

beaut
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Something or someone of superior, excellent or admirable quality (often used with wee or little to express endearment; equivalent to, and to some extent replacing,  earlier bottler, corker, or bonzer, bosker; whopper etc.), and often passing into an adjectival use.

beautiful white devil
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: greater bindweed.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1926
Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
Author:  HILGENDORF
Vol / Page:  137
Edition:  1967
Quote:  GREATER CONVOLVULUS [BINDWEED] (<i>Calystegia sepium</i>) has the same popular names as the last species, [i.e. convolvulus] and in addition, beautiful white devil, and its native name of pohue. It is much like convolvulus [bindweed], but is larger in all its parts. The leaves are 3 to 5 inches in length and the flower 2 inches across, more usually white than pink.

The call probably originated in the fact that a bearded man was often a target in the game.

Date:  0/0/1917
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  49/4
Edition:
Quote:  Strictly speaking, the term `bed' is applicable only to that part of the valley actually covered by the flowing water. But the cass, like most New Zealand rivers, is continually liable to flood ... In this paper the term `river-bed', following the colloquial usage, is used to include that part of the valley liable to be covered with water in times of severe floods. This `river-bed' is bounded on either side by a broad expanse of flat land, chiefly tussock-covered, termed colloquially `river-flat', but in this paper `terrace'.

beech
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an important group of Southern Hemisphere timber trees forming extensive forests especially in southern and mountainous regions of New Zealand. Also called nothofagus and popularly but incorrectly, birch; often found with prefixed epithets denoting appearance of tree (black, silver), quality of timber (hard, red), habitat (mountain); the preferred name for spp. of Nothofagus (to 187?, <i>Fagus</i>), the southern beech, and for spp. of other genera resembling the southern beech (see false beech 2 below); contrast the popular name birch q.v. now obs., and for the NI esp., the Maori generic taw(h)ai; and (erroneously) kamahi in the SI.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1875
Source:  Durability NZ Timbers
Author:  KIRK
Vol / Page:  17
Edition:
Quote:  With the view of obviating the confusion caused by the misuse of the common names hitherto applied to the New Zealand beeches, I would suggest the adoption of new names based on the obvious characteristics of their foliage:- For <i>Fagus fusca</i>, tooth-leaved beech; for <i>Fagus solandri,</i> entire-leaved beech; and for <i>Fagus menziesii,</i> round-leaved beech.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  2018
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Beech</i> (b&emacr.ch), <i>n. [Add.] ... The ordinary</i> native beech <i>of commerce in New South Wales is Gmelina Leichhardtii.</i> The New Zealand beeches are <i>Fagus Solandri, F. Blairii, F. Menziesii, F. fusca, F. Cliffortioides, </i>and <i>F. apiculata.</i> The word <i>beech</i>, however, is rarely used in New Zealand, the trees being called <i>birch</i> by settlers and bushmen, and <i>tawai</i> by the Maoris. See under BIRCH,<i>n</I>
Notes:

Date:  16/9/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Birch</i>. Various species of Nothofagus. There are various kinds (white, red, black etc.) of trees in New Zealand called birches. They are all really beeches and the newspapers and forestry people are trying to get them so called, but up country they are still always called birches. Birch (creeks, hill, etc.) is one of the commonest components of local names in the South Island. ([1898 Morris Austral-English], and an unpublished letter to Hunter Brown from Dr Hodkinson, August 9, 1854.)
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
Author:  McLINTOCK
Vol / Page:  2/680
Edition:
Quote:  English names of animals and plants are sometimes mistakenly applied. The native beech, <i>Nothofagus</i>, has been called <i>birch</i> since the early days and is still often so called by bushmen; ...
Notes:  Wall NZ Speech

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
Author:  McLINTOCK
Vol / Page:  3/705-712
Edition:
Quote:  Beech .. tawai, tawhai <i>Nothofagus </i>
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Forest Vines to Snow Tussocks
Author:  DAWSON
Vol / Page:  121
Edition:
Quote:  Five species of <i>Nothofagus</i> were formerly recognised in New Zealand, but more recently two of these have been combined as varieties of one species. <i>Nothofagus menziesii</i>: silver beech (the bark is white and silvery particularly in young trees). <i>Nothofagus fusca:</i> red beech (the timber is reddish in colour). <i>Nothofagus truncata:</i> hard beech (the wood has a high silica content making it hard). <i>Nothofagus solandri</i> var. <i>solandri</i>: black beech (the bark is very dark partly due to the growth of a sooty mould). <i>Nothofagus solandri </i>var. <i>cliffortioides</i>: mountain beech (grows mainly at higher altitudes than other beeches).
Notes:

Edition:
Quote:  <i>Beech fever</i>. An Otago term which refers to a sickness which affects some people in beech country. It may be the same as<i> birch itch</i>, suffered by people allergic to beech pollen
Notes:  Ruth Mason `Track and Trail'

Source:  History of Children's Play
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  128
Edition:
Quote:  A universal animal play in the North Island, but known also in the South Island, was a game variously termed Butcher Bats, Butcher Boys, or Penny Doctor Beetles. In this game, straws suitably moistened at the end with spittle were placed down insect holes and flicked out when the insect bit the end of the straw. The player won who could flick a beetle up first.

Belgian biscuit
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: white icing; Belgian biscuits =German biscuits
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: Jim writes : DNZE gives use as "during and after World War I", with no citation after 1926.It remains current <i>sub..nom. belgian cremes</i>, an everyday item on supermarket shelves, often (?usually) called Belgian biscuits. I also recall it as an alternative to <i>spice biscuits</i> in cakeshops.

bellahonie
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1972
Source:  Folkgames of Children
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  80
Edition:
Quote:  In a few tagging games the players joined hands with the He when they were caught and helped him catch the other players. These games were known as <i>The Bellahonie </i>(E-21) (Wellington, 1910), Kick Post One (Hampden, Otago, 1880), and Ballyhooley (Wellington, 1920). More popular were those games in which the players helped one another to fight the He, and of these the most widespread was the game known as <i>Kick the Tin</i> (e-3), Kick the Boot, Kick the Block, or Homiacky. In this game the He was put on guard of a jam tin placed inside a small circle marked on the ground. [Other players hid: those He could see he named and tapped the tin three times and `captured': other hiders waited till they had chance to kick tin out of circle: then all were free again.]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  History of Children's Play
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  231
Edition:
Quote:  There are games recorded in this period for which there is no record before 1900 though they may well have existed under other names. <i>West Coast</i>: Dunk and Davey, Spang Weazling; <i>Wellington</i>: Who Goes Round My Stone Wall, Beg o' My Neighbor, Bellahonie, Run a Mile, On and Off the Bridge, Here Come Two Nuns, Colours, Isaac and Rebecca. Scrag, Diabolo, Bumble Puppy, Homai, Fives;

Bellamy's
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the catering establishment within Parliament; the term, taken over from the British House of Commons, for the dining and drinking establishment of the NZ House of Representatives.

bellbird
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:

a bird commonly found in the New Zealand bush, noted for its beautiful song; various NZ birds from their bell-like notes, also called korimako, makomako.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
bellbird
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an indigenous honey-eating songbird,  Anthornis melanura , also known as korimako, mockymock and mockie.  The bellbird is not, however, a mockingbird like the tui.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]

<i>A. ruliceps.</i> PELZ.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1873
Source:  Birds of New Zealand
Author:  BULLER
Vol / Page:  91
Edition:  [1888 2nd edn I/85]
Quote:  ANTHORNIS MELANURA. (BELL-BIRD.) ... <i>Native names.</i> Mako, Makomako, Komako, Kokomako, Korimako, Kohimako, Kokorimako, Titimako, and Kopara. Of the above names, Korimako is most generally used by northern and Makomako by southern tribes. The Ngatiawas call this bird Rearea; and the natives of the Bay of Plenty distinguish the male and female as Kokorohimako and Titapu.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1879
Source:  Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland
Author:  HAAST
Vol / Page:  38
Edition:
Quote:  Every morning ... we were awakened by the songs of numerous birds ... amongst which the New Zealand Thrush (<i>Keropia crassirostris</i>), the Bell Bird (<i>Anthornis melanura</i>) ... could well be distinguished.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1883
Source:  Ranolf and Amohia
Author:  DOMETT
Vol / Page:  2/96
Edition:
Quote:  And <i>honey</i>-bird and <i>mocking</i>-bird/ And he of clearest melody,/ The blossom-loving <i>bell</i>-bird <I>Ibid.</I> 2/338 ... the Bell-bird or Korimako ..... Anthornis Melanura. This most interesting song-bird seems in danger of extinction, owing, according to Dr. Buller, to the ravages of the Norway rat.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  26
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Bell-bird </i>... name given to several birds, from their note, like the tinkling of a bell. In Australia, a Honey-eater, <i>Myzantha melanophrys</i>, Gould (`Birds of Australia,' vol. iv. pl. 80), the `Australian Bell-Bird' (the same bird as <i>Myszantha flavirostris,</i> V. and H.), chiefly found in New South Wales; also <i>Oreoica gutturalis</i>, Gould (Vol. ii. pl. 81), the `Bell-bird' of Western Australia; and <i>Oreoica cristata</i>, Lewin. In New Zealand, <i>Anthornis melanura,</i> Sparrm., chief Maori names, <i>Korimako</i> in North, and<i> Makomako</i> in South. Buller gives ten Maori names. The settlers call it <i>moko</i> (q.v.). There is also a Bell-Bird in Brazil.
Notes:

Date:  0/11/1884
Source:  NZ Journal of Science
Author:
Vol / Page:  277
Edition:
Quote:  12. <i>Anthornis melanura</i>, Sparrm. Bell bird, Korimako, Makomako, which last name settlers often render into mockymock.
Notes:  (T.H. Potts),

Date:  0/0/1961

Author:
Vol / Page:  200
Edition:
Quote:  <i>bellbird n</i> [so called fr. its bell-like note] : any of several birds whose notes are likened to the sound of a bell: as <i>b</i> : a honey eater (<i>Manorina melanophrys</i>) of Australia or a honey eater (<i>Anthornis melanura</i>) of New Zealand

Date:  0/0/1835
Source:  Boultbee Journal
Author:
Vol / Page:  104
Edition:  1986
Quote:  The birds are not remarkably musical - the linnets are rather so; The Bell-Bird, is of a purple colour, with a white spot on the breast, shaped like a bell. The Saddle back, is a brown bird with a bright red spot on its back like a saddle, these two last species, are about the size of a thrush. There are green parroquets, large hawks, and several kinds of wild ducks, besides Emus, greenbirds and woodhens, which are birds of excellent flavour. [ed. fn: The linnet, brown creeper (Finschia novaeseelandiae>), was occasionally called brown linnet in the earlier days; ... `parroquets', probably the red-crowned parrakeet ...]




Notes:  also in 1828 Boultbee Journal in 1979 Begg 222

Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  Amongst its [a capsized ferry's] passengers was one of the bellmen who plied their trade, and often made a hideous noise in the city streets. This man had been engaged to announce the different events on the day's programme [at Vauxhall Gardens, Dunedin, c1860s], and as he landed dripping on the Vauxhall jetty he exclaimed: `Oh! What'll I do? I've lost my bell.' `Wring your clothes,' said a bystander.

Vol / Page:  25

Quote:  BELLOWFISH [chk spg] Deep-bodied fish of the family <i>Macrorhamphosidae</i> which resemble related pipefish and seahorses, with their mouths at the end of a tube-like snout. ... Whiteley suggests that they get their name from the closeness with which they resemble the old-fashioned bellows for blowing fires.

bells
Homonym Number:

Definition:

Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1972
Source:  Folkgames of Children
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  170
Edition:
Quote:  Next in order of importance [to Egg Cap] in the pitching games was <I>Bells </I>(K-23). This was based on the game of Pitch and Toss ..., but had a more innocuous character. The coins for this game, that is the `bells', were the round, flat tops of the cylindrical Bell [Company] Wax Vesta matchboxes. The head was the blue end with the red flowers in the middle. The `sugaries' at the other end of the box (the spot on which the match was struck) were not often used, although there is one report in which they were said to represent half the value of the bell. ...
Notes:

Quote:  When on his rounds he rode an old horse and always wore a bell-topper hat. It was not unusual to come onto the doctor's horse and bell-topper on the side of the road or track, and the doctor lying down a band or somewhere nearby fast asleep. [pre-1910]
Notes:

Quote:  No sooner had he left the store than the diggers caught sight of his bell-topper and began [31] greeting him with cries of `Joe, Joe.' The township was soon ringing with the cry. The minister was puzzled to understand why he was being barracked so freely and asked Thomas the reason.

Date:  0/0/1916
Source:  Aloe, The
Author:  MANSFIELD
Vol / Page:  71
Edition:   (1982 O'Sullivan)
Quote:  He had a good voice; he liked to sing in public, he liked to dance and attend pic-nics - to put on his `bell topper' and walk out of Church if he disapproved of anything said in the sermon - and he had a passion for inventing highly unpracticable things, like collapsible umbrellas or folding lamps. He had one saying with which he met all difficulties. `Depend upon it, it will all come right after the Maori war.'

bell-wether
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition:  a tame wether that leads others to their doom at freezing works or a leader of a mob of sheep, furnished with a collar and bell that sheep will follow.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See: Judas sheep
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1980
Source:  Dog's Life, A
Author:  MCGREGOR
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  Even in New Zealand's early farming days the flock followed the shepherd who led a bell-wether. This was usually a tame sheep wearing a collar with a bell .. In later years the bell-wether was the fore-runner of the Judas sheep in the freezing works.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Loughnan Glossary
Author:  LOUGHNAN
Vol / Page:  9
Edition:
Quote:  Bell-wether. To this day tame wethers are used to lead others to their doom in the freezing works. They carry no bell but still retain a broad leather collar. This will protect them, and would effectively blunt the knife of a sticker who might absent mindedly seek to slit the wrong throat.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Farming of NZ
Author:  MCLAUCHLAN
Vol / Page:  155
Edition:
Quote:  In pioneering days, dogs were used more to contain sheep in the absence of fences than to drove them. The shepherd often led his flock with a bell-wether.

belly-flop(per)
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an awkward dive in which one lands on one's stomach on the water; in NZ as elsewhere mainly children's for (a) dive into water landing flat on the stomach.

She, on the other hand, knew of no other name for the kind of farm track that at one time was dug and is now more commonly bulldozed along and up a hillside. `Benched-out' roads, she assures me, climbed all over Banks Peninsula where she was brought up and it had not occurred to her that the phrase was in any way unusual.

Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1913
Source:  Country Work
Author:  CARR
Vol / Page:  43
Edition:
Quote:  When the flax arrives at the mill it is weighed and credited to the cutter. The `bench loader' then takes two or three bundles and puts them in a barrel (heavy end down). He then takes the longest leaves and places them on a bench convenient to the `feeder'. ...[44] The `feeder' takes each blade separately and places the butt end into the `stripper' which takes the green outer covering off. ... The fibre as it leaves the stripper is caught by the `fly boy', who collects enough to make into a hank, which he places convenient for the `shaker'. The latter, with a motion like cracking a whip, gets rid of as much rubbish as possible, after which he places the hank handy for the `washer'. This man places the fibre in a vat, through which ... clean water is running.
Notes:

Date:  0/10/1977
Source:  NZ Numismatic Journal
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  For the shilling <i>bob</i> was the most common nickname in use, but also recorded is

<i>deener</i>. This latter name was used more widely in New Zealand and Australia than in Britain. The sixpence attracted many slang terms -<i> tizzy, tanner, sprat, bender</i>, and a<i> kick. </i>

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author:  BURTON
Vol / Page:  32
Edition:
Quote:  An ingenious contraption was developed for brewing water for tea. Known as the Benghazi burner, it consisted of an upright cylindrical sleeve inside which a diesel or petrol fire was made. The jacket was filled with water which boiled with the rising heat. ... An adapted version of these burners is still popular on camping trips and picnics in New Zealand.

berdan
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a device for separating gold dust from crushed rock
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1876
Source:  TrNZI
Author:



Vol / Page:  8/179
Edition:
Quote:  The blanket tailings or blanketings, as they are otherwise called, consist mostly of iron pyrites and other sulphides, cobines with quartz, and contain a fair proportion of gold ...that had escaped over the silver tables. These tailings are treated in berdans with extra quicksilver and ground up. The berdans now in use at the Thames ... are generally five feet in diameter ... At one time a couple of rotating balls were considered sufficient for the amount of crushing required; now, the general practice is to have a loose ball as well as a stationary one attached to a chain, and it is called a drag ball; this drag does more work than a loose ball ... for the drag grinds the bowl as much as the tailings.
Notes:   (Goodall Thames Gold-fields)

Date:  0/0/1878
Source:  Forty Years in NZ
Author:  BULLER
Vol / Page:  152
Edition:
Quote:  Gold was crushed at first in a `berdan', until they were able to provide [153] an engine of many horse-power.
Notes:

Date:  27/10/1867
Source:  Trip to the Thames Gold-fields
Author:
Vol / Page:  28
Edition:  1978
Quote:  There are but two or three small Berdan machines on the spot [for crushing stone].

Vol / Page:  93

Quote:  Kurunui Battery ... of six stampers, and one stamper specimen battery with Berdans at the end of tables to grind the tailings.

Author:  No.4 (NS) 112
Vol / Page:

Quote:  The mill on the Hauraki claim consists of a fifteen-stamper battery, Wilfley, vanner, berdans, and accessories.

Vol / Page:  No.6 (NS) 26

Quote:  The crushing machinery in all these batteries consisted of four to ten heads of light stamps, and the gold-saving plant of amalgamated copper plates, with or without the addition of a small berdan.

Date:  0/0/1948
Source:  NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin
Author:  No.42 (NS) 39
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  In 1880 the Welcome built a 10-head mill with berdans ...




Notes:  [Reefton] [1880] 1948 NZ Geol SB

Date:  0/0/1971
Source:  Maratoto Gold
Author:  BALE
Vol / Page:  54
Edition:
Quote:  In front of him was a massive, rust-covered iron dish, with a big iron block inside it. ... `That's a berdan,' replied Mr Alexander. ... `You place crushed ore inside the revolving bowl. ... The iron block stays still, grinding the ore into a slime. Water flows into the dish and spills over the edge carrying the lighter gold-free particles and slurry with it. Then mercury is added to absorb or amalgamate the gold and silver. It's usually used for testing the ore.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
Author:  McARA
Vol / Page:  312
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Berdan pan</i>: An annular-shaped cast-iron bowl or basin about four feet in diameter containing heavy weights which were revolved slowly to grind the ore, particularly concentrates, finely. Sometimes mercury was added to the berdans to form an amalgam with the finely-ground gold.
Notes:

Date:  20/11/1890
Source:  Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  If all that is claimed for this invention is borne out by actual working, the old berdan will at length have more than a rival.

Date:  18/6/1963

Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:   Sales affect me in an odd way. I seem to go a trifle berko and rush round buying tomes on pot plants.
Notes:  [El Crud, student commentator, writes]

Date:  4/4/1972
Source:  Otago Daily Times
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  A 23-year-old housewife, ... who said she was under emotional strain because of family problems, was convicted of breaking property valued at [dollars]120, assaulting a police constable and using obscene language. ... The cause of her behaviour was probably a combination of the alcohol and the drugs, she said. `You went what is commonly called berko,' Mr Ross said when remanding the defendant for sentence ...
Notes:  (Griffiths Collection)

Date:  0/0/1980
Source:  Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A
Author:  LELAND
Vol / Page:  14
Edition:
Quote:  <i>berko</i>, or <i>to go berko:</i> GO BERSERK, committing violence upon persons and/or property.
Notes:

Date:  29/11/1986
Source:  Personal Communication
Author:  KATH COLERIDGE
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Used by a washing machine serviceman about machines going berko (wrong or out of control)

Edition:
Quote:  <i>berko</i> berserk, though not really; to <i>go berko</i> is to be temporarily angry and out of control. NZA.

Sense Number:

Bertie Germ
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: anthropomorphic name for bacteria which causes dental decay.  Used in schools, posters, and by dental nurses - largely in nineteen fifties.

See:

Notes:
Citations
Date:  12/1/2002
Source:  Dominion
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Given to me by erudite colleague Ian Harris, bespredel is a Russian word for a situation we recognise but have no single label for. In growing use by Russian commentators despairing of the situation in their country, it simultaneously denotes hopelessness, deep distress, rampant cynicism and antisocial behavioiur. It implies no limits, anything goes and a universal "I'm all right, Jack" attitude.

best cow
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a tap outside the cowshed used by unscrupulous dairy farmers to ''water down'' the milk.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  11/2/1977
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  19
Edition:
Quote:  He knew what the 'best cow' was. It was the tap outside the milking shed which the unscrupulous dairyman looked on as the cheapest milk. He has the story of a dairy farmer's wife, who during the visit of an inspector to the farm, in some distress advised her husband that the 'best cow' was choking. The farmer rushed outside to remove a potato which the children had stuffed up the tap outside the back door.

Notes:

biddy-bid
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Acaena spp. esp. <I>Acaena anserinifolia, </i>(often formerly <I>A. sanguisorbae </i>

occas. <I>A</i>. novae-zelandiae), <I>and other spp., </i> a (mainly) creeping plant and its burr, a prostrate herb having a many-seeded fruit with hooked spines which catch in clothing, the wool of sheep, etc. [from Maori piripiri]; hutiwai, piripiri q.v. cf also related forms biddy-burr, bizzie, and the Aust. alteration<I> bidgee-widgee,</i> AND 1910.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  22/2/1905
Source:  Otago Witness
Author:
Vol / Page:  74
Edition:
Quote:  After tea we went further up the creek,

some of us gathering ferns and the rest

throwing bid-a-bids at each other. Those

throwing "biddies" must have been

enjoying themselves.

Author:  LINDSAY
Vol / Page:  59
Edition:
Quote:  Hence the plant [<i>Acaena sanguisorbae</i>] is only too familiar, as the `Native Burr' to the sheep farmers alike of New Zealand, Australia, and Tasmania. ... To the Otago settler the plant is also known as the `Bidi-bidi,' or `Beta-beta;' to the North Island Maori as `Hutiwai,' `Piri-piri,' (Colenso), or `Piri-kahu,' (Colenso).
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1926
Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
Author:  HILGENDORF
Vol / Page:  99
Edition:  1967
Quote:  PIRI PIRI (<I>Aceara ... sanguisorbae</I>). This name is commonly corrupted into [called] bidi bid. In the North Island the plant is called hutiwai or utiwai and by mistake poroporo. It is a native species well known to all New Zealanders, and is a weed chiefly on land in process of being brought into occupation.

Date:  0/0/1880
Source:  Out in the Open
Author:  POTTS
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Piri-piri (<i>Acaena sanguisorbae</i>) by the settlers has been converted or corrupted into biddy-biddy; a verb has been formed on it, which is in very constant use for a great part of the year at least. To biddy is to rid one of burrs, as `I'll just biddy my clothes before I come in'.
Notes:  1880 T.H. Potts `Out in the Open' NZ Country Journal 195 (Morris),

Quote:  Piri-piri (<i>acaena sanguisorbe</i>) [Morris, sanguisorbe sic] by the settlers has been converted or corrupted into <i>biddy-biddy</i>; a verb has been formed on it, which is in very constant use for a great [Morris, good: check] part of the year at least. To biddy is to rid one of burrs, as `I'll just biddy my clothes before I come in'.
Notes:  1880 T.H. Potts `Out in the Open' NZ Country Journal 12/195 (1898 Morris, 29),

bidi-bidi
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: [alteration of piripiri] a burred weed of the Acaena spp. that flaws fleecewool and that was used by colonists to augment tea leaves.

Big Bay skink
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: A dark brown skink resident in North Fiordland and South Westland.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: <i>Oligosoma "Big Bay"</i>
Citations
Date:  0/0/1999
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Results from genetic work show all Big Bay skinks collected belong to a new species within the

<i>Oligosoma nigriplantare polychroma</i> complex . . . The exotic weed <i>Ulex europaeus</i> (gorse) encroaching on to stable cobble fields is likely to be the most immediate threat to Big Bay skinks, and gorse control should continue in order to keep cobble habitat clear.


Notes:  http://www.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/casn228.pdf

Date:  0/11/2002
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The two skinks known from the Area [sic] are the Open Bay Island skink and the 'Big Bay Skink', the latter being locally common in cobble strands in northern Fiordland and at Barn Bay, and possibly the skin[k] species that is relatively abundant in the rocky areas on the Cascade Plateau ... A brown striped skink of unknown affinity has been found in sphagnum swamp at Okuru.
Notes:  http://www.linz.govt.nz/docs/crownproperty/high-country-leases/leaselist/cascade-con-res.pdf The material in this survey was copied in 2002; exact date of writing is unclear.

Date:  0/3/2009
Source:  Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution
Author:  Chapple, Ritchie, Daugherty
Vol / Page:  52/478
Edition:
Quote:  There was no support for

the Big Bay skink (BBS1, BBS2, BBS17) being genetically distinct

from O. inconspicuum (Fig. 3). The level of genetic divergence between

the two subspecies of O. nigriplantare is 7.6%.

Quote:  <i>SHARK, SCHOOL</i> (a) Scientific name: <i>Galeorhinus australis</i> (principally). (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Flake Fillets. (c) Other common names: B.B., Big Boys; Soupfin; Grey Boys; Tope or Topi.
Notes:

Date:  23/7/1986
Source:  Codes for Species in NZ Waters
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  [species name] school shark .. [scientific name] <i>Galeorhinus australis</i> .. [other name(s)] tope, big boys, greyboys, flake, grey shark, soupfin, sandshark

big lag
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a life sentence or PD
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/10/1999
Source:  NZWords
Author:
Vol / Page:  2(2) : 1
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Lag</I> is a general term used to refer to a sentence or to an inmate. Examples are <i>big lag</i> (life sentence or preventive detention), a <i>wicked lag</i> (any sentence over seven years, life or preventive detention), and a <i>bed-and-breakfast lag</i> (a very short sentence). To <i>knock your lag out</I> is to serve your time in prison.
Notes:

Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  31/5/2003
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  F6
Edition:
Quote:  [I] concluded that what I'd found was the species <i>Gymnopilus spectabilis</i>, commonly known as big laughing gym. Eating this mushroom gives whole new meaning to the expression, " I nearly died laughing". That is literally what can happen. The victim goes into fits of uncontrollable laughter (perhaps because of the mushroom's psilocybin content), but also experiences nausea, abdominal pain, convulsions or death.

Until the mid-1950s they were painted silver and called "silver ghosts" because they were so quiet. Then they were painted red like the trams they replaced and became fondly known as the Big Reds.

big ring
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a children's game
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1972
Source:  Folkgames of Children
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  174
Edition:
Quote:  In the nineteenth century the ring game seems to have been the most popular marble game. (In more recent years marble games with holes have had the greater role.) There was Big Ring, in which a circle a yard or more in diameter was drawn on the ground; there was the mullibar variation, in which an outsize taw was catapulted amongst the marbles in this circle. There were Little Ring, Liney, Follows, Follow the Taw, Holey, and then, on a less important scale, Butcher's Board, in which the marbles were bowled through the holes in a board, Eye-Drop, Knock-Backs, Leggings-Out (or Leggin's-Out), Span-'Em, and Backits. The last was more usually a girls' game.
Notes:

Big Smoke
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: (esp. from a rural perspective) any big town or city
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: perhaps introduced by soldiers of WW1, it was originally  attested only of Dunedin city, but apparently in Otago rural can mean the nearest town (1951 Ray Coombes); in Aust. (see Baker 1942), Sydney or Melbourne, and common in Aust. radio plays among (low or) outback characters

Big Smoke
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: orig. London, and used in England by NZEF soldiers of WWI, and in WW2 (and by Australians); now any large town or city

biggy-bung
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an early Ma.-Eng. (?pidgin) nickname for an artilleryman: a Moaricisation of big bang<i>, with an extra vocalic syllable added to<i> big and the E. [`ash'] approximated to Maori [a] appearing to English ears as [the sound of but].

Bill Massey's Cockits
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: spec. policemen or `specials', recruited mainly from farmers who `kept order' during the 1913 strike, (from cocky @n, if not a misprint).

billet
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: OED: verb is gen. Eng. (with preps at, in, on, upon, with: but not, <i>billet out</i>, which is a common NZ verbal usage in this sense; in gen. Eng. and NZ usage, esp. sports etc., tournaments etc, `temporary private lodgings for visitors'; or as a verb, to provide such lodgings.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations

bill-hook
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a long-handled tool with a hooked blade for trimming or pruning trees, seems to be the gen. Eng. term (OED 1611) for what in NZ would usu. be called a slasher, but freq. used in 19C. esp. for a sort of short-handled slasher with a hooked point and phs distinguished from the various long-handled slashers [check illustrations before defining].

Register 2:

Quote:  The fern is fired; if it burns well, all the thick and matted dead stuff at the bottom.. will be consumed, leaving only the shrivelled 'Tutu'; and the cane-like fern stalks.. should be cut at once with a strong hook, or better still, with a short

scythe, and the 'Tutu' slashed down with a bill-hook.

billy
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a vessel (orig. tin can) with a lid and a swinging wire handle used first for boiling water or food over open fires and later as a receptacle for milk and other liquids, billyful, noun; a tin can (or enamelled or, later, aluminium) vessel with a swinging wire handle, and often a lid, used orig. for boiling water or cooking in the open, and later for holding milk and other liquids; a billy can cf tin billy [AND TIN- from tinplate 1881] phs to tin-; cf billy-boiling, boil the billy, milk-billy see also swing the billy, swing 3.




Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Date:  0/0/1925
Source:  Random Recollections
Author:  BATHGATE
Vol / Page:  12
Edition:
Quote:  It is true that there were large tins of boeuf bouilli containing not very palatable boiled beef, with a good deal of liquid, which were obtainable and used for ships stores. The contents were commonly called soup and bully, and the cannisters bully cans, from which the popular name of `billy' for a tin pitcher is undoubtedly derived. [Bathgate is possibly following Morris's <i>Austral English</i> surmise.]
Notes:  (Griffiths Collection),

Date:  0/0/1945
Source:  If You'd Care to Know
Author:  SIMPSON
Vol / Page:  99
Edition:
Quote:  This billy is an article much like an outsize in preserved-peach cans; indeed its real name is billy-can. It has a wire handle on it as a bucket has, and a lid as a saucepan has. ... The billy is found in almost every home throughout Australia and New Zealand. Where milk is not delivered in bottles, the billy is `put out' at night to receive the morning supply.
Notes:

Date:  8/1/1863
Source:  Journal and Letters (Walker)
Author:  WALKER
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Monday, got in stores at the following rates and pitched tent. Flour 9d. tea 4/6 a good handful ... Pick 15/6 Shovel 10/- Tin dish 6/- Billy 3/6 small swing pot for boiling
Notes:  (Dunstan Diggings)

Date:  0/0/1901
Source:  Erewhon Revisited
Author:  BUTLER
Vol / Page:  ch ii [Everyman edn 1932
Edition:   (1960) 207],
Quote:  On to other D's, with which his saddle was amply provided, he strapped his Erewhonian boots, a tin pannikin, and a billy that would hold about a quart. I should, perhaps, explain to English readers that a billy is a tin can, the name for which (doubtless of French-Canadian

origin) is derived from the words `<i>faire bouillir</i>.' frying pan to cook his flapjacks.

billy boy
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a boy, or cadet, who carries, the billy, makes tea, and does the rouseabout work for field parties, shearing gangs, etc.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

Pronunciation:

Edition:
Quote:  Starting as a billy-boy, he worked at just about every job in the next 3 and a half years - on the skids, loading timber; breaking down logs in the sawmill; driving logging trucks, a TD18 dozer and chainsaw felling of native trees.

Author:
Vol / Page:  144
Edition:
Quote:  The only point I want to make is that my experience of mountains is lengthy although it may not be deep - billy boy to the botanists of the `twenties', mountaineering and field collecting for geologists in the `thirties'.
Notes:  1960 Report of Ninth Science Congress May 12-17: Proceedings of Royal Soc. of NZ 144

to camp before dark, light the fire and

start the dinner.


Notes:

billy boy
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: 1. a worker who mixes and distributes billies of burgoo or Ship's Lime to harvesting teams, working in hot, dry conditions [1850s to 1930s]. 2. a person who collects/delivers smoko materials or makes tea in shearing sheds.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See: billy time
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/5/1909
Source:  NZ Farmer
Author:
Vol / Page:  338
Edition:
Quote:  Here you find boys of scarce fourteen eager to take on a job as billy-boy, a by no means enviable task.
Notes:

Source:  Golden Harvest
Author:  COULSON
Vol / Page:  37
Edition:
Quote:  Cutting grass seed was dry work, and there was a regular break for a drink. It fell to the lot of the Billy Boy to provide this. 2.

billy bread
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: bread baked in a billy over a fire, bread baked orig. in a billy using it as a kind of camp oven
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: cf. billy loaf
Pronunciation:

Edition:

Author:
Vol / Page:  35
Edition:
Quote:  <i>BILLY BREAD</i> ... flour ... wheatmeal ... salt ... B.P. ... golden syrup ... milk. Mix ... into a wet dough, grease and flour the billy, bake for 2 hours with lid on.

Vol / Page:  44
Edition:
Quote:  Billy Sponge. 4 eggs, 8 oz. sugar, 4 oz. flour, pinch of salt. Whisk the eggs. Gradually beat in the sugar. Pour into a greased and floured billy or loaf tin. Sprinkle with castor sugar. Bake at 325[degree sign] for 3/4-1 hour.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Hills, The
Author:  PICKERING
Vol / Page:  8
Edition:
Quote:  Of billy tea. Waiting until the billy boils, throwing in half a handful of tea, trying to hook the billy off the fire before it boils over, and tapping the side with a spoon to settle the leaves. Then demonstrating a touch of skill by pouring the tea over the billy handle and into your chipped enamel cup and swallowing the brew in hot blowy gulps.
Notes:

Source:  Your Weekend
Author:
Vol / Page:  8
Edition:
Quote:  Nowadays, musters are completed in days using helicopters and 4WDs.   Hob-nailed boots, billy tea and camp ovens have been replaced by GPS locators, energy drinks and Vibram rubber soles.

Vol / Page:  462
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Tea ... Billy-tea</I>, or <I>Bush-tea.</I> Tea made in a <I>billy</I> (q.v.) There is a belief that in order to bring out the full flavour it should be stirred with a gum-stick.<I> New Zealand tea</I>. Tea made of the leaves of the <I>manuka </I>(q.v.). See <I>Tea-tree. </I>

bin
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: to class wool into its appropriate bin for eventual rebaling and sale ; spec. in woolstores, to class or sort small parcels of wool into bins
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1936
Source:  Agricultural Organization in NZ
Author:
Vol / Page:  710
Edition:
Quote:  With small slips they are either mixed with the pieces or sent to store to be binned. <i>Ibid.</I> 711-712 In `Binning,' the bales are broken up and classed into lines. This method of building up saleable lines is generally used in the case of small parcels of fleece wool and bales of oddments which cannot be included in the main lines without destroying their evenness. As each vendor's wool [712] is classed in the binning-room, the wool in each class is weighed and credited to the owner before being placed in its appropriate bin.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1974
Source:  NZ Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  66
Edition:
Quote:  Wool may be opened and reclassed in the broker's store, repacked [67] in the owner's bales, and sold under his `brand'; or it may be opened, classed, and then `binned'. Binning is a system of pooling similar wools from a number of properties, allowing the smaller quantities to be grouped for sale. The farmer is credited according to the weight of his wool that has been assigned to each bin. This wool is sold under the broker's brand.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  Collins Compact Dictionary
Author:
Vol / Page:  48
Edition:
Quote:  <i>bin ... v.t. 4</i> classify (wool) and put in bin.
Notes:  [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; nf. 1986 NZPOD]

Edition:
Quote:  At the main entrance of the shearing-shed, which is a long building with pens down the centre, and an outlet at each end, stands a wool-press, and behind this are the bins into which the fleeces, after having been classed, are placed preparatory to being pressed. <i>Ibid.</I>

244 Meanwhile the shorn fleeces are carried to a large table in the wool-shed by a man appropriately named `Fleecy', and are spread out by four wool-pickers, who tear away the bad parts and fold the fleeces square, passing them to the classer, who, in turn, after a rapid examination hands them on to his attendant, and he places them in their respective bins according to their quality.
Notes:

There are ... good and bad stookers after years of experience.

Notes:

bindweed
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: [OED2 1. The English name for the species of the N[atural] O[rder] Convolvulus; as Greater Bindweed (<i>C. sepium</i>), Lesser Bindweed (<i>C. arvensis</i>), Seaside Bindweed (<i>C. Soldanella</i>). 2. Applied dialectally or vaguely to various other climbing plants ... 3. <i>black, corn</i>, or<i> ivy bindweed</i> Polygonum Convolvulus; <i>Blue Bindweed </i>Bittersweet or Woody Nightshade. [17-18c.].] In NZ applied to various genera of climbing or .... plants, chiefly of the family Convolvulaceae, esp <i>Calystegia sepium </i> see also greater bindweed [check that this is still admitted]. [Note from ed. AND in response to query are there native bindweeds in Aust. 1986. Yes, three native (2 of which endemic) spp. of <I>Convolvulus</i>. However OED definition (`The English name for the species of the N[atural] O[rder] <i>Convolvulus'</i>) covers our use of the word, so we haven't needed to make an entry. (1 quot only Mitchell 1848; 1 fig 1965).]
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: convolvulus
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations

bindweed
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 3
Definition: Calystegia sepium beautiful white devil, pohue, greater convolvulus; (1926 headword convolvulus; 1967 headword bindweed)
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1926
Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
Author:  HILGENDORF
Vol / Page:  137
Edition:
Quote:  GREATER CONVOLVULUS [1967 BINDWEED] (<i>Calystegia sepium</i>) has the same popular names as the last species, [i.e. convolvulus] and in addition, beautiful white devil, and its native name of pohue. It is much like convolvulus [bindweed], but is larger in all its parts. The leaves are 3 to 5 inches in length and the flower 2 inches across, more usually white than pink.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1969

Date:  0/0/1982

Vol / Page:  42

Quote:  <i>Calystegia tuguriorum</i> NATIVE BINDWEED ... Convolvulus ... High climbing, twining stems with thin leaves. Flowers white, conspicuous. ... [Introduced] CONVOLVULUS or GREAT BINDWEED (*<i>Calystegia silvatica</i>) has much larger, longer leaves, and larger white flowers ...

binning
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: broker service for the disposal of small or mixed lots of wool in which each grower's wool is classed and weighed to bins with similar types from other growers, cf bin.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1936
Source:  Agricultural Organization in NZ
Author:
Vol / Page:  710
Edition:
Quote:  The wool removed by crutching is of low value and the amount per clip is usually small. For these reasons `crutchings' are seldom if ever classed except by the wool brokers when the wool is sent to them for binning. <i>Ibid.</I> 711 In `Binning,' the bales are broken up and classed into lines. This method of building up saleable lines is generally used in the case of small parcels of fleece wool and bales of oddments which cannot be included in the main lines without destroying their evenness. As each vendor's wool [712] is classed in the binning-room, the wool in each class is weighed and credited to the owner before being placed in its appropriate bin.
Notes:

birch
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: applied to other than Nothofagus genera (see esp. black birch below. Kirk 1875 (quoted by Anderson) states that birch is to be regarded as a generic name applied by bushmen to any small-leaved tree ... so the term black birch was in many districts

applied to <i>Pittosporum tenuifolium</i> (black) matipo and to <i>Weinmannia racemosa</i> in Otago. <i>Myrsine Urvillei</i> [ ] was known as `red birch', and <i>Carpodetus serratus</i> [ ] and <i>Quintinia serrata</i> [ ] as `white birch'.

Notes:

birch
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: (any of a group of deciduous, Northern Hemisphere trees with slender branches and smooth bark, used for timber.) In NZ commonly, but incorrectly, applied to the native beech spp.; a common popular name c1795-1970s for the trees and timber of Nothofagus spp., preferred common name beech q.v. Also occas. used for species of other general thought to resemble Nothofagus. occas. (usu. overseas usage) New Zealand birch.

As with beech, vernacular naming tries to distinguish var. and spp. by ref. to colour of bark, texture of wood or timber, appearance of leaf, etc., but with similar confusion and local variation.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1975
Source:  Men of the Milford Road
Author:  ANDERSON
Vol / Page:  93
Edition:
Quote:   On the Hollyford job the road went through beech-forest, but this was locally called birch. Woe betide us if we referred to birch trees in our correspondence with Head Office: we were reminded that it was <i>beech</i> and given all sorts of advice telling us that the botanical name was something like <i>Fagus fagusti</i>, and so on. Some people are allergic to beech trees and the local name for this allergic condition was birch itch. On one occasion a compensatory claim was sent to Wellington advising that the condition suffered was birch itch. Back came a reprimand about this use of the term birch - it should be <i>beech</i>, Head Office pointed out. Nothing was done about this until one day it came to the notice of our chief. He was quick to reply and acknowledge that the trees were beech, not birch, but the itch suffered by the men was birch itch not beech itch. It was locally named by them, and as far as his staff were concerned they used the term birch itch to describe the allergy caused
by beech trees. There was no further comment from the Moguls in Head Office.
Notes:   (Griffiths Collection)

Date:  0/0/1958

Date:  0/0/1796
Source:  Journal
Author:  MURRY
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Capt. Cook has given so good a description of the Spruce Fir, that it is impossible to mistake it. But he has not taken any notice of the Pitch Pine - Birch - And large Myrtle. ... The Birch is only fit for fuel - Its uncommon whiteness would cause it to be preferred for decks, &c. but it splits with the smallest blow, and, of all the woods at Duskey Bay it is the least durable - It grows from a large stump about 50-60 & even 70 feet with branches included. The boughs spread more than any other tree and the bark is generally white, somewhat resembling the hazel in England.
Notes:  1796 [chck ?1795]Jan Murry's Journal of the `Britannia' in 1908 McNab Hist. Records 2/534

Date:  16/9/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <I>Birch</I>. Various species of Nothofagus. There are various kinds (white, red, black etc.) of trees in New Zealand called birches. They are all really beeches and the newspapers and forestry people are trying to get them so called, but up country they are still always called birches. Birch (creeks, hill, etc.) is one of the commonest components of local names in the South Island. ([1898 Morris Austral-English], and an unpublished letter to Hunter Brown from Dr Hodgkinson, August 9, 1854.)
Notes:  Acland Glossary

birch
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1918
Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/307
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Fagus Solandri.</i> - The most common name of this tree is `black-birch,' but it has several other names. In the Wellington and Marlborough districts it is called `black-birch'; in Canterbury it is called `black-birch,' `white-birch,' `red-birch,' and `brown-birch'; in Otago it is known as `white-birch,' `black-birch,' or black-heart birch.' Young specimens of this tree that have no dark heart-wood are often called `white-birch.' This tree is a beech, and it would do away with confusion if it was called `black-beech'. <i>Fagus Menziesii. </i>- The commonest name of this tree is `silver-birch,' but it is often called `brown-birch,' `red-birch,' and `white-birch' [308] in different localities. It would be best to call it `silver-beech,'though it is gaining an Australasian reputation as `Southland beech.' <i>Fagus fusca. </i>- In Auckland this tree is called `black-birch'; in Wellington `red-birch'; in Nelson, Marlborough and Westland it is called `brown-birch'; and in Otago it is called both
`red-birch' and `bull-birch.' The most suitable name is `red-beech.'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1876
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  64
Edition:
Quote:  The utmost confusion prevails among the common names of the birches. There are scarcely two districts, a few miles apart, in which the same name is applied to the same tree, and a similar result may be obtained by consulting two bushmen in the same bush. With a view to obviating this difficulty Mr Kirk suggests `the adoption of new names based of the obvious characteristics of foliage [e.g.] for Fagus fusca `tooth-leaved beech' ...
Notes:  (Blair)

Date:  0/0/1885
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  17/300
Edition:
Quote:  [this cit. not spec. repeated in individual entries] [In Oxford Forest] I learned that the tree [F. solandri, entire-leaved beech ] was termed [red, brown, white, black, and yellow] birch at different stages of its growth, but the application of these terms differed greatly; perhaps Black Birch was most generally applied to the mature condition before decay commenced, and White birch to the young state; but there were too many exceptions to allow the names to be anything but misleading.
Notes:   (Kirk, NZ Beeches)

Date:  0/0/1891
Source:  NZ Journal of Science
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/50
Edition:
Quote:  The perversity with which the true `beeches' have become popularly known as `birches,' and different kinds of `mapau' as `maples - a popular name which includes small trees of widely distinct Natural Order, is enough to fill with despair any botanist who desires to foster a system of popular names that will be free from misleading and inaccurate suggestions.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1926
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  56-57/663
Edition:
Quote:   '... the term birch may be regarded as a generic name applied by bushmen to any small-leaved tree, and qualified by the prefixes `black', `white' or `red' at the caprice of the individual or as may be suggested by the colour of its foliage, bark or timber.' So the term `black birch' was in many districts applied to Pittosporum tenuifolium [ ] and to Weinmannia racemosa [Kamahi] in Otago - the latter tree being also known as `brown birch' or `red birch.' Myrsine Urvillei [ ] was known as `red birch', and Carpodetus serratus [ ] and Quintinia serrata [ ] as `white birch.' It was principally to the trees of the species Nothofagus (then known a Fagus), that the term `birch' was applied, and a distinguishing of the various kinds by the prefixing of a descriptive word was a step in the right direction; but in this instance the step was on a path that led to a quagmire. To take only the instance of N. Solandri (formerly Fagus Solandri). [v. 1885 Kirk] ... The confusion created has been endless ; it
has at times even resulted in commercial loss ; [v. (Morris) 1889 Kirk `Forest Flora of NZ p.91] yet so strong is habit that confusion was preferred before a change of name. And, indeed, the bushmen might well ask what name they should adopt ; for the scientists came and added to the confusion by pointing out that the trees usually called `birch' were not birch at all, but `beech' - when a fresh crop of names resulted.: `black beech', `red beech', `dusky beech', etc. The scientists themselves, however, in calling the species Nothofagus, `beech', took care - that is, usually took care - to make the distinguishing prefix one that would not lead to a repetition of the old confusion. N. Solanderi was accordingly called `entire-leaved beech' ; N. Cliffortioides, `mountain beech' ; N. Menziesii, `round-leaved beech' ; N. fusca `tooth-leaved beech'. It was some time before even these names were agreed upon ; and `silver beech' finally took the place of `round-leaved beech' for N. Menziesii. A note may here be made
of the fact that, whilst the entire-leaved beech was Fagus Solandri, on Fagus being changed to Nothofagus, Solandri was altered to Solanderi ; but this has been altered back again to Solandri ; for that was the original and not incorrect spelling of the word.
Notes:  Andersen Popular Names ff Kirk in 1875 [Reports on the Durability of N.Z. Timber 16]

Date:  0/0/1940
Source:  NZ Plants
Author:  LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page:  136
Edition:
Quote:   ... it is perhaps futile to hope that the more exact name [beech] will become popular ; but we might at least expect some consistent nomenclature to be adopted through the islands. At present the various species are designated almost indifferently, white, red, black, silver birch etc. What is white birch in one part of the country may be black in another ... The use of the name <i>birch</i> in place of <i>beech</i> is inexcusable, though ... N. Menziesii ... [shows] some external resemblance to the English birch.
Notes:

Date:  11/3/1972
Source:  Otago Daily Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  1
Edition:
Quote:  Colour Coding  [heading] ... St Patrick's Day sports organiser, Mr Lyn Thompson yesterday inquired about the difference between red, black and brown birch. It was `clearly' explained for him by a prominent axeman, Mr Bill Evans. The bark of the red birch is silver, but the timber is pink when it's green. Brown birch often has black bark, but the green timber is red. Sometimes the bark of the black birch is white, but the timber is yellow and sometimes it's brown when it's green.
Notes:  (Griffiths Collection)

birch itch
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an allergy affliction (see cit.): phs the same as birch fever, birch sickness,
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: cf. tauhinu rash
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1952
Source:  Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker
Author:  THOMSON
Vol / Page:  119
Edition:
Quote:  Cliff developed a kind of skin rash, sometimes called `birch itch'. This rash usually occurs with people who are allergic to bush localities, especially when the pollen is released from the trees in the spring.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1975
Source:  Men of the Milford Road
Author:  ANDERSON
Vol / Page:  93
Edition:
Quote:  On the Hollyford job the road went through beech-forest, but this was locally called birch. Woe betide us if we referred to birch trees in our correspondence with Head Office: we were reminded that it was <i>beech</i> and given all sorts of advice telling us that the botanical name was something like <i>Fagus fagusti,</i> and so on. Some people are allergic to beech trees and the local name for this allergic condition was birch itch. On one occasion a compensatory claim was sent to Wellington advising that the condition suffered was birch itch. Back came a reprimand about this use of the term birch - it should be <i>beech</i>, Head Office pointed out. Nothing was done about this until one day it came to the notice of our chief. He was quick to reply and acknowledge that the trees were beech, not birch, but the itch suffered by the men was birch itch not beech itch. It was locally named by them, and as far as his staff were concerned they used the term birch itch to describe the allergy caused
by beech trees.
Notes:   (Griffiths Collection)

biscuit
Homonym Number:  2

Definition: a railways tablet

Register 2:

Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Citations
Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  G'day Country
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  32
Edition:
Quote:   Inside the station they had the big red metal boxes that work the old-fashioned tablet signalling system. If you ever wonder what drivers are picking up or unloading on the end of a curved piece of wood, it is the tablet or biscuit. A train cannot get through a section of rail without the biscuit matching the one in the red metal box, which is connected to the manually operated signals. Automatic signals are phasing this system in to rural museums.

Quote:  He was a bit of a one for going on the booze.
Notes:  (`Pair of Socks')

Date:  0/0/1974
Source:  Australian & NZ English [TS]
Author:  SYDER & HODGETTS
Vol / Page:  60
Edition:
Quote:  as common in NZ in a variety of senses and uses as it is in gen. Eng. - esp. bit of a, pronounced [ ] and often spelt <I>bituva</I>, used adjectively for `small, little', and also ironically in understatement as `large' (e.g. 1944 `I must 'er made a bituva mistake, and opened up yer nose'): also used (esp. by children) adverbially as `rather': e.g. `It's bituva hot in here'. These and other uses are attested in OED(S) and EDD; cf hang of a; collocations (A) BIT OF (A) [to go to file 3BI5 BIT 1.]. The expression is in constant use. It has different meanings, but each is clear from the circumstances of the conversation. For example:

<I>A bit of luck, A bit of a break</I> The event is praised, its quality is genuine.

<I>A bit of a lark, A bit of fun</I>  There is no intense quality in the event.

<I>A bit of an ass, aren't you?</I>  The quality of the topic is weakened so that the remark will not sting as much.

<I>A bit of a hold-up (i.e. check to progress)</I>  The delay is brief.

<I>A bit of risk attached to it</I>  The proportion of risk is not great, possibly slight.

<I>A bit of a muddler, A bit of a no-hoper, A bit of a poor show </I> The quality referred to is present in full force.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author:  TURNER
Vol / Page:  48
Edition:
Quote:  Exaggeration is not an Australian characteristic and appears mainly in slang ...; understatement shows in style and unemphatic intonation rather than in vocabulary, except for the ubiquitous <I>a bit. </i> <I>Ibid.</i> 126 [qoting a Queensland survey] The word <i>bit</i> is common because it occurs in<i> a bit</i> (169) ...,<i> a bit of</i> (142) ... The word <i>bit</i> (1,241) is thus very frequent; compare <i>two (1,253).. </i>
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1867
Source:  Carmina Varia
Author:  STEWARD
Vol / Page:  9
Edition:
Quote:  Not wishing a time-honoured custom to efface,/ I prefix my book with `a bit of a Preface'.

bit on, a
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: (that's) a bit on, from the longer expressions on the cuff (q.v.) nose, the <i>snorer,</i> that's tough; that's a bit much; see also cuff.

Notes:
Citations
Date:  13/1/1934
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Bitch</i>.-(1) Spoil or botch; (2) pour out tea. I thought these were colonial expressions, if ever there were any; but an erudite friend points out that (1) is used by Surtees in chapter XLII of `Handley Cross,' perhaps the most English book ever written, and that (2) is an old Cambridge University expression quoted in Gradus ad Cantabrigiam - a dictionary of Cambridge expressions, published in 1824. Let us hope that Samuel Butler introduced it to Canterbury.
Notes:   Acland Gloss

Date:  16/9/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  ~ Slang. To spoil or make a mess of, e.g., `You've bitched the whole thing.' (C.)
Notes:  (ca1890-1910) 1933 Acland Glossary Press 16 Sept 15

bitch-house
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a secure kennel, usually built on stilts, where a female working dog in oestrus is separately housed.

bite
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: accost and beg successfully from: `the old man bit me for a dollar outside the town hall'; put the bite on, (informal) to ask a favour; to cadge, borrow; to accost and borrow (esp. money)

bitzer
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: shortened form of "bits of this and bits of that"; usu. any old and ramshackle mechanical thing or vehicle appearing to be made up of odd bits and pieces; used esp. of cars and (by schoolchildren) of bicycles, but in extended or transferred use, of the non-mechanical.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

More correctly it is an Antarctic "bitzer," for it has been made from items salvaged from an old Tucker snocat, a crashed helicopter, various foreign snow vehicles, and locally-manufactured parts... The "bitzer's" steering sysrtem is believed to be novel.

biv
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a hut, or tent etc. built or used as a temporary shelter; and esp. as bivvy (or biv) freq. among outdoors people for a purpose-built rough shelter or sheltered camping place.

Quote:  I remember shortly after arrival in New Zealand watching the well-known dealer, Andrew Grant, picking `fats.' When asked by me for his hesitancy and discrimination in regard to several apparently prime blacks, his answer was that they `killed' badly. So many statements, nevertheless, continue to be accepted because it is nobody's interest to disprove them, that this dealer's belief is given for what it was worth. On the other hand, what Sandy Grant did not know of sheep was not worth knowing

Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Black Birch of Otago, Beech, etc. (<i>Fagus fusca</i>), another valuable timber tree, attaining a great size; ... H.H. Allan <i>Flora</i> (1982) pp. 397ff, 1035 assigns the popular name black beech to <i>Nothofagus solandri</i>, and renames <i>N. Cliffortioides</i> as <i>N. solandri</i> var. <i>cliffortioides: N. fusca</i> is assigned red beech - these three have dark bark; the epithet <i>black</i> is taken from the bark or from a sooty fungus growing on the bark

Date:  0/0/1883
Source:  Handbook of New Zealand
Author:
Vol / Page:  125
Edition:  3rd
Quote:  <I>Nothofagus fusca,</I> Hook. Tawhai Tawhairaunui, Black-birch of Auckland and Otago (from colour of bark), Red-birch of Wellington and Nelson (from colour of timber). --This is a noble tree 60-90 feet high the trunk 5-8 feet in diameter. The timber is excessively tough and hard to cut. It is highly valued in Nelson and Wellington.

<I>Kawhaka</I> of the natives ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1885
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  17/300
Edition:
Quote:  [<I>Notho]fagus fusca</I>, Hook. f. ... Tooth-leaved Beech. Black Birch of Auckland and in part of Otago and Southland. Black or Bull Birch of Lake Wakatipu. Red Birch of Wellington, Nelson, and in part of Otago and Southland. It is not so easy to see why any difficulty should have occured in the identification of this fine timber-tree apart from the misleading tendency of the common names generally applied. The thin yet firm texture of the leaf, the prominent veins, the sharply-toothed margins, are characters that can only be confused with those afforded by a careless observer. Yet merely owing to the use of common names based upon colour, and applied or rather misapplied to the leaves, bark, or wood at the fancy of the bushman, no species has been more misunderstood.
Notes:   (Kirk, NZ Beeches)

Date:  0/0/1882

Quote:  <I>F. fusca, Hook.f.</I> ... A noble forest-tree 60-100 ft. high; ... bark dark-brown or black in old plants, deeply furrowed, smooth and greyish-white on young trees; ... rare in Canterbury and eastern Otago. ... <I>Tawhai; Tawhai-rau-nui; Black-birch; Red-birch. </I>... [642] Wood bark-red, ... more durable than that of other species, ...

Vol / Page:  4/57
Edition:
Quote:  [?Cby Alps and foothills] This bush, though very beautiful to look at, is composed of nothing but the poorest black birch. We had no difficulty getting through it, for it had no under-growth, as the bushes on the front ranges have.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1885
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  17/301
Edition:
Quote:  <i>[Notho]fagus solandri</i>, Hook. f. ... <i>Myrtilloides cinerascens</i>, Banks & Sol., MS. Cliffortiordes oblongata, Dryander. Entire-leaved Beech. Black Birch of Wellington, Canterbury, and in part of Otago and Southland. White Birch of Nelson, and in part Otago. Black-heart Birch of Otago. White, Black, Red, and Brown Birch of Oxford and Alford Forests. A fine tree, sometimes attaining the height of 100 feet, but usually 60-80 feet, with a trunk from 2 to 4 feet or more in diameter.
Notes:   (Kirk, NZ Beeches)

Date:  0/0/1885
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  17/304
Edition:
Quote:   <I>[Notho]fagus Cliffortioides,</I> Hook. f. ... Mountain beech. Black Birch of portions of Wellington, Canterbury, Otago and Southland. White Birch of Nelson, and in part of Otago and Southland. Barely distinguished by the woodman from Entire-leaved beech. The mountain beech bears a close resemblance to the entire-leaved beech in general appearance, although it never attains the extreme dimensions of that species.
Notes:  (Kirk, NZ Beeches)

black birch

Citations
Date:  0/0/1848
Source:  Handbook for New Zealand, The
Author:  WAKEFIELD
Vol / Page:  142
Edition:
Quote:  9. Tawai, (<i>Leiospermum racemosum.</i>) This tree has a rough, dark-brown bark, and a small round leaf, in shape like that of an elm. The wood is particularly well adapted for ship-building, and for the staves of barrels, and is commonly called `black birch' by the sailors and other Europeans acquainted with it.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1875
Source:  Durability NZ Timbers
Author:  KIRK
Vol / Page:  19
Edition:
Quote:  TAWHERO.- (<i>Weinmannia racemosa.</i>) ... Often called black birch, and substituted for that timber, to which it is greatly inferior in strength and durability.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1877
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  9/148
Edition:
Quote:  The kamai is called black birch in the Callin River District and Southland, which name is given on account of a supposed resemblance to the `birches', or more correctly, `beeches', a number of which occur in that locality ... Whatever the reason, the misapplication of names is complete, for the birches are still commonly called kamai in Southland. Kamai is little known on the East Coast north of the Clutha River.
Notes:  (Blair)

Date:  0/0/1889
Source:  Art Album NZ Flora
Author:  FEATON
Vol / Page:  136

Date:  0/0/1875
Source:  Durability NZ Timbers
Author:  KIRK
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  In many parts of the colony, the small-leaved tarata (<I>Pittosporum tenuifolium</I>) is called black birch; in others the name is applied to the tawhero (<I>Weinmannia racemosa</I>). ... The timber [of tawhero] greatly resembles that of the true black birch, but may be at once distinguished by its lighter specific gravity.

It is significant that in his 1848 Handbook of NZ 142, Wakefield replaces the 1845 <i>Towai</i> above with <i>Tawai</i>: thus, `Tawai ... is particularly well adapted for ship-building ... and is commonly called `black birch' by the sailors and other Europeans

Black Budget
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: The name given first by opponents, and then generally, to Finance Minister Nordmeyer's deflationary budget of 1958 and thence to any such budget (also used of an earlier budget); Charles Ransom comments (Nov 1986): referred to occas. by journalists but does not seem to have entered the language as meaning `deflationary budget'.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  2/8/1999
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:
Quote:  June 26 [1958]. Minister of Finance Arnold Nordmeyer presented his first Budget, increasing taxes on beer, spirits, cigarettes and tobacco. Known ever after as the Black Budget, it was a response to a balance of payments crisis and introduced cheap housing loans and the Pay-As-You-Earn (Paye) tax system.


Notes:

Date:  11/2/1999

Vol / Page:  6

Date:  0/0/1976
Source:  Nash
Author:  SINCLAIR
Vol / Page:  309
Edition:
Quote:  In 1930 J.G. Coates had called Ward's budget `the Black Budget' [PD 1931, 229, 88] - but that was long forgotten. This time the label stuck. Nordmeyer's budget [of June 1958] was remembered as `the black budget' for many years. It can be argued that it was good for `the country'. For the government it was a suicidal mistake. It was the biggest blunder in Nash's political career. Although he was not immediately and directly responsible, he was the leader and did not say `No'.

black burn
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: an incomplete forest fire where the heat is insufficient to reduce timber to a small residue of white ash.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1970
Source:  Grasslands of NZ
Author:  LEVY
Vol / Page:  241
Edition:
Quote:  A white ash, called a white burn was the objective; a black burn resulted from a less intense fire where the heat was not sufficient to burn the timber, leaf mould, seeds and spores on the forest floor.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1990
Source:  Lunesdale: A Bush Farm Community from 1871
Author:  BIBBY
Vol / Page:  12
Edition:
Quote:  The fire made a horrible mess, the material not being dry enough to get rid of small trees - to the bushmen, a 'blackburn'. [blackburn]
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1951
Source:  Grasslands of NZ
Author:  LEVY
Vol / Page:  87
Edition:  1970
Quote:   It was not so difficult to replace the forest with grass where the climate made intense white-ash burns possible after the felling of the forest. ... But in higher rain-fall belts, when poor burns (black burns) only occur, much forest litter remained unconsumed ... <i>Ibid.</I> 241 A steady, hot fire was desired in order to burn all fallen timber and leaf mould, seeds, and fern spores lying dormant on the forest floor. A white ash, called a <I>white burn</i>, was the objective; a black burn resulted from a less intense fire where the heat was not sufficient to burn the timber, leaf mould, seeds, and spores on the forest floor.
Notes:

Notes:  Myers Endemic Birds

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/156
Edition:
Quote:  <i>pi[i]wakawaka</i>, a bird (Rhipidura flabellifera), pied fantail: the so-called black fantail, which is chocolate-colour (R. fuliginosa) is ti[i]wakawaka. The former is common throughout Newzealand; the latter is common in the South Island but rather rare in the North and is thought to be a mutant of the former. Both names were applied to both birds by the Maori, but for distinction pi[i]wakawaka for the pied and ti[i]wakawaka for the black have been adopted by the Pakeha. The bird is noted for the disaster it caused to Maui in his struggle with the mother of night, Hine-nui-te-po, Death personified.


Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Birds of New Zealand
Author:  FALLA et al.
Vol / Page:  198
Edition:
Quote:  FANTAIL <i>Rhipidura fuliginosa Maori name</i>: Piwakawaka. ...  Birds of normal colour pattern (`Pied Fantail') make up most of the population in North Island, but the `Black Fantail' (i.e. dark phase) accounts for perhaps a quarter of the population of the South Island subpecies; ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Author:
Vol / Page:  280
Edition:
Quote:  Fantail <i>Rhipidura fuliginosa</i> (SPARRMAN, 1787)  North Island Fantail <i>R.f. placabilis </i>BANGS, 1921. South Island Fantail <i>R.f. fulginosa</i>  (SPARRMAN, 1787). Chatham Island Fantail <i>R.f. penitus</i> BANGS, 1911. OTHER NAMES: <i>Piwakawaka, pied  fantail, black fantail. </i>

Date:  0/8/1998
Source:  Mana
Author:
Vol / Page:  28
Edition:
Quote:  She plays on the wing for the Black Ferns, as the New Zealand women's rugby team is now called after rejecting labels like Gal Blacks, Elle Blacks and She Bs.


Notes:

Date:  0/1/1999
Source:  NZWords
Author:
Vol / Page:  2(1) : 5
Edition:
Quote:  Better or not the officially sanctioned substitute was announced early in August and the Gal Blacks of brief notoriety (along with other canvassed names such as Elle Blacks and She Bs

- after ABs) were finally history. The team was henceforth to be known as the Black Ferns. Here the colour adjective fittingly remains, and the noun echoes the name sported (since the early 1990s) by another black-clad international New Zealand women's team, the netballers or Silver Ferns. Since that title itself derives from the famous fernleaf-cum-national symbol of the All Black jersey (to wear the silver fern is a common variant of to be an All Black), there is an obvious appropriateness in reapplying the fern to the rugby union context. Black Ferns is further legitimised bv the presence in the natural world of a black (tree-) fern, in Maori the mamaku.
Notes:

Date:  6/6/1999
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  12
Edition:

Notes:  (Thomson, Otago)

Date:  0/6/1921
Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology
Author:
Vol / Page:  IV/122
Edition:
Quote:  RHOMBOSOLEA RETIARIA Hutton. <i>Black Flounder; Patiki-mohoao</i>. This species, known generally as `river-flounder,' is occasionally taken in the sea. Common in the estuaries of most large rivers, and often taken many miles inland.


Notes:  Phillipps  Notes on the Edible Fishes

Date:  0/0/1927
Source:  Natural History of Canterbury
Author:  SPEIGHT
Vol / Page:  201
Edition:
Quote:  The four species of Rhombosolea are distinguished by form and colour. The best known is the Sand flounder, or simply Flounder,  (<i>R. plebeia</i>) (Plate II. fig. 2) wider across than the other, while the Greenback  (<i>R. tapirina</i>) with white undersurface, the Yellowbelly  (<i>R. leporina</i>) and the Black flounder  (<i>R. retiaria</i>) have their distinguishing colours recorded in their common names.
Notes:  1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in  Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 201

Date:  0/0/1927
Source:  Bibliography of NZ Fishes
Author:  PHILLIPPS
Vol / Page:  29
Edition:  1971
Quote:  <i>Rhombosolea retiaria</i> Hutton. RIVER-FLOUNDER, BLACK FLOUNDER; PATIKI-MOHOAO.

Source:  Marine Fishes

Vol / Page:  32

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1970
Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author:  SORENSON
Vol / Page:  24
Edition:
Quote:  FLOUNDER (four species) (a) Scientific name: <i>(i) Rhombosolea plebeia (ii) Rhombosolea retiaria (iii)  Rhombosolea tapirina (iv) Rhombosolea leporina</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Flounder (ii) Freshwater Flounder (iii) Flounder (iv) Yellowbelly Flounder. (c) Other common names: (i) Square, Dab, Plaice, Diamond or Diamond-back, Tin-plate, Three Corners. (ii) Blacks, Black Flounder (iii) Greenback [25 `Not common but occasionally taken in southern

waters.'] (iv) Yellow Flounder.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  72
Edition:
Quote:  FLOUNDER, BLACK More sole-like in shape than his cousin flounders this fellow also has small, brick-red spots on his back and has the ability - unlike the other flatfish - of being able to live in pure, fresh water. Other names are `River Flounder' and `Mud or Freshwater Flounder'.


Notes:

Date:  8/12/1982
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  37
Edition:
Quote:  Another rare species is the black flounder, which may be available in the lower North Island because a few are netted at Lake Onoke in the Wairarapa and sold locally. It has a dark green back with darker mottling and is dotted with beautiful brick-red spots.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author:  BURTON
Vol / Page:  73
Edition:
Quote:  These much sought-after but relatively rare flatfish [flounder and sole] are generally found on sandy bottoms of shallow inshore areas. There are eight commercial species in New Zealand : the sand flounder, yellowbelly flounder, greenback flounder, black flounder, lemon sole, common sole, brill and turbot.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  204
Edition:  2nd ed.
Quote:  NEW ZEALAND BLACK FLOUNDER or RIVER FLOUNDER (PATIKI-MOHOAO)

<i>Rhombosolea (Adamsoma) retiaria adams </i>Whitley and Phillipps. It is known to fishermen and those in the fishing industry as the River Flounder as it is caught mostly inside or near the mouths of rivers and enters lakes where it lives chiefly among weeds. To some it is known as the Maori Flounder. I have helped to catch these fish in various rivers in New Zealand, Both in the North and South Islands, from the Bay of Islands, Bay of Plenty, Canterbury and Otago.
