black maire
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Nestegis species, esp. N. cunninghamii


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1875
Source:  Durability NZ Timbers
Author:
Vol / Page:  21
Edition:
Quote:  MAIRE.- <i>(Olea cunninghami</i>i and <i>O. lanceolata.</i>) ... BLACK MAIRE.-

(<i>Olea apetala</i>.) ... MAIRE.- <i>(Santalum cunninghamii.) </i>These afford fine-grained timber of great density ... All are commonly called `Maire' alike by settlers and Natives. Black maire usually attains the largest dimensions, and is sometimes 40 feet high or more. <i>Santalum</i> is the least of the group, but even stems of this ... make durable fencing rails. ... All the kinds are confined to the North Island ... <i>Eugenia maire</i> black maire
Notes:  (And) 1875 Kirk Durability NZ Timbers 21

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Oxford Book of NZ Plants
Author:  MOORE & IRWIN
Vol / Page:  118
Edition:
Quote:  The four New Zealand species were long placed with the true olives in <i>Olea</i>; more recently

they fell temporarily into <i>Gymnelaea</i> but now are all attributed to <i>Nestegis, ...

NESTEGIS CUNNINGHAMII, black maire</i>. A tall, stout-trunked tree of North Island mixed forests, recorded also from Nelson and marlborough but now common in only a few districts. The young sapling has longer and narrower leaves as has its nearest relative, the white maire <i>(N. lanceolata)</i>.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  NZ Medicinal Plants
Author:  BROOKER et al.

Vol / Page:  42

species, black maire (<i>N. cunninghamii</i>) and white maire (<i>N. lanceolata</i>), the juveniles are much narrower than the adults ... (ii) local name for <i>Eugenia maire </I>

Source:  Handbook of New Zealand
Author:  HECTOR
Vol / Page:  132
Edition:
Quote:   Maire - a small tree ten to fifteen feet high, six to eight inches in diameter; wood hard, close-grained, heavy, used by Maoris in the manufacture of war implements. Has been used as a substitute for box by wood-engravers. Black maire, <i>N.O. Jasmineae</i>; also Maire-rau-nui, <i>Olea Cunninghamii.</i> Hook., fil., Black M., forty to fifty feet high, three to four feet in diameter, timber close-grained, heavy, and very durable.

black oil
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: oil burned by careless trying-out in unclean or charred pots, (not the oil of the `black whale' in this instance).

Author:  FORSTER
Vol / Page:  2/220
Edition:  1982
Quote:  We saw a great Variety of bird this day viz. A white & sooty Albatross (<i>Diomedea exulans & palpebrata</i>). The black & sooty Petrel, (<i>Procellaria aequinoctialis & fuliginosa</i>) the black banded Petrel (<i>Procellaria vittata</i>); the small white rumped Petrel (<i>Proc. pelagica</i>) & we saw likewise three times a <i>Port Egmont Hen</i>, which is commonly thought a mark of the vicinity of Land. [ed. fn] The birds listed here are, respectively, the Wandering Albatross; Light-mantled Sooty Albatross; White-chinned Petrel; Great-winged Petrel; <i>Pachyptila</i> spp; Wilson's Storm Petrel and Antarctic Skua.

Edition:
Quote:  <i>Majaqueus parkinsoni</i>, Gray. (Black petrel.) ... I am quite satisfied that this bird is the `Night Demon' of our diggers. I had a live one ... from Collingwood ... On windy nights the bird would become very excited, and then it would give vent to the hysterical laugh or scream from which it takes its name.

black robin
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a small black endangered bird, Petroica traversi whose numbers fell to five known individual birds in the 1970s, and of which there was only one female in the world, known as Old Blue. A small population now exists on at least two of the Chatham Islands.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Environment
Region: [none]

black sand
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: DNZE nested in black-sand v.intr. p.60
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/11/1990
Source:  Geological Society of NZ Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page:  90/35-6
Edition:
Quote:  Te Maika has rich blacksand beaches, and is within walking distance of the very extensive blacksand deposit at Taharoa.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1948
Source:  Julius Von Haast
Author:  VON HAAST
Vol / Page:  528
Edition:
Quote:  Generally the greater portion of the sand is removed, but in favourable spots, sheltered either by a slight indentation in the coast-line, or by some large pieces of drifted timber, its heavier particles remain; these consist [529] of black iron-sand (both magnetic and titaniferous oxide of iron) associated with small garnets and with gold. These black layers are often one or two inches thick, and repose upon coarse quartzose sands. As soon as a storm has subsided, the `beachers' or `surfers' as they are called, examine the coastline near their houses. When they come upon one of the rich spots, the fine particles of gold being often visible to the naked eye, they at once remove the black layer of sand out of the reach of the tide, and wash it when convenient.
Notes:  1868 Von Haast in 1948 Von Haast Julius Von Haast 528-529



Date:  0/0/1895
Source:  NZ Reader
Author:
Vol / Page:  259
Edition:
Quote:  Nearly the whole of the west coast of the Middle Island ... is auriferous ... a ship's boat disembarked you on the black sand of the sea shore ... Ten thousand diggers ... were delving in the sand of a long strip of beach sixty miles south of Hokitika.
Notes:  1885 A Forbes `Souvenirs of Some Continents' in 1895 NZ Reader 259

Date:  0/0/1974
Source:  Bright Fine Gold
Author:  HEINZ
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  They give me a shovel and with it nearly full of sand, direct me to shake it gently in the water till all the sand has gone, then round its rim is a thin line of gold, fine as dust, enough to cover a threepenny bit. This is the easiest way of getting gold, so easy it is called `haymaking', but it will not last long, as the black sand brought down by the rivers, with its gold from the mountains and cast up on the beach where it has lain for centuries, is of limited extent.
Notes:  18-- Harper Letters from NZ (1914) in 1974 Heinz Bright Fine Gold 10

Word Class: noun

black stilt
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an endangered South Island wading bird, Himantopus novaezelandiae, also known as kaki.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  18/8/2002
Source:  Sunday Star Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  F4
Edition:
Quote:  In <i>Pied</i>, a tight target-like knot of 50 black stilt heads is surrounded by a "widespread" (3nm in diameter) flock of pied stilts. This is a direct reference to the fact that in 1980 there were only 50 black stilts left in the world. One of the threats to the species was that it had begun inter-breeding with pied stilts.

Date:  0/0/1980
Source:  House Above the Sea
Author:  LOCKLEY
Vol / Page:  181
Edition:
Quote:   New Zealand boasts four endemic waders not found elsewhere in the world. These are the black stilt, now limited to a few pairs nesting on high ground in the centre of the South Island; the shore plover, confined entirely to a small island off the Chathams, where its numbers are fairly strong; and the New Zealand dotterel, red-breasted in summer, rather curiously nesting in two discrete groups, one in the Hauraki Gulf, the other far away at and around Stewart Island -
Notes:

Author:  PARKER
Vol / Page:  117
Edition:
Quote:  `There are eleven species of Native Ducks belonging to nine genera, all found elsewhere, except two--the little Flightless Duck of the Auckland Islands (genus <i>Nesonetta</i>) and the Blue Mountain Duck (<i>Hymenolamus</i>). Among the most interesting of the non-endemic forms, are the Paradise Duck or Sheldrake (<i>Casarca variegata</i>), the Brown Duck (<i>Anas chlorotis</i>), the Shoveller or Spoonbill duck (<i>Rhynchaspis variegata</i>), and the Scaup or Black Teal (<i>Fuligula Novae-Zealandiae</i>).'

black-backed gull
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a black and white gull, Larus dominicanus, the largest of three native species of gull, commonly seen inland as well as on the coast (also called karoro, southern black-backed gull).

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  Animals of NZ, The
Author:  NATUSCH
Vol / Page:  267
Edition:
Quote:  Family LARIDAE (gulls). Of the three species here, the common  red-billed gull (<i>Larus novaehollandiae scopulinus</i> ... ) breeds on islets in harbours and off shore; the black-billed (<i>L. bulleri, </i>... ) nests commonly on the wide shingly river flats of Canterbury; and the much larger black-backed (<i>L. dominicanus</i>, ... ) breeds along coasts, river banks and on outlying islands [and is] our biggest and commonest seagull.

blackball
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: black and white striped boiled sweet; a hard, round, black sweet with white stripes, similar to a

`brandyball': in general English often called humbug. ;
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Citations
blackberry
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: The common term (rather than bramble) for the introduced Rubus fruticosus var., both the vine and the fruit since (in Britain,<i> bramble</i> is possibly applied more to the vine; <i>blackberry</i> to the fruit: see OED2 2.) Cook (Third Voyage) seems to prefer <i>bramble</i> [check]; also occas. (as was bramble) used for the native <i>R. cissoides, R. australis</i>, tataramoa, bush-lawyer
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: cf. also bramble
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/12/2003
Source:  NZ Memories
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 45/26
Edition:
Quote:  He had bought forty acres of blackberry and gorse.

blackberry man
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1

black-billed gull
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an inland gull, Larus bulleri, with slender black bill and reddish-black legs and feet (superficially like the red-billed gull but with a black bill)
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]

black-eyed gecko
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a grey gecko which lives in the mountainous areas of Nelson and Marlborough at higher altitudes than any other NZ lizard.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Environment
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/8/2002
Source:  Forest & Bird
Author:
Vol / Page:  305/33
Edition:
Quote:  The black-eyed gecko was first discovered on the Seaward Kaikoura Range in the 1970s, though not formally described until 1984. It is New Zealand's only alpine lizard, inhabiting bluffs and outcrops between 1250 and 2200 metres above sea level.
Notes:

Date:  0/8/2008

Vol / Page:  30
Edition:
Quote:  Insects and lizards are particularly diverse in the new park, and include three species of giant weta and New Zealand's only alpine lizard - the black-eyed gecko - which has its stronghold in the area.

Quote:  GIRELLA TRICUSPIDATA. <i>Mangrove-fish</i>, or <i>Blackfish.</i> Common in Auckland throughout the year. Sold as `blackfish.' ... In December and January this species is often seen on the surface associated with school snapper, among which it appears to spawn.

Quote:  Family GIRELLIDAE.<i>Girella tricuspidata</i>..., the blackfish or parore, is another seaweed eater; dark brown above, lighter beneath, striped in life, it inhabits warm northern waters.

black-heart birch
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Nothofagus solandri
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1876
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  64
Edition:
Quote:  The utmost confusion prevails among the common names of the birches. There are scarcely two districts, a few miles apart, in which the same name is applied to the same tree, and a similar result may be obtained by consulting two bushmen in the same bush. With a view to obviating this difficulty Mr Kirk suggests `the adoption of new names based of the obvious characteristics of foliage [e.g.] for Fagus fusca `tooth-leaved beech'; for Fagus solandri `entire-leaved beech' etc. [This is unsuitable as foliage varies] I would suggest the retention of the common Otago names Fagus fusca - Red birch ; F. solandri - Black-heart birch ; F Menziesii - Silver birch.
Notes:  (Blair)

Date:  0/0/1877
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  9/
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Nothofagus Solanderi </I>
Notes:   (3 examples)

Date:  0/0/1883
Source:  Handbook of New Zealand
Author:  HECTOR
Vol / Page:  125
Edition:  3rd
Quote:  <i>Nothofagus solandri</i>, Hook. White-birch of Nelson and Otago (from colour of bark), Black-heart Birch of Wellington.--A lofty, beautiful evergreen tree 100 feet high; trunk 4-5 feet in diameter.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1885
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  17/301
Edition:
Quote:  <i>[Notho]fagus solandri,</i> Hook. f. ... <i>Myrtilloides cinerascens</i>, Banks & Sol., MS. <i>Cliffortiordes oblongata,</i> Dryander. Entire-leaved Beech. Black Birch of Wellington, Canterbury, and in part of Otago and Southland. White Birch of Nelson, and in part Otago. Black-heart Birch of Otago. White, Black, Red, and Brown Birch of Oxford and Alford Forests. A fine tree, sometimes attaining the height of 100 feet, but usually 60-80 feet, with a trunk from 2 to 4 feet or more in diameter.
Notes:  (Kirk, NZ Beeches)

Date:  0/0/1889
Source:  Forest Flora
Author:  KIRK

Quote:  <i>Nothofagus solandri</i>, BLACK-BIRCH

Blackmore coulter
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an attachment to an ordinary seed-sower which spreads seeds in 30 rows, 3 inches apart instead of 15 rows of an ordinary coulter. Designed by L. Blackmore of the Department of Agriculture, Timaru. see 1952 Nov (1953) Proceedings of the NZ Grasslands Assoc.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes: (R. Mason)

black-sander

Sense Number:

Vol / Page:  19
Edition:
Quote:  They called a crook cook a 'blacksmith', perhaps because he used his stove like a forge and welded all the food to the pot. Though those whose noses scented out the menu, while clumping up the path, won't forget those days .. providing their cook wasn't a 'blacksmith' - on sabbatical from the local forge.

blacksmith

Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:  a sticky sheep that is difficult to shear.

Author:
Vol / Page:  14
Edition:
Quote:  [Hdg] Zorbing not for the pink-knuckled... New Zealand has contributed the terms zorbing and black-water rafting. Zorbing is an entertainment where those taking part are suspended inside giant plastic balls and rolled down steep slopes. Black-water rafting is the pastime of floating along pitch-black underground streams in inflated inner tubes.

Date:  22/2/2003
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  C1
Edition:
Quote:  "We represent a company called Blackwater Rafting, who are involved in cave tubing," Mr Bassett said. "Unfortunately, they lost exclusive rights to their name when a judge ruled that Blackwater rafting had become a generic name for cave tubing and others in the industry could use it... For example, Blackwater Rafting was involved in cave tubing, but the media continued to describe the activity as blackwater rafting. The company should have corrected this the first time, as by not doing so the term eventually became generic."

See:

Notes:
Citations
blanketings
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1876
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  8/334
Edition:
Quote:  While on an official visit to the Thames Goldfield I ...[observed] the ... effect of Cyanide of Potassium, in preventing the flouring of mercury used in working the blanketings. These blanketings I found have ... a decidedly acid reaction, due ... to the presence of ferric and ferrous salts ..., and it is to the former ... that what is commonly known as [335] `flouring,' is mainly due, in the process cited above; such ferric salts being able to either oxidize or chloridize the surface of any mercury ..., thus enfilming it with a compound, which being practically insoluble in water ... prevents that metallic contact taking place between detached mercurial globules, which is necessary to amalgamation.
Notes:  (Skey)

Date:  0/0/1876
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  8/179
Edition:
Quote:  The blanket tailings or blanketings, as they are otherwise called, consist mostly of iron pyrites and other sulphides, cobines with quartz, and contain a fair proportion of gold ...that had escaped over the silver tables. These tailings are treated in berdans with extra quicksilver and ground up. The berdans now in use at the Thames ... are generally five feet in diameter ... At one time a couple of rotating balls were considered sufficient for the amount of crushing required; now, the general practice is to have a loose ball as well as a stationary one attached to a chain, and it is called a drag ball; this drag does more work than a loose ball ... for the drag grinds the bowl as much as the tailings.
Notes:

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1960
Source:  Memories of Maoriland
Author:  SCRYMGEOUR
Vol / Page:  145
Edition:
Quote:  Often in that Autumn, belated lambs that failed to fatten in the earlier drafts, waxed fat. The seed ripened on the ryegrass, and with it came the legacy of `ergot'. Practical sheep men found that this complaint produced `staggers'. Too much blood obtained, although the patient was in splendid condition, used to keep spinning round, and the remedy was the ancient panacea of most diseases in England, centuries ago, and ere science interrupted their outlook, viz. `to bleed' and take from the patient the overflow of red corpuscles.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1968
Source:  Remembered Trails
Author:  TOMLINSON
Vol / Page:  19
Edition:
Quote:  After camping the night there, we had to cross Kerr's Hill which was covered with tutu, a poisonous plant for sheep, and the curse of drovers. ... Odd sheep started to get `tooted' and instead of pushing on the men started bleeding the sheep. This was done by cutting a vein under the eye. It was supposed to help the sheep, although I never thought it did any good.

blenny
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: used mainly as a book-name (f.Blennius) for a widespread family (?genus), or in NZ a variety of genera, small spiny-finned fishes recorded earliest in NZ waters(OED2 1774);

often (esp. by children) popularly called cockabully;

For most New Zealanders over 50, however, Blerta is best remembered as a colourful troupe of artists, anarchists and musicians who travelled the highways and byways of New Zealand in a vivdly decorated omnibus of indeterminate age and intermittent reliability. ... Religious allusions aside, Blerta's over-riding message was fun.

Vol / Page:  F1

Quote:  During its five-year run in the 1970s, Blerta attracted such an extraordinary collection of movers, shakers and far-out characters, Bruno was just one wild man among many... "It's possible to trace the beginings of the New Zealand film industry from Blerta," says Murphy, whose documentary <i>Blerta Revisited</i>, features in the naton's film festivbals this month... Blerta began in October, 1971, when Bruno was 30 years old and restless as a bear stung by a swarm of bees... Blerta was an acronym for Bruno Lawrence's Electric Revelation and Travelling Apparition... "Blurter" was also a rude term for genitals in '70s slang.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/159
Edition:
Quote:  <i>tauhou</i>, a wandering bird (Zosterops halmaturina), blight-bird; twinkie; button-eye; wax-eye; ring-eye. Tauhou means stranger and this name was given by the Maori when the bird appeared, in 1856, in the central part of Newzealand, gradually spreading north and south till the islands were occupied. It is an Australian bird, and was blown across the Tasman sea in the year mentioned.
Notes:   Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1957
Source:  Dictionary of the Maori Language
Author:  WILLIAMS
Vol / Page:  94
Edition:

Edition:
Quote:  The history of the little <I>Zosterops</i>, or Blight-bird, is a case in point. <I>Ibid.</I> 1/82 By the settlers it [sc <I>Zosterops</I>] has been variously designated as Ring-eye, Wax-eye, White-eye, or Silver-eye, in allusion to the beautiful circlet of satiny-white feathers which surrounds the eyes; and quite as commonly as the `Blight-bird', or `Winter Migrant'.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1897
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  29/285
Edition:
Quote:  To-day my son was dissecting a common bittern (<I>Botaurus poecilopilus</I>) ... We found the `bill of fare' for that day to have been a silver-eye (<I>Zosterops caerulescens</I>), ... It is well known that the bittern varies its feeding ... adding still another enemy to our useful little migrant blight-bird.
Notes:  (Drew)

Vol / Page:  2018
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Blight&#769;.bird&#769;.</i> (bl&imacr.t&#769;.b&etilde.rd&#769;.), <i>n. (Zoo.l.) </i>The New Zealand name for the white-eye (<i>Zosterops coerulescens</i>), whichclears trees of insect blight; - called also <i>ring-eye, silver-eye</i>, and <i>wax-eye</i>. See WHITE-EYE in Dictionary. The bird was originally confined to eastern Australia and Tasmania, but it settled in flocks in New Zealand in 1851, making its escape from the great bush fire of Black Thursday (Feb. 6, 1851).
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  36
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Blight-bird</i> ... a bird-name in New Zealand for the <i>Zosterops</i> (q.v.). .us; <i>Called also</i> Silver-eye <i>(q.v.)</i>, Wax-eye, <i>and </i>White-eye (q.v.). It is called <i>Blight-bird </i>because it eats the blight on trees.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1882
Source:  Out in the Open
Author:  POTTS
Vol / Page:  130
Edition:
Quote:  The white-eye or blight-bird, with cheerful note, in crowded flocks, sweeps over the face of the country, and in its progress clears away multitudes of small insect pests.'
Notes:

Date:  18/6/1904
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  8
Edition:
Quote:  A notable exception is the silver-eye,

white-eye or blight-bird (zosterops)

which was blown across the Tasman Sea by

a storm some fifty or sixty years ago.

Date:  0/0/1869

Author:
Vol / Page:  1/iii/10
Edition:
Quote:  [<i>Zosterops</i>] subsists almost entirely [in Wellington orchards and gardens] on the destructive little <i>Aphis</i> known as `American Blight'.
Notes:  (Buller Ornithology)

Date:  0/0/1870
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  2/61
Edition:
Quote:  ZOSTEROPS LATERALIS, Lath. Tauhou. Blight-bird. We first noticed this bird ... in the Rockwood Valley, Malvern Hills, July 28th, 1856. ... It very soon obtained the name of Blight-bird ... from its habit of feeding on the American blight, with which apple trees in this colony are so generally infested ...
Notes:  (Potts Birds)

Date:  0/0/1871
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  3/21
Edition:
Quote:  By the settlers it has been variously designated as Ring-eye, Wax-eye, White-eye or Silver-eye in allusion to the beautiful circlet of satiny-white feathers which surrounds the eyes.; and quite as commonly as the `Blight-bird' or `Winter Migrant.'
Notes:  (Buller)

blight-bird
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a small bird Zosterops  lateralis, valued by horticulturists for pest control. [also known as ring-eye, wax-eye, white-eye or silver-eye].

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <I>blimey, Charlie! </I>indicating friendly relief; obs.; derived from mostly Cockney `blimey' abbreviation of `Gorblimey', abbreviation of `God blind me'. NZA.
Notes:

blind
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition:  1. ground easily overlooked when inspecting a flock. 2. a feature such as a gully or a spur that ends abruptly and denies access.

blind-stabbing
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: cf. blind dip
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1950
Source:  Personal Communication
Author:  CLEVELAND
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  <i> blind-stabbing</i>: Used by Jack Sweeney, prospector, to describe traditional method of getting gold-bearing wash out of glacial rivers. The prospector is anchored by a rope which is controlled by a mate on the bank. He wheels a wheelbarrow as far into the torrent as is possible, shovels the alluvial wash into it blindly, because the water contains glacial silts and is milky white, and returns to the bank with as much as he can shift. This is processed at leisure for gold
Notes:   South Westland

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary)
Author:  McARA
Vol / Page:  313
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Blister</i>: A small charge of gelignite placed on a large stone to break it into pieces small enough to handle. The charge was laid on the stone and covered with damp clay to make it airtight. Frequently used by truckers when the ore passes or chutes became blocked with large boulders.

Pilchard are caught for groper bait (`bloater'), and have been used also for tuna.

block
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:  1. one of the parcels in which a town site is available for settlement ... 1833 2. a parcel of land which is entire and of a piece, esp. one taken up for settlement 1835 3. a variously defined unit of measurement used to limit the size of a piece of land taken up for settlement or to determine rent 1843 ... the runs would be divided into blocks of a square mile ...4. a building allotment 1874 5. mining 1858 a block claim is a fixed area, with bounds ascertained from the first.]
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1929
Source:  Whitcombe's Etym. Dict. Aust-NZ Suppl.
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  <I>~ n</I>. a surveyed piece of land; a section of a town bounded by streets.- doing the block, on the block, promenading in a popular or fashionable place in a large town.




Notes:

Date:  19/11/1957
Source:  Personal Communication
Author:  G T ARCUS
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  A few years ago I travelled to Britain via Australia and on the boat an Englishman was telling me that while in Australia he bought a block of land and built his own house. To me the word block suggested a large piece of land, so with visions of Sid Kidman I asked him how big. He replied, `Oh, just fifth of an acre,' I said that in NZ we would call that a section. An American put in that in his country a section was a square mile and the word was used with that meaning in parts of Australia, but in the States they used the word `lot' to describe a building block. I replied that in NZ building blocks were the piles that a house stood on and the Englishman said that in Australia they called them stumps.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collins Concise English Dictionary
Author:
Vol / Page:  114
Edition:
Quote:  <I>block ... 6. do one's block. Austral. sl</I>. to become angry. ... <I>10. Austral. & N.Z.</I> an area of land, usually extensive, taken up for farming, settlement, etc. <I>11. N.Z.</I> an area of bush reserved by licence for a trapper or hunter. ... <I>13. Austral. & N.Z</I>. a log, usually of willow, fastened to a timber base and used in a wood-chopping competition.
Notes:   [1986 NZPOD 74; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 52]



block
Homonym Number:  3
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a self-contained off-job training or study section of a trainee's or apprentice's training period, esp. a block course, an off-job course of study or training done in a `block' of time (say a fortnight) as distinct from a course given while working on the job.




Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  7/6/1952
Source:  Letter
Author:  R MASON
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  Esp. on block. ca1939 R. Mason (nurses) In early days nurses trained and nursed at the same time, a system replaced by a `block' of nursing followed by a `block' of study. ON BLOCK signifies the whole time is devoted to study; on a period.
Notes:

Source:  Lyttelton Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:
Quote:  The colonists, since they arrived in this country, have represented that great advantages would be gained by increasing the block so as to include all the plains of the district. They found that the Canterbury block was part of the plain lying in the vast segment of the wide circle between the sea and a range of mountains, entirely cut off from all other settlements by natural boundaries, and formed, as it were by nature, to consist of one district in itself.

block
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: and official Government land purchase and partly a technical surveyors' term for a large surveyed parcel of land, which in some cases has been incorporated into place-names, some of which survive (e.g. Bell Block, Taranaki); A large parcel or lot of Maori land officially surveyed for purchase for subdivision and settlement; a survey block: possibly spec. of Ma. land defined and bearing the orig. tribal name (AND 2 1835 seems to fit with this last sense). -

Date:  0/0/1952
Source:  NZ Forest Glossary
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  1. in forest management, a major subdivision of a forest, generally bounded by natural features and bearing a local name. In some of the first established exotic forests, BLOCK was used in place of <i>Compartment. </I> 2. in land-subdivision, a major subdivision of a Survey District. ... A BLOCK is usually 1/16 of a Survey District and is square, with sides 250 chains long. Block numbers are indicated by roman numerals

3. in land-subdivision, a term relating to a defined area of Maori land and bearing the original Maori tribal name.

block

Sense Number:  1
Definition:  1. an area of land, usually separately surveyed off a larger piece 2. an extensive hilly paddock in hill and high country areas. 3. a complete farm property, occasionally one of many under the same ownership.

Source:  NZ Forest Glossary
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  1. in forest management, a major subdivision of a forest, generally bounded by natural features and bearing a local name. In some of the first established exotic forests, BLOCK was used in place of <i>Compartment</i>.

Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:   2. in land-subdivision, a major subdivision of a Survey District. ... A BLOCK is usually 1/16 of a Survey District and is square, with sides 250 chains long. Block numbers are indicated by roman numerals

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  2018
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Block</i> (bl&obreve.k),<i> n. [Add.] 13.</i> A rectangular lot of land; specifically, one of the large lots which Australian public land, when opened to settlers, is divided by the government surveyors. <i>Back blocks</i>, Australian pastoral country remote from the seacoast or from a river. "In the <i>back blocks</i> of Queensland, far removed from towns and civilization." <i>Melburnian. - Back blocker</i>, a bushman from the back blocks. <i>

[Colloq.] - Mallee block</i>, an area of land marked out by government in the Mallee district. See MALLEE. <i>- The Block,</i> fashionable promenade in Melbourne and in Sydney.

- <i>Do the Block</i>, to promenade in<i> the Block</i>.

Date:  0/0/1983
Source:  Whina
Author:  KING
Vol / Page:  36
Edition:
Quote:  ... Native Land Court sittings were held there in the late 1890s and early 1900s.* [fn] These sittings were not of the court proper, but of `block committees' of chiefs responsible for parcelling out shares in land allocated to particular hapu in earlier court sittings presided over by a judge. The block committees' decisions were subsequently ratified by court.

block grazing
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: stocking of pasture using front and back fencing and portable troughs.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/6/1970
Source:  NZ Dairy Exporter
Author:
Vol / Page:  7
Edition:
Quote:  If you are highly stocked or low on winter feed reserves, then block grazing, or wintering between the wires using a front and back fence, is a good way to get through until spring growth.
Notes:

Date:  0/11/1975
Source:  NZ Dairy Exporter
Author:
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  He says he has 'tried a whole lot' of wintering systems over the years but has decided that block grazing with a back fence is the best for his farm.
Notes:

Date:  15/6/1994
Source:  NZ Farmer
Author:
Vol / Page:  31
Edition:
Quote:  Mr Parks runs an all-grass system with winter ewe management a mixture of strip and block grazing.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1999
Source:  NZ Pasture and Crop Science
Author:  WHITE & HODGSON
Vol / Page:  156
Edition:
Quote:  Block grazing differs from strip grazing to the extent that the herd/flock is offered pasture on a daily basis with both a front and back temporary electric fence, and daily blocks are rectangular in shape.
Notes:

Date:  1/6/2001
Source:  Fencepost.com
Author:
Vol / Page:  Expert Farming
Edition:
Quote:  ..the cows are back fenced with another electric fence so that they cannot go back and cause further hoof damage on the pasture already eaten. Often, doing this will require the provision and connection of a portable water trough which will also be required to be shifted daily. This system has become known as block grazing.
Notes:

Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1972
Source:  Folkgames of Children
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  174
Edition:
Quote:  Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. <i>Ibid.</I> 176 [Waitara, Taranaki, 1899] A `taw' was usually an `alley' or `blood alley' made of agate. We used to take them home and burn
them in a fire to convert them into `blood alleys'.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1984
Source:  NZ Yesterdays
Author:  KEITH & MAIN
Vol / Page:  288
Edition:
Quote:  Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles.
Notes:


Date:  0/0/1984
Source:  Dictionary of Slang
Author:  PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page:  97
Edition:
Quote:  <i>blood alley</i>. A white, or whitish, marble streaked with red: Aus. and NZ children's: latye C.19-20. Adopted ex. common English dialect.

bloody
Homonym Number:
Word Class: adjective
Sense Number:
Definition: a colloquial intensifier, used, so EDD, by the `lower classes' `indifferently as a term of depreciation or appreciation'; frequent in NZ speech as it is elsewhere, but not so much as to be regarded as a New Zealandism (contrast great Australian adjective: no doubt used off the New Zealand coast from earliest English rediscovery, but not much recorded in print before WW1
Origin: [none]

Date:  0/0/1868
Source:  Contributions to NZ Botany
Author:  LINDSAY
Vol / Page:  49
Edition:
Quote:  The larger species [of <i>Aciphylla</i>] are familiar to the settlers as `Spear-grass', or `Bayonette-grass', `Wild' or `Bloody-Spaniard', [<i>bloody</i> =?] in allusion to their very rigid, strong, poniard-like, sharp-pointed leaves ... Hence a `Spear-grass Scrub' on the hill ranges is frequently most formidable ... to men and horses, though it forms one of the favourite hunting grounds of the Wild Pig. In the Matukituki Valley, `Bayonette-grass' forms an undergrowth in a dense scrub of prickly thorn ... [50] Familiar to the shepherds of Canterbury as `Bloody Spaniard'.
Notes:  [A.Colensoi: alpine plant]

Vol / Page:  2

Date:  0/0/1944
Source:  Moonshine
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  87
Edition:
Quote:  Dan Freel's conversation [as an Irish settler] was plentifully interlarded with oaths and obscurities that are - or would have been in the [18]80's - quite unprintable. At first it seemed an arresting, if not an interesting idiosyncracy, but one sickened of it. ... The sanguinary adjective too that sounds so daring but really has no significance whatever, he used between every second word, even between syllables as `I bloody well told the bloody mongrel that he was too ego-bloody-istical.' After the first few sentences this gave no gain in force and much loss in time. I noticed that the Irishmen, though they obviously bowed to Dan's smallest word, did not give him the sincerest flattery of imitation in this respect.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1950
Source:  Landfall
Author:
Vol / Page:  15/213
Edition:
Quote:  Yeh. Bloodywell need them.

Date:  0/0/1888
Source:  Antipodean Notes
Author:  D'AVIGDOR
Vol / Page:  171
Edition:
Quote:  [Colonialisms] To <i>`blow</i>' is, in the colonies, to brag or boast; this is graphic if not elegant; but one of the most curious expressions, based on an entirely errroneous derivation, is `an old identity', used for a person long `identified with a place' - in fact an old inhabitant, or one whose interests have long been bound up in it. This expression is unfortunately now universal even in newspapers.
Notes:

Vol / Page:  35
Edition:

blow
Homonym Number:  3
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: shearing: a stroke with the shears, a stroke of the shears (esp. long blow).


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1989
Source:  NZ English Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page:  3/21
Edition:
Quote:  <i>blow</i>: (1) Any stroke the shearer takes; e.g. `a blow over the tail'. (2) `To strike a blow' means to begin work.
Notes:   (Wallace Shearing Glossary)

Date:  0/0/1938
Source:  High Country
Author:  BURDON
Vol / Page:  84
Edition:
Quote:  The sheep they shore were not so well woolled on the belly and carried less wool on the points than they do now, so that fewer short blows were required to take off the trimmings; but the shears they used were one inch and a half shorter in the blade and, being joined by a single instead of a double bow, required a wrist of iron to drive them continuously throughout a summer's day. A piece of raw hide known as a knocker is now used to prevent the shears clashing when closed, but before this was introduced the clack and snap of steel meeting steel was a noise inseparable from any busy shearing shed.
Notes:

Date:  16/9/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Blow.</i>- The stroke of the shearer in handshearing. He drives the shears forward and makes a cut.
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Vol / Page:  2
Edition:

On good average-shearing crossbred sheep anything from fifty to sixty blows is satisfactory. <i>Ibid.</i> 65 The best way of working when crutching is to go at a good smart pace for half an hour and then have a five minutes' blow.

blow
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: to clean a mineral (esp. gold) by blowing air over it to remove the particles of the material in which it was found; to dry-blow
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: cf. dry-blowing
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1874
Source:  Colonial Experiences
Author:  BATHGATE
Vol / Page:  217
Edition:
Quote:  [Bank clerk] `By the time I had cleaned, or `blown' the gold, it was too late to think of returning. <i>Ibid.</I> 220 The gold is placed on a flat pear-shaped metal dish, with a perpendicular rim or edge except at the point of the pear, where there is no rim. This is moved in such a manner that the gold is tossed up, and all the finer particles and dirt are worked forward towards the opening, out by which the operator blows the sand.
Notes:

Quote:  It appeared that from October to Christmas he had made [pounds]2000 and he was now engaged in `blowing it in'. He was reeling down the street ...and when he saw me he called out, `Hey, Tom, I'm flyblown just now but come with me in a day or two and I will make your fortune for you.' [171] ... You ask what the term `flyblown' meant. It was a word used in those days [c1860s] and meant a man had no money, but once I saw a man really flyblown.

Register 2:

Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  <i>blow that for a joke! </i>emphatic rejection; `blow' euphemistic curse; eg `Me referee that lot? Blow that for a joke!

Date:  0/0/1974
Source:  Australian & NZ English [TS]
Author:  SYDER & HODGETTS
Vol / Page:  75
Edition:
Quote:   An acid dismissal of a proposition in which the speaker has been asked to participate; in the daily round of work, or in social life. .in 4;`What! Mac and I've done all the organizing and you others won't do a little job like this. Blow that for a joke!' .in 4;'I've done the late shift for three weeks, because none of you other jokers was willing. I wont do it continuously. Blow that for a joke!'
Notes:  (1962-63)

Source:  NZ Memories
Author:
Vol / Page:  p19
Edition:  No 51
Quote:  Knock it off, pack a sad, have a nice one Get stuck in, boots and all, have a coke, Half a shake, how ya doin', have a drop, of mother's ruin Hell's bells, blow that for a joke.

He hasn't been heard of from that day to this.' .in 4;b. To depart quickly with very little announcement. `Oh, he blew through - he went off up North somewhere, I think.'

blowing down
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a system of sluicing
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1908
Source:  NZ Geol. Survey Bulletin
Author:
Vol / Page:  No.5 (NS) 47
Edition:
Quote:  A system of sluicing in which strips of ground about 3 yards wide, on each side of a gutter, are sluiced into a gutter which runs down the slope. The work begins at the top of the slope and works down to a tail-race already constructed at the bottom ... <i>The Blowing-Down

System of Sluicing</i>. This is a novel system of sluicing that has been successfully used for the working of wide stretches of poor alluvial ground in Central Otage. Its greatest application has been in the Cromwell District where it has been in use for over thirty years. It was first introduced by a Russian miner, and, although long in use, is almost unknown outside of Central Otago.
Notes:  (Park, Cromwell)

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collins Concise English Dictionary
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  <i>bludge Austral. & N.Z. inf. ~ vb. 1.</i> (when <i>intr</i>., often foll. by <i>on</i>) to scrounge from (someone). 2.<i> (intr.)</i> to skive. <i>~n. 3.</i> a very easy task. [C19: back formation from<i> bludger</i> pimp, < BLUDGEON] - <i>bludger n. </i>

Vol / Page:  77
Edition:
Quote:  ?over long periods. .in 4;`He won't go out and get a bit of wood from the bush like the rest of us do, he'd rather bludge some from his old mother's shed.' Thus also, to make an occasional request, in good humour. .in 4;`We won't unpack till we get there, we'll call at Don's on the way and bludge a snack. He'll be real pleased to see us.'

Vol / Page:  15

Quote:  <i> bludger:</i> a bludger is a SPONGER - someone who is always borrowing and rarely repaying. To bludge is to borrow. It's socially acceptable to say `may I bludge a cigarette (or a cup of sugar)' but calling someone a bludger can be a fighting insult

bludger
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 4
Definition: inveterate cadger; sponger; occas. one who `borrows' or `lifts' objects
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1953
Source:  Till Human Voices Wake Us
Author:  HAMILTON
Vol / Page:  89
Edition:
Quote:  The Bludger. He was known among the boobheads as that. When they called him by his name you felt they were being intentionally respectful. ... But connected with him it didn't mean what it was supposed to mean. A bludger is a pimp, a man who lives on women, but I doubt if anyone thought specifically that of him. Bludger is also what it sounds, a fairly indiscriminate term of abuse. When the boobheads called him that they meant a lot of things. A bully, something sly, a chap who'd put a dirty one on to you, not necessarily for any purpose other than it gave him pleasure to do so.
Notes:

Quote:   The Mollymawks we had till we reached the South Tropic. ... In the Pacific I saw ... large flocks of `whale-birds' as the sailors called them - which were the Blue Billy (<i>Prion turtur</i>); but, in the South Atlantic, we met flocks of another but larger-sized grey bird, which they also called `whale-birds.' These were evidently <i>Procellaria glacialoides. </I>

blue borage

Quote:  The clays and sandstones are called the `Blue Bottom' ... [<i>Ibid. </i>86]

The Blue Bottom is so called because it forms the basement formation of the extensive unconsolidated later Tertiary and more recent deposits of the coastal plain, and consists chiefly of blue clay.
Notes:   (Bell and Fraser, Hokitika)

Quote:  <i>Blue cod Parapercis colias</i> ... Found only in New Zealand. Known almost exclusively by this common name, the occasionally listed coal-fish being a name used only by Captain Cook and some early writers, and derived from an unrelated European fish.

Notes:

blue duck
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an uncommon indigenous duck with blue-grey plumage, Hymenolaimus malacorhynchos, living in swift-flowing mountain and bush rivers, and also known as rapid duck on account of its fast-moving river habitat.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]

blue fit

blue grass
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: [sp. use] a palatable native tussock grass, Agropyron scabrum.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:

Author:  CONNELL & HADFIELD
Vol / Page:  272
Edition:
Quote:  Blue wheat grass (<i>Agropyron scabrum</i>) grows up to 1 ft. 6 in. chiefly between silver tussock. The only palatable tussocks are (1) the blue tussocks which are easily killed by continuous burning and by continuous close grazing and (2) the blue wheat grass which will stand hard grazing.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1980

Quote:  The cementing medium of the deposit is finely comminuted fresh mica-schist, resembling coarsely ground cement, hence the term `cement' applied by the miners to this and similar deposits. In the zone of weathering the `cement' is a rusty-brown colour ... Below the zone of weathering lies the unaltered `cement' which forms the `blue ground' of the miners.

the Blue Merle, but this is simply the description of a colour type, not the name of a breed, and in any case the phrase should be `blue merled'.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/153
Edition:
Quote:  <I> matuku, two birds, 1, Botaurus poeciloptilus, bittern, and 2, Demigretta sacra, blue-heron; the Maori distinguished these two according to their habitat: 1, matuku-hurepo (swamp matuku) and 2, matuku-moana (sea-matuku). When the Pakeha mentions the matuku he always refers to the bittern; the other he always calls blue-heron. </i>
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  Animals of NZ, The
Author:  NATUSCH
Vol / Page:  270
Edition:
Quote:  The reef heron or blue heron <I>(E[gretta]. sacra sacra, ...) </I>

Vol / Page:  132

Quote:  <I> Reef Heron Egretta sacra sacra </I>(GMELIN,  1789) ... OTHER NAMES: <I> Blue reef heron,  eastern reef heron, blue crane, blue heron,  matuku-moana. </I>... Reef herons in New Zealand are at the southeastern limit of their mostly tropical range, and for that reason alone may never be common.

Vol / Page:  35
Edition:
Quote:  <i>MAOMAO</i> (two species) (a) Scientific name: (i) <i>Scorpis violaceus</i> (ii) <i>Caprodon longimanus.</i> (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Blue maomao; Blue fish (ii) Pink maomao; Pink fish. (c) Other common names: None listed for either species (d) Principal localities where taken: [both] North Auckland, Hauraki Gulf, Bay of Plenty.

Author:  WILSON

Edition:
Quote:  MAOMAO Comes in two varieties - Pink and Blue. Both, however are from quite different families. The Blue Maomao occurs in northern waters over rocky ground and clear water down to about 100 feet.

Date:  26/6/2004
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  42
Edition:
Quote:  Among the 12 better-managed species at the top of the amber category there are only two - blue moki and blue cod - that I often buy... In the case of blue moki, although the flavour and texture is the equal of tarakihi or snapper, the flesh is threaded with fine dark veins, which makes it less appealing on the plate.

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  PAUL
Vol / Page:  105
Edition:
Quote:  [Trumpeters are] a family (Latrididae) which contains several species of Australasian fishes closely related and very similar to the morwongs. The Maori name `moki' is given to members of both families. <i>Blue moki Latridopsis ciliaris </i>... Also reported from southern Australia, although this may be a confusion with `bastard trumpeters'. Often simply called moki in New Zealand.
Notes:

blue moon
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a butterfly
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1980
Source:  NZ Butterflies
Author:  GIBBS
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Incidentally, it was Johannes Anderson (1924) writing in the <i>New Zealand School Journal</i> about a specimen of this butterfly which had been caught in Westland, who gave it our common name, saying `I have called it the `blue moon butterfly' because it is so rare; it is found only `once in a blue moon'. Besides it carries the blue moon on its wings, and it is like other blue moons - it is there all the time, but it is only when you are in certain positions that you see it.' The name has stuck and is certainly appropriate. The butterfly is known as the `common eggfly' in Australia.

Citations
Date:  3/10/2001
Source:  Capital Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  7
Edition:
Quote:  Blue Pearls are unique to New Zealand... Eyris established the first ocean based blue pearl farm in the Chatham Islands, followed by farms at Akaroa.
Notes:

Date:  4/10/2002
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  It's a story of the vision of New Zealander Roger Beattie who, in 1989, established the                 first ocean based blue pearl farm at Whangamoe Inlet on New Zealand's Chatham Islands...

Although most of the nucleation process is kept a secret, the Eyris Blue Pearl Company are continuing to refine the art of attaching a seed to the  inside of the shell, beneath the mantle, so that a blue pearl mabe can develop... Once the seed is inserted beneath the mantle, the paua begins to overlay this nucleus with its brilliant mother-of-pearl, made up of layer upon layer of conchiolin and nacre.
Notes:  from www.bluepearls.com

blue pointer shark
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1886
Source:  Handbook Fishes of NZ
Author:  SHERRIN
Vol / Page:  117
Edition:
Quote:  TIGER SHARK] TIGER SHARK (<i>Lamna glauca</i>). ... In New South Wales it is called the blue pointer, and, as Mr. Hill tells us, is `not only a very powerful, but perhaps the most bold of any of the large sharks visiting our shores. ... [118] Although there is some doubt on the subject, <i>Lamna glauca</i> is considered to be the mako of the Maoris, which is mainly found in the neighbourhood of Mayor Island. ... Mango, it should be remembered, seems [119] almost a generic name for shark in the North, as there is the mango-taniwha, a large variety; the mango-pare, the hammerheaded shark; the mango-reremai, the common dog-fish; the mango-pekepeke, and the mango-aruroa.

The substance is not illegal under New Zealand law but is believed to be performance-enhancing in horses and therefore banned in racing.... So armed with all this, some bright spark in Australia has decided to call it Blue Stuff - not HorsePower or Super Horse, or even methoxyxchlororidepanoprophren.You can imagine the confusion when there's a pre-dawn bang on the door and the coppers are yelling through the letterbox: "We're looking for illegal Blue Stuff."

Quote:  Most astounding of all is the belated recognition of Galaxy Blue Vein., which has been made to the same recipe since 1951, and is one of the strongest-tasting blue cheeses in the world.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author:  BURTON
Vol / Page:  51
Edition:
Quote:  Blue vein belongs to that family of cheeses which in England is called stilton, in France roquefort, in Italy gorgonzola, and in Denmark Danish blue. New Zealand blue vein is recognised as a blue cheese in its own right and can be distinguished from its Continental counterparts by the deeper yellow colour of its curd. This arises from a difference in milk colour.

Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1926
Source:  Weeds of New Zealand
Author:  HILGENDORF
Vol / Page:  143
Edition:  1967
Quote:  VIPER'S BUGLOSS (<i>Echium vulgare</i>), also called blue weed and by mistake, blue borage, occurs on roadsides, river-beds, and fields in both islands, though it is commoner in the south, and especially in Marlborough. It is an annual or biennial with a deep penetrating tap root and a stem 2 to 3 ft high.

Source:  Plants of NZ
Author:  LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page:  430
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Wahlenbergia  gracilis (The Graceful Blue-bell) ... W. albomarginata </i>has larger and more beautiful flowers, and is common in the hilly and sub-alpine districts of both islands. ... [431] <i>W. gracilis</i> is one of the commonest of flowers in dry situations on open plains, and grassy hill-sides. It might be described as the New Zealand blue-bell, except that the application of the term to a flower, which is more often white than blue, is scarcely appropriate.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1973

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Oxford Book of NZ Plants
Author:  MOORE & IRWIN
Vol / Page:  182
Edition:
Quote:  <i>DIANELLA NIGRA</i>. Turutu, blueberry, inkberry, or whistles thrives in lowland scrub, on clay banks, and along bush tracks. ... The reddish leaf-base leaves a yellow scar when broken ...; often it is folded into a tube so that skilful blowing can force air out in an ear-splitting whistle. Shining berries, ranging from palest grey to almost purple, or clean blue and white like old china, ripen in great numbers but they drop at a touch; ...

Notes:  1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 409

Date:  0/0/1970
Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author:  SORENSON
Vol / Page:  49
Edition:
Quote:  <I>TUNA</I> (3 species excluding Albacore) (a) Scientific name: (i) <I>Katsuwonus pelamis</I> (ii) <I>Thunnus maccoyi</I> (iii)<I> Thunnus albacares.</I> (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Skipjack Tuna (ii) Southern Bluefin Tuna (iii) Yellowfin Tuna. (c) Other common names: (i) Skipjack; Striped Bonito (ii) Bluefin Tuna; Southern Bluefin; Southern Tuna (iii) Yellowfin All sometimes referred to as Tunny. (d) Principal localities where taken: (i) A summewr visitor to New Zealand ... (ii) Southern Bluefin Tuna is a large species of temperate Australasian seas and migrates south to Foveaux Strait in summer months. (iii) A widely distributed tropical species which ranges into northern waters ... in summer months.
Notes:

tuna, bluefin 2099-100, 2108

Quote:  <i>G.[irella]. cyanea </i>..., the handsome bluefish, is bright blue above, paler below, with a sprinkling of golden specks; lives and ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Fisherman's Bible
Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  34
Edition:
Quote:  BLUEFISH <i>Girella cyanea</i>: A pretty, violet-blue fish with gold flecks the Bluefish inhabits our more northern waters usually around off-shore islands and rocky headlands. It is a close relative of the Australian drummer and luderick. The Maori name of `korokoropounamu' is still heard in some remote areas.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collins Guide
Author:  AYLING
Vol / Page:  229
Edition:  1984
Quote:  <i>BLUEFISH</i> (Blue drummer, korokoropounamu) <i>Girella cyanea</i>... As the name suggests their body colour is a uniform bright blue and all the fins are a similar colour.

bluefish
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 5
Definition:  ? Girella spp; ?=parore, or other Girellas; ?=blue maomao.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1892
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  24/210
Edition:
Quote:   From Cape Maria van Diemen a number of fish termed `blue-fish' are recorded. The same returns also record rock-cod. I am quite unable to suggest what fish is meant by `blue-fish,' unless, indeed, the observer has used the names indiscriminately. These fish were very numerous, were taken during every month of the year, and fed chiefly on mussel, but occasionally on small fish. They weighed from 1lb to 2lb each.
Notes:  (Thomson)

Quote:  The custom of tattooing is now falling out of fashion amongst the rising generation of both sexes, and it is to be hoped that before many years have passed, the nickname of `Blue-lips' will no longer be applicable to the native girls of New Zealand. Where the tattooing is confined to the slender lyre-shaped line on the fair one's chin, the effect is really not unpleasing; but the tattooed lip is an abomination.

They were small and good to eat and were numerous there. The old chief at Blueskin Bay was very blue in his tattoo; ...

bluestone
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a volcanic rock used in buildings, particularly in Otago; a basaltic rock used for road metal and (esp. rubble) building material (cf greenstone).
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  10/12/1988
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  94
Edition:
Quote:  Perhaps most truly characteristic of the city [sc. Dunedin] is the "bluestone". a class of volcanic rock used for the basements of main buildings (Knox, Bishopscourt), coarsely hammer-dressed because it was too hard for fine dressing.
Notes:  See also Knight & Wales : <i>Buildings of Dunedin</i> 1988

blue-wattled crow
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: The two spp. also attract the occas. names C. wilsoni, blue (-wattled), North Island crow; <i>C. cinerea, </i>orange-wattled, South Island, (occas. early) yellow-wattled crow.

Date:  0/0/1946
Source:  Journal of the Polynesian Society
Author:
Vol / Page:  55/144
Edition:
Quote:  <i>ko[o]kako</i>, two birds (Callaeas wilsoni - North Island, and C. cinereous[sic] - South Island), blue-wattled crow and orange-wattled crow, the colour of the wattles being the only difference; nearly if not quite extinct: this is the bird to which the echoic name bell-bird was first applied.
Notes:  Andersen Maori Words in English

Date:  0/0/1947
Source:  Native Animals of NZ
Author:  POWELL
Vol / Page:  87
Edition:
Quote:  BLUE-WATTLED CROW (<i>Callaeas wilsoni</i>). A moderately large dark bluish grey bird with a stout black bill, ... and conspicuous wattles of bright blue. The South Island species, <i>C. cinerea</i>, is almost identical except for the wattles, which are orange ... The Orange-wattled crow is still plentiful ... The Maori name for both <i>species </i>is Kokako.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1961
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  242
Edition:
Quote:  <i>blue-wattled crow n</i> : a passerine bird (<i>Callaeas wilsoni</i>) of New Zealand that resembles a starling
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Author:
Vol / Page:  303
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Kokako Callaeas cinerea</i> (GMELIN, 1788) ... <i>North Island Kokako C.c. wilsoni</i> (BONAPARTE, 1851).<i> South Island Kokako C.c. cinerea </i>(GMELIN, 1788). OTHER NAMES: <i>Blue wattled crow, blue gill, orange wattled crow, organ bird. </I>
Notes:

bluey
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a swagger's pack; 1. See swag (from colour of blanket wrapping a rolled swag). 2. (informal) a summons to court, especially a traffic offence notice (from former colour of paper). 3. (plural) workmen's blue overalls. 4. (nickname for) a red-headed person. =swag.

Quote:  <i>Bluff.</i>-Used in some parts as meaning, to drive sheep over a <i>b</i>., in others as meaning, `to get stuck in a <i>b.'</i>

Date:  0/0/1953
Source:  Musterer on Molesworth
Author:  STRONACH
Vol / Page:  40
Edition:
Quote:  But we got through, though one man had bad luck bluffing twenty sheep. They all ran out on to a rocky ledge, and we could see that to go near them meant that they would follow each other - like sheep - over the edge. .h;.us; [cf. OED2a. 1 b. Of a shore or coast-line: `Presenting a bold and almost perpendicular front, rather rounded than cliffy in outline.' 1658.]

Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: [high country mustering] a sheer rocky vertical face, upon which sheep, dogs and musterers can be trapped.

The word most recently appeared in an e-mail suggesting Clark apologise to deadwood MPs for "the injustice and mental abuse served up to us by the National Party". If she does, the missive says, "then we can boag Boag."

Vol / Page:  26

Quote:  He turned to the Maori. `You remember me, Joe? I've lost a few quid up at your place. On the board. On Saturday. Remember, eh?' <i>Ibid </I> 30 Joe's done me some good turns. He runs a crown-and-anchor game down in McLagan Street.
Notes:  [Dunedin pub] c1962 Baxter Horse (1985) (Name and the Game) 26

board
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a shearing floor, a killing floor of a freezing works;  the area in a woolshed used for shearing on; or the working floor of a freezing works; occas. the complement of shearers at work, cf all aboard, clear the board, shearing board

(usu. constr. with the, and sometimes pl the boards).

Register:
Register 2:

Date:  0/0/1945
Source:  NZ Geographer
Author:
Vol / Page:  1/39
Edition:
Quote:  `Press' and `sweep' are technical terms for necessary operations in the woolshed at shearing time. The former refers to pressing the fleeces into tight-packed bales ... to facilitate the transport of an otherwise bulky commodity. The latter is the process of keeping the floor (the `boards'), on which the sheep are shorn, clear of loose ends of wool, dirt and excrement.
Notes:  (Pascoe `Canterbury High Country') [is ths a true pl: or an error on writer's part]

board
Homonym Number:  3
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: of various statutory administrative boards
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1963
Source:  In the Sticks
Author:  BACON
Vol / Page:  180
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Board, Education</i>-New Zealand State Schools are administered by one or other of ten Education Boards, who make teaching appointments for all schools in their respective areas. Teachers are graded following inspection visits, and according to the Inspector's assessment, are given `grading marks'. In applying for a position, a teacher quotes his mark, the vacancy being filled by the highest graded applicant. Local parents elect School Committees bi-annually. Committee has no say in curriculum, etc., but is, in effect, a caretaking body.
Notes:

Date:  17/5/1951
Source:  Personal Communication
Author:  GORDON
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The <i>department-boss</i> is in charge of the <i>board-walkers </i>often promoted from the ranks, who are in charge of the chain etc.; they vary the speed the speed of the drive on the chain, which is done by a chain hanging down, giving rise to cries `Give it a pull' (i.e., speed it up) or `Pull it back' (slow down). If some are tired and he speeds it up, there are cries of `Get out you whip!' or `Bring your whip tomorrow!'. If the men are very tired to the point of <i>mutton-staggers</i> there will be cries of `Give him a drink of water.', and responses `But he had water yesterday'.

boarfish
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: applied to various dissimilar fishes which have projecting snouts
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1956
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  GRAHAM
Vol / Page:  407
Edition:
Quote:  Boarfish <i>Paristiopterus labiosus</i>(Gunther)
Notes:  1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 407

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  Animals of NZ, The
Author:  NATUSCH
Vol / Page:  222
Edition:
Quote:  Family HISTIOPTERIDAE. The histiopterids ... supposed to be a delicacy, are rare, In the common boarfish, <i>Paristiopterus</i>(not really common, but perhaps less rare than other kinds), the sexes are markedly different. The long-finned boarfish (<i>Zanclisteus</i>) rather resembles the tropical angel fish of aquariums; very rare indeed is the Nelson boarfish, <i>Griffinetta nelsonensis</i>, collected once from its nameplace, and once from the Chathams.
Notes:

Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish

Edition:
Quote:  <i>SOWFISH - Paristiopterus labiosus</i>, also known as Boarfish. Taken occasionally in the north and as far south as Cook Strait.

Author:  WILSON
Vol / Page:  35
Edition:
Quote:  BOARFISH <i>Histiopteridae</i>: Spiny-finned, deep-bodied family of fish characterised by small, rough scales and a protruding snout. There are three species found in New Zealand waters.

boarfish
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2

Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Date:  0/0/1872
Source:  Edible Fishes
Author:  HECTOR
Vol / Page:  112
Edition:
Quote:  The term Boar Fish (<i>Cyttus australis</i> ) has been applied to the fish of which several specimens were cast up on the shore of Cook Strait during the south-east gale of November last.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1886
Source:  Handbook Fishes of NZ
Author:  SHERRIN
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  BOAR FISH (<i>Cyttus Australis</i> ). ... The term boar fish has been applied to fish of which several specimens were cast up on the shores of Cook Strait. They resemble the Dory somewhat in form and size, but are easily distinguished by the rough skin and the absence of the round black spot on the side.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Merriam-Webster Third International
Author:
Vol / Page:  2018
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Boar&#769;.fish&#769;</i>. (b&omacr.r&#769;.f&ibreve.sh&#769;.),<i> n. [Add.] (c) </i>A fish (<i>Cyttus australis</i> ) of the family <i>Cyttidae. [New Zealand]</i> See <i>Bastard dory</i>, under DORY.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1898
Source:  Austral English
Author:  MORRIS
Vol / Page:  40
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Boar-fish</i> ... a name applied in England to various dissimilar fishes which have projecting snouts. (`Century.') In New Zealand it is given to <i>Cyttus australis</i> , family <i>Cyttidae</i>, which is related to the <i>John Dory</i> (q.v.).

Vol / Page:  1/317
Edition:
Quote:  The <i>boat-steerer </i>pulls the oar nearest the bow of the boat, fastens the whale with the harpoon, and takes his name from having to steer the boat under the headsman's directions while the latter kills the whale.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1905
Source:  Where the White Man Treads
Author:  BAUCKE
Vol / Page:  75
Edition:
Quote:  An old-time bay whaling station consisted ... of at least two boats, with their crew of six men each. The headsman, or mate, four ordinary oarsmen, and the harpooner, or `boat-steerer,' who pulled the bow-oar, and drove in the harpoon, and who, when the whale had been struck and `fastened on,' went aft and steered the boat, while the mate took his place, and by repeated lance-thrusts killed it.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1985

bob
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: orig. worms threaded and coiled (see cit. 1967), but also meat, bacon, etc. held in a tangle of twine or shredded flax-blade, attached to a line, for catching eels.

This was fastened with flax to a strong stick about six feet long. [early 20C.] We went down to the river about dusk, each of us with a rod, ... our bobs suspended in a deep pool.

Edition:
Quote:  The manner most frequently adopted for catching eels, called 'bobbing".., is primitive enough, and is by means of a line formed of narrow strips of flax leaves, to the end of which is tied a bundle of earth worms. The eels bolt the "bob" and are readily pulled out of the water.

bob
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: (where [x] is a gradient from 1 to 19) transf. uses and fig. senses (often graded between 1 and 19) to express various conditions of alleged intellectual handicap, mental bankruptcy, on the part of the addressee, implying that the person is not all there: see also shilling, quid [brief entry only at pound].

bobby calf
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an unweaned, usually male, calf for slaughter; a calf to be slaughtered when over 4 days old fed solely on whole milk, defined as under 45.5 kg live weight with carcasses of not less than 9.98 kg.

Date:  0/0/1939
Source:  Sketches from Maoriland
Author:  GRIEVE
Vol / Page:  133fn
Edition:  1961
Quote:  It should ... be explained that `bobby calves' are the unwanted bull-calves which the farmers part with for a few pence. Buyers canvas the districts and collect the animals, so that it is quite a common sight to see a boarded-up motor-lorry speeding along the road with a cargo of `bobby calves'.
Notes:

Date:  26/7/1928
Source:  Auckland Weekly News
Author:
Vol / Page:  58/3
Edition:
Quote:  [OED2] 30,000 bobby calves, mostly from the Waikato, were exported ... last season as boneless veal.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author:  TURNER
Vol / Page:  150
Edition:
Quote:  Calves not kept for the herd become <i>bobby calves</i>, a truly standard word since it was defined in the <i>Bobby Calf Marketing Regulations</i> in the New Zealand Statutory Regulations, 1938: `Bobby calf' means a calf which is intended for slaughter for human consumption as boneless veal.' The origin and dating of the word are doubtful. There is a similar word poddy calf for a hand-fed calf, recorded in Australia from last century. The present New Zealand meaning seems to have arisen about 1929. The Christchurch Times, 17 August 1929, reported: `During the last year or so quite a trade has grown up in young, or `bobby' calves, which are taken in by the freezing works, killed and exported.' The term <i>vealer</i> is also used.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  MAF Agricultural Glossary
Author:
Vol / Page:  19
Edition:
Quote:  ~ Calf to be slaughtered when over 4 days old that has been fed solely on whole milk. The stomach (vel) provides rennet that is used as a coagulant in cheese making. They are calves defined as under 45.5 kg live weight with carcasses of not less than 9.98 kg.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1938

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1936
Source:  Agricultural Organization in NZ
Author:  470
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Prior to the season 1927-28, it was customary to kill all surplus calves on the farm, and dispose of their skins only. The trade, which is known locally as `The Bobby Calf' trade, developed during that season, and has extended rapidly each year since. Under this system of disposal, calves are collected by motor lorry and delivered at freezing-works, where they are slaughtered and packed as boneless veal.
Notes:

bobby-dazzler
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a good or amazing person or thing (mainly children's). 1. Anything fine, superior, or outstanding of its kind; ironically, an `eccentric, curious (person)'; corker

bob-in
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Often `have a bob-in', a bar-room drinking system whereby one pays a shilling (more or less) into a round of drinks, so that one can withdraw from the school when the money is cut out.

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  G'day Country
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  61
Edition:
Quote:  Another time she went to the outhouse and sat on a hedgehog and kicked up bobsy-die, ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  17
Edition:
Quote:  <i>bobsy-die</i> fuss or fun; common phr. `kicking up bobsy-die'; ironic C18 English nautical almost rhyming `bob's-a-dying/idling' underwent sea change to NZ C19, possibly picking up `bobbery' or shindy, from Hindi `bapre'. Ngaio Marsh used original in <i>

Surfeit of Lampreys</i>: `If she's right ... it plays Bobs-a-dying with the whole blooming case.' NZA.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1960
Source:  Kings of Rugby
Author:  McLEAN
Vol / Page:  vii/50
Edition:
Quote:  By generally kicking up bobsy-die.
Notes:  (OEDS)

peculiar to the middle 20th Century, but

the characteristics are not... In the

under-privileged masses the counterparts

of Bodgies were variously styled as

'yahoos', 'larrikins', 'hooligans' and

'yobs'. The 'playboy' of upper class

society is the "Bodgie" of the poor.

Date:  28/11/2000
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  A stereotypical bogan or "westie" is a male clad in black jeans and black T-shirt embellished with the name of a heavy metal band. Females of this genus are normally found wearing ill-fitting jeans and lace blouses or velvet dresses and an optional speckled leather jacket.  The bogan car of choice is Holden and the more grunt the better. Fluffy dice are mandatory and not optional. The bogan drink of choice is Lion Red and preferably from a crate. Bogan pastimes usually involve their car and ranged from drag racing down residential streets to peel-out sessions in vacant lots.

boil down
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: to dispose of unwanted sheep by cooking them and selling the tallow, especially prior to refrigeration of meat for export in 1882.

There is a boiling-down works at Featherston, ... where thousands of these large fat sheep ... are boiled down.

Date:  0/0/1964
Source:  Life on a Five Pound Note
Author:  HOSKEN
Vol / Page:  34
Edition:
Quote:  One day, a resident of the Mackenzie Country, when travelling in a dray on the Braemar Road, overtook a young swagger. `Throw your swag up, and get in,' he remarked, `and we'll boil the billy soon.' But this young Englishman, a stranger to New Zealand and its ways, not knowing what `boiling the billy' meant and mistrustful of his friend's rather wild and unshaven appearance, refused the kind offer and decided to push on.

Quote:  This boundary was always debatable ground - it was always imperatively necessary that claims should be `pegged out', and this rule was of necessity `more honoured in the breach than in the observance.' Pegs were not to be had, unless imported, and when introduced stood a great chance of helping to boil the neighbour's `billy'.'

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1945
Source:  If You'd Care to Know
Author:  SIMPSON
Vol / Page:  99
Edition:
Quote:  Before the real Australian guides you out of the bush, he will probably halt at some place where there is water and say, `How about boiling the billy?' In saying that he is not asking you for a cigarette, a pipe of tobacco, a chew of gum. ... He is simply extending to you the original and (I hope) the everlasting hospitality of all Australia; he is suggesting that he make a brew of tea.
Notes:

boil the billy
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:  1
Definition: [shepherding, mustering and hunting] [originally] to light a fire and heat water for tea; [recently] to have a cup of tea/coffee.

boiling down
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the process of, or tanks for, boiling down sheep carcasses to extract tallow.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1861
Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author:  HURSTHOUSE
Vol / Page:  374
Edition:
Quote:   `Boiling-down' was formerly practised to a considerable extent in Australia; the mere fat or tallow of the animal for export to England <i>being worth far more than the meat for colonial consumption</i>. `Boiling-down establishments' were formed in the pastoral districts, and the process became a regular business. The sheep or cattle were killed and skinned, the carcass thrown into the boiling vat, the fat skimmed off for export tallow, and the meat thrown away. `Boiling down' will probably remain a permanent feature of Australian grazing in the districts remote from large towns.
Notes:

Date:  25/5/1870
Source:  Diary
Author:  BENMORE
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  On 25 may, B.D. started on benmore; boiling down, like other unpleasant things, was usually known by its initials.
Notes:  >[1870 May 25 Benmore diary] in 1981 Pinney Early Northern Otago Runs 24

Jock Graham did a roaring trade in Dunedin by purchasing carrots in the Taieri and tying three of them to a hind leg of a sheep. This was known as a fiddle and he would hawk them through the streets and dispose of them for sixpence.
