bolter
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an unexpected selection
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Sport
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:	J Boon (jboon@unitec.ac.nz) suggests this comes from the phrase "bolt from the blue". Trish Ryan (dentrish@clear.net.nz) says it comes from "infamous horse betting circles. Back before the days of judicial videos, race results were sometimes 'pre-arranged'. The backed horse would be given the perfect run in behind a nominated pacemaker. Other horses would be ridden into deadend passages or taken wide in the run home. Occasionally an uncooperative pacemaking horse would 'bolt' on its jockey and win the race - and lose large betting plunges that had been made on the intended victor." >Google search showed in used in Australia also and to a lesser degree also UK, the Netherlands

bomb-squasher
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: also bum-squasher
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1974
Source:  NZ Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  188
Edition:
Quote:  Culled dairy cows and culled beef animals are sent directly to the works as `boners' - that is, the bones are removed from the carcasses and the meat is used for manufactured products (as distinct from meat that is used for prime cuts). Farmers are paid schedule rates on the killing weights.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1972
Source:  Folkgames of Children
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  174
Edition:
Quote:  Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1984
Source:  NZ Yesterdays
Author:  KEITH & MAIN
Vol / Page:  288
Edition:
Quote:  Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1989
Source:  Dinkum Kiwi Dictionary, The
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>bomb-squasher</i> big marble, a menace to small marbles.

boneseed
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  20/9/2000
Source:  Norwester
Author:
Vol / Page:  8
Edition:
Quote:  An effective treatment that uses no herbicide has been found to control the coastal pest plant boneseed, says the Wellington Regional Council. Boneseed is flowering now, the best time for control... Boneseed is widely established throughout the coastal areas of the Wellington region, especially Wellington's south coast, Eastbourne, Pukerua Bay and Raumati... Boneseed produces clusters of small, yellow daisy flowers that cover the plant in late winter to early summer. The single-seed is very hard and bone-like in colour and texture when ripe (thus the name boneseed. Boneseed is a bushy shrub which grows to 2-3 metres high producing up to 50,000 seeds per plant. From South Africa, it was introduced to New Zealand as an ornamental plant and is now found throughout the North Island, mostly in coastal situations, and in the South Island.

Notes:

bong
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  13/3/1988
Source:  Dominion Sunday Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  He writes about five young men who went on a week-long camping holiday ... taking with them a car-load of beer and a curious collection of plastic tubing and large funnels; the equipment needed for alcohol bonging: ... The bong comprises a plastic funnel joined at the base by a long plastic tube, it can be large or small. It can hold from one to four bottles of beer. One person holds the contraption high in the air while the intended recipient puts the end of the tube in his mouth and allows the beer to rush in a torrent into his stomach. ... Four bottles is said to test the digestive system to the limit and is almost impossible to keep down and so usually leads to what is called a `power chunder' or projectile vomiting.
Notes:

bonies
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1972
Source:  Folkgames of Children
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  174
Edition:
Quote:  Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1984
Source:  NZ Yesterdays
Author:  KEITH & MAIN
Vol / Page:  288
Edition:
Quote:  Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles.
Notes:

Author:  SORENSON

Edition:
Quote:  <i>BONITA</i> - Two fish species are taken in small quantities, Ray's Bream (<i>Brama raii</i>) and, chiefly in Cook Strait, <i>Hyperoglyphe porosa</i>. Both are commonly called Bonita or Bream and usually marketed as Groper. The common name Bonita is not to be confused with Bonito which is Skipjack Tuna, (<i>Katsuwonus pelamis</i>).

Vol / Page:  267
Edition:
Quote:  BONITO Offshore anglers use bonito fillets for snapper bait and deep-sea anglers claim its dark-red flesh attracts almost every sporting fish up to shark and marlin. It is known as Mackerel, Horse Mackerel, Skippy, Skipper and Skipjack because of its habit of breaking the surface when feeding. The name `Skipjack' has also been applied however to at least half-a-dozen other species.

Quote:  <i>TUNA</i> (3 species excluding Albacore) (a) Scientific name: (i) <i>Katsuwonus pelamis </i>(ii) <i>Thunnus maccoyi </i> (iii) <i>Thunnus albacores </i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Skipjack Tuna (ii) Southern Bluefin Tuna (iii) Yellowfin Tuna. (c) Other common names: (i) Skipjack; Striped Bonito (ii) Bluefin Tuna; Southern Bluefin; Southern Tuna (iii) Yellowfin All sometimes referred to as Tunny. (d) Principal localities where taken: (i) A summer visitor to New Zealand ... (ii) Southern Bluefin Tuna is a large species of temperate Australasian seas and migrates south to Foveaux Strait in summer months. (iii) A widely distributed tropical species which ranges into northern waters ... in summer months.

bonito
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: Sarda chiliensis.


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1927
Source:  Natural History of Canterbury
Author:  SPEIGHT
Vol / Page:  199
Edition:
Quote:  The only true mackerels recorded from Canterbury are the Pacific Bonito (<i>Sarda chiliensis </i>) and the large-scaled Tunny (<i>Gasterochisma melampus </i>) which may reach a length of 6 feet; but a related family includes the well-known Barracouta (<i>Thyrsites atun </i>), the King Barracouta, <i>Jordanidia solandrii </i> (often known locally as Kingfish, but not to be confused with the North Island Kingfish which is a form or Yellowtail) and the elongated, silvery-hued frost fish (<i>Lepidopus caudatus </i>) whose curious stranding habits can hardly yet be said to be satisfactorily explained.
Notes:  1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 199

Citations
Date:  30/10/2005
Source:  Sunday Star Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  A5
Edition:
Quote:  Beyond the case of Club 574, they placed particular emphasis on the rights of small owner-operated brothels, or Soobs, and so the obvious joke here is that big owner-operated brothels must henceforth be known as Boobs. Club 574 is a Boob - it contracts 45 sex workers. As for the Soobs, which are typically 2 or 3 women whoring out of private homes throughout the Auckland suburbs, the city council argues they could move into the city, where there are 9500 apartment units or, more to the point, 12,000 bedrooms.

Quote:  [species name] stargazer .. [scientific name] <i>Kathetostoma giganteum</i> .. [other name(s)] monkfish, boofs, bulldogs, churchills, flathead monk, giant stargazer, monks, muddies, spotted stargazer, toebiters, whitefish, sandcod
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  PAUL
Vol / Page:  118
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Monkfish Kathetotoma giganteum</i> ... Also occurs in southern Australia. Known by a number of local names: giant stargazer, flathead, bulldog, boof, etc. The name monkfish is well established for this species in New Zealand, whereas overseas it is used for similarly shaped but unrelated anglerfishes.

boohai
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a remote place or district;  the backblocks

[perhaps from North Auckland township of Puhoi]; up the boohai: confused, wrong, messy
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: cf. backblocks, bush, cactus, wo(o)p-wo(o)ps.
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  8/4/2004
Source:  Wellington Contact
Author:
Vol / Page:  38
Edition:
Quote:  Arthritis in the hands forced Titahi Bay artist Kerry Moore to 'paint' with words, and it has resulted in his first novel, <i>The Boo-Eye</i>. Set in 1950s New Zealand, in a town "10 miles from nowhere". (or in other words, in the boo-eye), three young men go on an odyssey of discovery that is both tragic and triumphant.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1980

Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  <i>boohai:</i> country esp. remote areas <i>up the boohai</i>: in error, in confusion


Notes:   (Goldie Brown Collection)

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  18
Edition:
Quote:  <i>boohai/boo-ay/boo-eye</i> remote area; ... <i>up the boohai</i> to be lost or to have got something quite wrong, a nod perhaps at `puhoi', Maori for dull, slow, phlegmatic;  3. in elaborations emphasising distance, or distancing attempts by the speaker.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Through the Looking Glass
Author:  MEIKLE
Vol / Page:  126
Edition:
Quote:   Of the boys' funny sayings [in the 1930s] two live on in my memory. ... And if he was asked where he was going, he would answer: `Up the boo-ai in a matchbox hunting pukakers [pukekos] with a long-handled shovel.'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:
Vol / Page:  18
Edition:
Quote:  <i>up the boohai - shooting pukakas</i> (pukekos) an amusing extension of notion of being lost, possibly in the head, Sue Budd recalls. Grant Tilly recalls its completion: <i>up the boohai shooting pukakas with a popgun</i>. `Boohai' c.1920.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
Author:  McLINTOCK
Vol / Page:  2/678
Edition:
Quote:  Some slang terms seems to be peculiar to certain districts. An example is the Auckland term <i>up the Puhoi</i> or <i>Boohoy</i> (its form varies a good deal) meaning `gone somewhere or other' and this is a genuine local product referring to an old German settlement on the coast north of Auckland and little, if at all, in use elsewhere in New Zealand. <i>Ibid.</i> 2/680 Examples of slang and colloquial expressions of local origin are ...<i> up the boohai</i> (and other forms) for `off in some unknown locality', an Aucklander's idiom. [Wall does not seem to completely relate these two statements]
Notes:  (Wall, NZ Speech)

Date:  0/0/1980
Source:  Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A
Author:  LELAND
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  <i>booeye:</i> So far OUT IN THE COUNTRY, mountains, or woods that carrier pigeons lose their way trying to find the nearest town.

Notes:

Date:  1/3/1986
Source:  NZ Herald
Author:
Vol / Page:  1
Edition:
Quote:  The oldest son, John, left Puhoi when he was 16 to settle in Auckland. He found a job as a grocer's boy, and played the fiddle at night to pay his board. In 1907 he founded the National Trading Co in Customs St. `The expression `up the Buhoi' was said to have originated with him because when he was asked where he came from, that was what he replied in his strong accent - the same pronunciation of the name of our village can still be heard in Puhoi today,' said Mrs Williams.
Notes:  (Schischka)

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Fools on the Hill, The
Author:  LAY
Vol / Page:  220
Edition:
Quote:  Living in a shack in the middle of the boo-ai with a load of strangers, doing the washing by hand under a tilly lamp? .bf text; b. way to boohai , intensifying remoteness or distance.

cf. <i>way to blazes. </i>
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Speaking a Silence
Author:  HUNT
Vol / Page:  88
Edition:

book
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition:  to fold sealskins into layers like the leaves of books
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1940
Source:  Rakiura
Author:  HOWARD
Vol / Page:  40
Edition:
Quote:  Incoming skins are sorted to arbitrary standards - wigs (old males), clap-matches (females), bulls, yearlings, grey or silver pups (under one year), black pups. If the cargo is intended for the European or American market, the skins are removed from the animal with an inch of blubber adhering, and in the final simple treatment are washed, heavily slated, and then folded or `booked' into rectangular shape for packing. Skins destined for China, however, are treated with more preliminary care. They are taken as cleanly as possible, and after careful washing are sent to the `beamer' to be thoroughly scraped free of the last remaining particles of flesh and blubber.
Notes:

boom
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a timber-boom across a river, etc. to retain floating logs.


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1874
Source:  Edward Crewe
Author:  BAINES
Vol / Page:  177
Edition:
Quote:  It is nine miles from the dam to the `boom' at the mouth of the creek.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1894
Source:  NZ Official Yearbook
Author:
Vol / Page:  365
Edition:
Quote:  At the mouths of streams a line of floating [kauri] logs have been previously fastened together with iron `dogs' and short chains; this is called a `boom', and prevents the timber getting away to sea. The logs are then fastened together in rafts, and, guided by men armed with long poles shod with iron (called rafting-spears), are conveyed to the mills, ...
Notes:  (E. Tregear: Labour in NZ)

Date:  0/0/1907
Source:  Plants of NZ
Author:  LAING & BLACKWELL
Vol / Page:  62
Edition:  1940, p. 63
Quote:  Here [the felled kauri trees] lie until a `fresh' drives them down to the creek or harbour where the `boom' lies waiting. This boom is formed of a circle of logs fastened together with chains. There may be as many as fifty logs forming the chain, which sometimes encloses acres of water. The logs enter the boom, - are fastened together into a kind of raft, and towed to their destination.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1930
Source:  Fifty Years In Maoriland
Author:  PINFOLD
Vol / Page:  60
Edition:
Quote:   On his return [from Upper Thames] he took us to what were called `The Booms'. These were great logs of wood driven into the ground across the mouth of a river that opened out toward the sea. The bushmen ... felled the trees. Afterwards, when a good rain came and flooded the river, the `logs' would come down, and the `booms' were expected to stop them from going out to sea.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1920
Source:  Story of a NZ River, The
Author:  MANDER
Vol / Page:  198
Edition:  1960
Quote:   They watched the progress of the log from the booms up the skids to the side of the breakdown platform... Halved and quartered, it was then levered ... on to greased rollers and rushed towards the big circulars, which turned it into flitches. Then the small circulars, the drag, and the goose completed its metamorphosis into the regulation strips ...
Notes:

Sense Number:  1

Quote:  VIPER'S BUGLOSS (<I>Echium vulgare</I> ), also called blue weed and by mistake, blue borage, occurs on roadsides, river-beds, and fields in both islands, though it is commoner in the south, and especially in Marlborough. It is an annual or biennial with a deep penetrating tap root root and a stem 2 to 3 ft high.

Quote:  ... drives were broken off at right angles to [the dip heading] at distances of two chains apart ; thus forming pillars on either side of the dip, two chains square. These drives were called main levels. The bords were driven about two chains off the dip, and the `stenton' would be driven from the lower level to the one above.

bord and pillar
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1905
Source:  NZ Mining Handbook
Author:
Vol / Page:  417
Edition:
Quote:  The system of work [in the Grey coalfield] is mainly by bord and pillar, a small portion only of this coal having been worked by the longwall method. In the bord-and-pillar system the bords are 18ft. wide, and pillars 14 yards thick. The pillars are left intact until the boundary of a section is reached, when they are worked back. The roof has in [418] main proved good, enabling a large percentage of the pillar-coal to be won.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1958
Source:  Farm Engineering
Author:  RIDDOLLS
Vol / Page:  187
Edition:
Quote:  Border-ditch Irrigation. Where the fall of the land is too steep or the surface is too irregular for using the border-dyke method, or where it is not too desired to plough up the pasture, ditches are constructed over the area to be irrigated and the water is caused to flood over from the ditches. These ditches are called border ditches ...
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1958
Source:  Farm Engineering
Author:  RIDDOLLS
Vol / Page:  188
Edition:
Quote:  The border-ditch method is not as efficient as the border-dyke method in its use of water. [border ditch]

borrow-pit
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: before roads were macadamised, step-faggots [presumably as in `step(ping)-stones' HWO] were placed on one side of the road to form a footpath, and a barrow-ditch extended from and at right angles to the footpath into the road. These occurred at regular intervals, draining the surface water from the road, and also compelling carts, &c., to keep off the footpath (P.M.); Paid W. Masters for making 76 rods of Barrow ditch ... (Dec. 26, 1752). [no etym given: cf. barrow sb3 1. a hill; a heap of stones. [gen. dial. Cum to Ken and Cor]; DARE barrow ditch Also, by folk-etym. borrow ditch; rarely barrow [EDD ref.] Cf bar ditch1 1927-1973: barrow pit Also by folk-etym. borrow pit Prob, from barrow a mound of earth; for folk-etym. see quot1950 ... 1 rarely burrow pit: a roadside drainage ditch. Chiefly West, esp. Rocky Mts 1931-1973 Map shows mainly NW: 1950 quot explains folk etym: barrow `mound of earth formed when pit was dug'; barrow = `wheelbarrow'; borrow `a pit where dirt is borrowed to be used
in another.] 2 a place from which material for construction has been excavated and which, esp. in the Gulf states, often fills with water (1940-1968); cf OED2 sb1 4. dial. A mound or heap 1869, 1881 Raymond Mining Gloss. Barrow (Cornw.), a heap of attle or rubbish.]
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: borrow
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations

Source:  Men of the Milford Road
Author:  ANDERSON
Vol / Page:  53
Edition:
Quote:  Unfortunately the road at this point went `zag' and that is where we left it, and the Model A slid sideways into a ditch - or `borrow-pit' to use the correct roading term.
Notes:  (Griffiths Collection)

Date:  0/0/1986

Author:  OWEN & PERKINS
Vol / Page:  73
Edition:
Quote:  Anyhow, he generally wore - and this was another thing pretty common with the swagger - he generally wore a good hat. Riverina always had a borsalino ... [which] was looked upon as a sort of a prestige thing, you know. The brim was wider by far than the present-day brim, and it was one of the superior hats of the day. ... A borsalino, stetson - these were the hats that had a bit of class about them. It was similar in style to a stetson, but with a slightly smaller brim, but it was a class hat.

Borstal honey
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:

Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:

Notes: -
Citations
Date:  0/11/1953
Source:  Here & Now
Author:
Vol / Page:  41
Edition:
Quote:  Before you're unlocked you put some things in a small linen bag. A knife, some bread ... and a small bottle containing syrup or, if you've been lucky, Borstal honey - which is a mixture of syrup and animal fat pinched from the cookhouse. It's a pretty foul mixture, but it replaces butter, which is always short in gaol.
Notes:  (Hamilton)

boshee
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a Maori
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1957
Source:  Origins of the Maori Wars
Author:  SINCLAIR
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  But the attitude of the settlers was not wholly a product of their environment. To a large extent their prejudice was imported with them. Those who had encountered few Maoris, like the Otago and Canterbury settlers, were as biassed as the rest. The Maori was called `nigger',

`black', and in the <i>Auckland Examiner</i>, `Boshee' [subscript 44] by people who had never seen a slave. The word `Maori' conjured up in the settlers' minds a stereotype based on experience in other colonies. [fn44] Perhaps a mixture of `bosh' and `Quashee', a West Indian negro.
Notes:  [?1860s]

boss's boots

Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1987
Source:  Boards, Blades & Barebellies
Author:  OGONOWSKA-COATES
Vol / Page:  95
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Boss's boots</i>. Whenever the boss is sighted the shearers pass on the phrase `boss's boots' or `boots on the board' as a warning. Not only was the boss the only person in the shed to wear boots, but from the doubled-up position of the blade shearer working over a sheep, the boss's boots were the first thing he saw.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1955
Source:  Wool Away!
Author:  BOWEN
Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  Yet I believe that if a shearer does continually cut sheep in these places he shears less in a day, as he is mentally conscious of his shearing, looking for the `boss's boots.'<i>Ibid.</i> 155  BOSS'S BOOTS. This means what it says: it is the footwear a shearer watches out for.

bot
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: esp. a cold, the flu (esp. with coughing fits); catch, have the bot to become, feel unwell
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1941
Source:  NZ Slang
Author:  BAKER
Vol / Page:  51
Edition:
Quote:  Emerging originally from children's slang to bulk quite considerably in a grown-up world is the serviceable term <i>bot</i>. Its origin seems to be medical, since in early uses <i>bot</i> is rendered as a germ, doubtless from bot-fly. [52] From this comes the phrase of greeting, <i>How are the bots biting?</i> By the 1920s a <i>bot</i> is being used extensively for a troublesome person, for a persistent borrower, a financial parasite. By 1925 the noun <i>bot</i> was translated to a verb, and as a result we have <i>to bot,</i> to borrow money, to impose on others, and <i>botting</i>, the practice. <i>To bot on</i> a person is widely used. An interesting extension to the term is to be found in Australia, in which country<i> to bite</i> is often the equivalent for <i>bot</i>. On the other hand <i>cold botting</i> is a straight-out request for food at house-doors. ... Of fairly recent development in New Zealand is the phrase<i> to have the bot</i>, to be sick or out of sorts, moody or disagreeable.
par
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1949
Source:  Dictionary of Slang Addenda
Author:  PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page:  997
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Bot, have the</i>. To feel unwell: to be moody: querulous: NZ: since ca1930, B1941. Ex bot n2 (<i>Dict</i>)
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1968
Source:  Pagan Game, The
Author:  SLATTER
Vol / Page:  144
Edition:
Quote:  And if you have a good rub down and wrap up warm after, nobody will catch the bot.
Notes:

Date:  20/7/1986
Source:  Sunday Star (Auckland)
Author:
Vol / Page:  B10
Edition:
Quote:  After complaining of Scott-Base-like conditions at last week's Auckland club footie, old Loosehead has come down with a spot of the bot and his regular Sunday Star column will take a week's rest with the joker himself.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary
Author:
Vol / Page:  81
Edition:
Quote:  <i>bot n. NZ & Austral. sl. 1. n</i>. scrounger, cadger; unspecified minor ailment (<i>have the bot). 2. v.i. bot on cadge from, impose on. [orig. = parasitic worm, f. LG] </i>
Notes:   [cf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict. 125]

bot

Sense Number: 3
Definition: a smalltime financial parasite, a cadger, a bludger.

Edition:
Quote:  By the 1920s a <i>bot </i> is being used extensively for a troublesome person, for a persistent borrower, a financial parasite. By 1925 the noun <i>bot</i> was translated to a verb, and as a result we have <i>to bot,</i> to borrow money, to impose on others, and <i>botting,</i> the the practice. <i>To bot on</i> a person is widely used.

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  19
Edition:
Quote:  <i>bot </i>a germ, originally in 1920s a TB patient, latterly a minor ailment, usually cold or flu; probably derived from the botfly, whose larvae feed beneath the skin, an afflicter of horses. - <i>to have the bot</i> to feel unwell or irritable. - <i>how're the bots biting? a humorous greeting. - <i>on the bot</i> to cadge. NZA.
Notes:

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1937
Source:  Dictionary of Slang
Author:  PARTRIDGE
Vol / Page:  83
Edition:
Quote:  Bot. See bot-fly. 2. A germ: New Zealand medical: from ca1928. Perhaps ex the bot(-fly), which, in horses, lays eggs that are said to penetrate into the animal when they hatch. 3. Hence, a tubercular patient: id: from ca1929. Cf <i>bots biting,</i> q.v. <i>bot-fly</i>. A troublesome, interfering person: Australian: C.20. In G.W. +, often abbr. to <i>bot. </i>
Notes:

Date:  4/11/1992
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  2
Edition:
Quote:  He had been feeling "a bit nauseous, hot and crabby" after taking antibiotics for "a bit of the bot."
Notes:

bottle-brand

bottlebrush
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an Aust. shrub with dense, coloured flower heads consisting of stamens all around the stem; usu. in NZ applied to the introduced Aust. genus Callistemon [or the Myrtaceae or Protaceae families] used as ornamentals, with brilliant red flowers reminiscent in shape to the brushes used to clean out (?orig. wine) bottles [cf the similar decriptive application to <i>pohutukawa</i>

Quote:  Great Shoals [295] of a cetaceous fish, whose nose was quite blunt & round as a bottle & the body slender, passed us; our Sailors called them <i>bottlenoses</i> but the[y] were not what Dale calls a <i>Bottlenose</i>, which is the <i>beaked Whale</i>: for this fish has no beak at all, was very slender, about 3 yards long, quite black & all had a white spot before the dorsal fin. [fn] The Bottle-head or Flounder's Head in Dale, <i>History and Antiquities of Harwich</i> ... (London, 1730), p.411, ... is the Bottle-nosed whale (<i>Hyperoodon ampullatus</i>), a species named by Forster in a footnote ...

bottles

Date:  13/3/1988
Source:  Dominion Sunday Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  Other well-known [drinking] games are Hokonui Swindle, Bottles, Fluffy Ducks, Bunnies are Hovering, Cardinal Huff, All Blacks, Matches, and The Amazing Grimaldi Brothers. All these games involve either a complicated intellectual exercise, tongue twisters, mathematical calculations or aerobatics in a confined space; High Candelabras for example, involves intoxicated individuals attempting to traverse the four walls of a room without touching the floor.

Vol / Page:  174
Edition:
Quote:  Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, molly-bars, mulley-bars [mullibars: large marbles], peelies, peewees, piss-wees, pretties, Scotties, Scottish alleys, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers, white alleys, and in more recent years ball-bearings, chippies, plastics, and woodies. ...When I first went to school, bottlies were good currency, being classed as two-ers, but usually sodawaters and black-bottlies counted as the
equivalent of six-ers. ... (Petone, Wellington, 1913)


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1984
Source:  Yesterdays in Maoriland
Author:  KEITH & MAIN
Vol / Page:  288
Edition:
Quote:  Marbles were the currency of childhood and there were an astonishing number of names for them, some referring to the material or colour, others to value or function in the game. There were agates, aggies, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cats-eye, [sic] chinkies, connies, duckies, eggies, glassies, Greeks, milkies, mollies, peelies, peewees, pisswees, pretties, Scotties, smokies, stinkies, stonies, stripies, tom-bobblers and whities. The march of technology added ball bearings - ballies or steelies - which were unbeatable when it came to smashing an opponent's miserable glassie. World War II[roman] brought `clayeys' often imperfectly spherical they were pathetic terracotta substitutes for real marbles.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL

Edition:

Bouai
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: boohai
Pronunciation:
Notes: idiosyncratic spelling?
Citations
Date:  0/0/1945
Source:  If You'd Care to Know
Author:  Simpson
Vol / Page:  101
Edition:
Quote:  Another New Zealand expression is `Up the Bouai' (pronounced boo-eye). There was a place near Auckland city which many years ago was somewhat isolated, and it was called the Bouai. The word is not Maori, for there is no `b' and no `h' sound in the original Maori tongue. Once more I cannot tell you where the word came from, but to go `up the Bouai' has become fairly general in use. Today, if a person comes to town from any lonely place in the forests or mountains, and a friend asks him where he has been, most likely the answer will be, `Oh, I've been up the Bouai.' It is a general word for an isolated region.


Notes:

bouilli
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an old word for stewed meat preserved in a tin as a common fare in emigrant ships and early settlement; compare bully beef; bouilli tin; a usu. early 19C. spg of a usual emigrant commodity: tinned boiled or stewed meat, esp. beef (OED 17C.), often, as emigrant-ship, or

early colonial fare, `soup and bouilli'. Now usually<i> bully-beef</i>.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations

Author:  SAM STEPHENS

Edition:
Quote:  [Surveyor] Dinner off(?) preserved soup & bouilli.

boundary dog
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an old word for a dog chained permanently on the boundary of a sheep-run to prevent stock straying; a dog chained to a break in fence, or to a gateway, to prevent sheep from passing through; fence dog.
Origin: [none]
Register:

Notes:

Date:  16/9/1933
Source:  Press, The  (Acland Glossary)
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  Boundary keeper A shepherd who keeps sheep from passing an unfenced boundary. He goes along the boundary once or twice a day or, if he has a convenient lookout, watches the sheep all day. In the old days any boundary keepers lived on their boundaries all the year and never saw anyone, except at mustering or by chance. The Australian word `boundary rider' has never been used in New Zealand; in fact, a boundary rider's work is different. He looks after the fences and sheep in a large paddock. (C.)


Notes:  Acland Glossary

Vol / Page:  4
Edition:
Quote:  Captain Bollons has presented to Canterbury Museum a specimen of the Bounty Island shag, Phalacrocorax ranfurlyi, which he obtained on his recent trip to the southern island in the Hinemoa. .. The Bounty Island shag was named after Lord Ranfurly, and it is the last bird added to the list of birds of New Zealand, which, for all practical purposes, is now complete and closed.

bow
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:

Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  16/9/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Bow</i> (1) The bows are the curved parts at the top of the handle of a pair of sheep shears. They give the shears their spring open after the shearer has made his blow. All shears are now made with double bows; but until about the 'seventies single bows were the only kind. (2) The iron that holds the yoke to a bullock's neck (see <i>bullocks</i>). ([1890- 1910])
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Date:  0/0/1938
Source:  High Country
Author:  BURDON
Vol / Page:  84
Edition:
Quote:  The sheep they shore were not so well woolled on the belly and carried less wool on the points than they do now, so that fewer short blows were required to take off the trimmings; but the shears they used were one inch and a half shorter in the blade and, being joined by a single instead of a double bow, required a wrist of iron to drive them continuously throughout a summer's day. A piece of raw hide known as a knocker is now used to prevent the shears clashing when closed, but before this was introduced the clack and snap of steel meeting steel was a noise inseparable from any busy shearing shed.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1951
Source:  High Country
Author:  McLEOD
Vol / Page:  26
Edition:
Quote:  So most of us stick to `the blades,' the big shining steel shears eight and a half inches long, with a double spring `bow' on the end to keep them apart.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1987
Source:  Boards, Blades & Barebellies
Author:  OGONOWSKA-COATES
Vol / Page:  95
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Bow</i>. The curved top of the handle of the shears which incorporates the spring. Until the late 1870s shears were made with only one bow and the extra tension made them more difficult to operate. Now all shears have double bows.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1989
Source:  NZ English Newsletter
Author:
Vol / Page:  3/22
Edition:
Quote:  <i>bow</i>: The curved handle top of hand shears. The grip is against the bows which causes the blades to spring open after each cut.
Notes:  (Wallace Shearing Glossary)

bow
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an iron contrivance in the shape of a double bow which fitted to the underside of the necks of a pair of draught bullocks and was fastened to the yoke across the upper side of the pair's necks.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:

Date:  0/0/1848

Date:  2/8/1851
Source:  Lyttelton Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  8
Edition:
Quote:  The Working Bullocks, with Bows, Yokes, and Chains, can be warranted as most unexceptional, being in good condition, and perfectly quiet.
Notes:

Date:  19/9/1856
Source:  Diary
Author:  W H S ROBERTS
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  I yoked up the bullocks. The bullock yoke was a square piece of white pine smoothed and hollowed out to fit the necks of the two bullocks, with holes for the iron bows which went round the neck and through the yoke, being fastened above with a key tied with a bit of greenhide; in the centre a bolt with a ring called `the start' passed through the yoke, to which the chain was fastened from the sledge.
Notes:  1856 Sep 19 W.H.S. Roberts diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 42

Date:  0/0/1863
Source:  First Year in Canterbury Settlement
Author:  BUTLER
Vol / Page:  vii 104-105
Edition:
Quote:  In the small river Ashburton ... we had a little misunderstanding [105] with the bullocks; the leaders ... slewed sharply round, and tied themselves into an inextricable knot with the polars [sic], while the body bullocks, by a manoeuvre not unfrequent, shifted, or as it is technically termed, slipped, the yoke under their necks, and the bows over; ...
Notes:  1860 in 1863 Butler First Year ch vii 104-105

bowser
Homonym Number:  1

Sense Number:
Definition: a petrol pump (chiefly Aust and NZ), also, a petrol tanker for fuelling aircraft .. etc; 1934; Petrol pump (at garage, etc)
Origin: [none]

Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Source:  NZ Journal of Science & Technology

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  19
Edition:
Quote:  old-fashioned word for petrol pump, after Mr Bowser, American manufacturer of only petrol pumps available in Australasia in 1930s; appropriately, `to bowse' means to come with a rush, a drinking vessel or a drinking bout; RAF called man in charge of a towed petrol tanker a `bowser king.'

bowyang
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the ties used below the knee to keep trouser legs free and from dragging on the ground, often used by shearers (usu. pl) (?obs in general use: extant in shearers'); string or a leather lace tied around the trouser leg below the knee.

box
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: box v.
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  16/9/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  When two mobs of sheep get mixed accidentally it is called a box. (1) When you put two mobs of sheep together on purpose, you box them. (2) When they join by accident they are said to <i>get boxed</i>. In fact, the active voice of the verb signifies intention; the passive, accident. ([1898 Morris Austral-English])
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Notes:

Date:  2/5/1981
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  43
Edition:
Quote:  The wheeled vehicles that transport the coal (trucks, tubs, or skips elsewhere) are in the Strongman called <i>boxes</i>, are linked together in a string they become a <i>race of boxes</i>. This <i>race</i> is the same word you hear in a railwayman's <i>rake of wagons, rake</i> being the northern-dialect form. <i>Race</i> was usually the southern form, used by miners in Cornwall. It looks as if a Cornishman at one time got loose on the West Coast.
Notes:  [I.A. Gordon: Strongman Mine]

box
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: part of a wool-press
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1913
Source:  Country Work
Author:  CARR
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:   Pressing. - When there is sufficient wool in one bin, the pressers (generally two) get to work. One gets into the `box' as the lower portion of the patent presses is called, while his mate ... hands him ... the fleeces. These are placed in tiers, and tramped down until the lower box is full. An upper box is then swung ... or [16] lowered on to the lower one, and the process repeated. When full, the `monkey' or cover is put into position, the spears (wire rope) affixed, and the two men lever the cover down until the top box is clear.
Notes:

Notes:  1837 Best Journal 1837-1843 ed Taylor 1966 81 July 12

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Loughnan Glossary
Author:  LOUGHNAN
Vol / Page:  9
Edition:
Quote:  box: separate lines of sheep or cattle that have been mixed together. There is a delicate nuance in the use of this word: if they have been mixed deliberately they have 'been boxed'.. If it all happened by accident, to be sure they 'got boxed.' And the latter case is inclined to occasion some pretty sulphurous language to foul the air.
Notes:

box
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: to mix mobs of sheep accidentally; usu. in quasi-aj or quasi-av constr. be, get boxed


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: box n.
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1947
Source:  Early Runholding in Otago
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  84
Edition:
Quote:  At first the diary describes this as `got mixed', but in 1864 I noted the use of the colonial term `boxed.' In 1868, however, I noted a reversion to `got mixed.'


Notes:  >?orig. SI station usage: the Puketoi diarist uses at first <i>join</i> as in 1859 July 24 Puketoi Station Diary [Hocken TS] Hume over, said that Wedder & ewe flocks had joined. but later uses join for the deliberate mixing of animals; e.g. putting rams with the ewes. cf Beattie's comment: 1864 Puketoi Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 84

box
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: to join or mix (either accidentally or for some purpose) mobs of sheep.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  19/4/1864
Source:  Puketoi Station Diary
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Grant unwell; lambs boxed [Apr 20] Fine. Drafted lambs out of John Murray's ewes & joined rams to both flocks
Notes:  [first use by diarist W. Baird Ogilvy][Hocken TS]

Date:  0/0/1881
Source:  Waitaruna
Author:  BATHGATE
Vol / Page:  148
Edition:
Quote:   He's allowed a mob of your sheep to cross the boundary, and now they're boxed with ours. ... [149] ... Gilbert concluded that as the sheep were ... irretrievably `boxed', nothing could be done; ...
Notes:

Date:  31/12/1910
Source:  NZ Truth
Author:
Vol / Page:  288/6/3
Edition:
Quote:  To hear the drover at his best - or his worst - it is desirable to be near him when a young dog is making a mess of things at a critical moment, or the mob gets `boxed' with another mob round the corner.
Notes:

Date:  16/9/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  When two mobs of sheep get mixed accidentally it is called a box. (1) When you put two mobs of sheep together on purpose, you box them. (2) When they join by accident they are said to <i>get boxed</i>. In fact, the active voice of the verb signifies intention; the passive, accident
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Date:  0/0/1947
Source:  Early Runholding in Otago
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  12
Edition:
Quote:  When two mobs ran into each other and intermingled, they were said to be `boxed.'
Notes:

Quote:   ... it was Andrew's job to patrol the rugged boundary each day, hunt the sheep back to keep them from getting boxed, and also to prevent their being menaced, destroy as many as possible of the wild dogs and pigs that inhabited the area.

Quote:  <i>Box</i>: When two mobs of sheep intended to be kept separate are mixed. Somebody is usually very unpopular.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collins Concise English Dictionary
Author:
Vol / Page:  128
Edition:
Quote:  <i>box ... 14. Austral. & N.Z </i>an accidental mixing of herds or flocks. ... <i>18. out of the box. Austral. inf. </i>outstanding or excellent. ... <i>21. Austral. & N.Z</i>. to mix (flocks or herds) or (of flocks) to become mixed accidentally.
Notes:  [1986 NZPOD 83; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 57]

Date:  0/12/1957
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  `A BOX OF BIRDS'

Sir, - I am aware that idioms in any language are often difficult to analyse, but there is one phrase used in New Zealand which leaves me completely puzzled. It is the expression `a box of birds,' given in reply to the greeting `How are you?' and is evidently intended to mean a state of well-being. This appears to be so completely irrelevant that I would be pleased if any of your readers could elucidate, if that is possible. The term suggests to me something to be prepared for the dinner table, but I am willing to be corrected. - I am, etc. KIWIPOM.

? 1957 Evening Post (?p) [To feel like a `box of birds' is to feel happy and chirpy - Ed.]
Notes:  month guessed at; check

Date:  13/12/1957
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  <i>BOX OF BIRDS</i>: After hearing this from another New Zealander, I tried out the phrase on many people in the South of England and London. Not one person had heard of it, and most were unable, from first hearing (in context), to judge its actual meaning or inference.
Notes:  G.J. Griffiths Letter

box off
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: to make redundant [prob.f. farming, to separate out as from a large flock; with poss. pun on box `a (cargo) container' so perhaps `to put in a box,' that is, to stack away].

box up

Definition: a mess up; state of confusion

Register:

Domain: [none]

Edition:
Quote:  When flocks are mixed they are said to be <i>boxed</i>, and from this peculiar use of the verb we have derived the term a <i>box-up</i>, a state of confusion, and <i>to be in a box</i>, to be in a confused state of mind.

Author:
Vol / Page:  (No.311) 129

Notes:  1841 Apr 19 Joseph Somes to Lord John Russell in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 129 [=Maori porter] [NZ letter of 23 Aug 1840]

bracket
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: ca1945 As a totalisator or betting convenience, to pair horses in certain circumstances so that if either is placed a dividend is paid on both. The circumstances are these: a) horses beyond 18 in any race are paired (bracketted) with a number, and hence a horse, already given (e.g. in a race of 20 entries, the last numbers would be 17, 17a, 18, 18a); b) similarly, when entries are more than can be safely run at one time and the race must be run in two divisions, each horse in the first division is paired (bracketted) with each horse in the second; c) (formerly) horses of the same ownership (galloping) or of the same ownership and trainership (trotting and pacing), running in the same race were bracketted.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations

In the event of there being a greater number of starters in a race than there are numbers available on the totalisator the Stewards or Committee may create a sufficient number of brackets by including two horses for each bracket so required beginning with the two lowest weighted horses and working up from them.

braided river
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a wide riverbed created by melting glacial action that contains single streams that join and separate [sign. in South Island for stock and human drowning, 1800s]

[fn] Economists, including the civil servants, R.M. Campbell, W.B. Sutch, and Professor Horace Belshaw (of Auckland University College), who advised Coates. The name was derived from Roosevelt's `Brain Trust'.
Notes:  1936 Jan 6 in 1988 Na To Hoa Aroha (Ngata-Buck Correspondence) 3/205-206 (Buck)

Quote:  At Waimate there were about 50 men and boys employed for the shearing - 22 shearers, 1 sheep-oh, 4 fleece-pickers, 4 wool-rollers, 1 brander, 1 wool-classer, 1 classer's boy, 3 pressers, 1 waggoner, 1 cook, 1 cook's mate, generally known as the offsider or `slushy' 8 shepherds; and last, but not least the shed boss, ... branding race
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a narrow race for branding sheep or cattle
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:

Date:  0/8/1950
Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  140
Edition:
Quote:  A branding-race might.. have a foot-rot trough installed in the bottom of it.


Notes:

Date:  16/9/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Brand.</i> - (1) The letter or other mark which each owner has to identify his own stock. It is stamped on to sheep with paint applied with a<i> branding iron</i> or <i>brand.</i> (2) and on to cattle and horses with red-hot iron which leaves a mark on the skin. Hence <i>branding race</i>, a narrow race for branding sheep, and <i>brander</i>, the man whose work it is to brand. (C.)
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Date:  15/7/1950
Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  7
Edition:
Quote:  In addition ... there may be units such as a branding race ...

branks
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a kind of bridle or halter ?with a piece of wood on each side instead of leather joined to a halter.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1947
Source:  Early Runholding in Otago
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  42
Edition:
Quote:  Mr. Andrew Liddell, who lived to be over a hundred, and who was a bullock-driver from the age of sixteen until he was twenty-two, had much to tell me of this adventurous portion of his long career, ... `You ask how the bullocks were attached to the vehicle, and as bullock-driving is now a lost art, I had better try and explain ... Very seldom was harness used, and then without winkers, and it was called branks. The pulling strain came on the bows, and a yoke joined two bows and went over each neck of a pair of bullocks. If there were five pairs, say, a chain ran from the yoke of the first pair to the yoke of the second pair, and another chain from the second to the third, and another chain from the third to the fourth. These chains were lighter between the first pairs and heavier as you got further back. The two rear bullocks were yoked to the pole of the dray or waggon. As there were no reins, the driving was all by commands and cracking the whip. The calls were `Get up' or `Gee up' to start,
`Whoa' to stop, `Come here' to turn to left, and `Gee off' to turn right. If you came to a sharp corner, you would often say persuasively, `Way! Way! Come here.'' There is a general impression that bullocks could not be successfully driven without roaring oaths and curses at them, but this idea is a relic of early-day humour.
Notes:

braxy
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an inflammatory disease of sheep.


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  13/1/1934
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Braxy</i>.-A fatal disease of sheep. Sheep that die of it make wholesome mutton, and in Scotland are prepared (salted, I think) and eaten. I do not know that we have exactly the same disease in New Zealand; certainly we have not the custom of eating the victims of it; but it is a stock joke on stations to point out any stinking carcase to a Scotch shepherd and say: `There's a nice bit of <i>b</i>. mutton for you, `So and so.''
Notes:   Acland Gloss. additions

Date:  0/0/1951
Source:  Early Canterbury Runs
Author:  ACLAND
Vol / Page:  358
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Braxy </i>a fatal disease of sheep. Sheep that die of it make wholesome mutton and in Scotland are prepared (salted perhaps) and eaten. We may not have exactly the same disease in New Zealand and certainly we do not have the custom of eating the victims of it; but it is a stock joke on stations to point out any stinking carcase to a Scotch shepherd and say, `There's nice bit of braxy mutton for you, So-and-so.'

Great care must be exercised, as a false move by man or dog will have the lambs, ever on their toes, stampeding or breaking.

Date:  16/9/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Break camp.</i> - Move away from camp; shift camp. Sheep which camp together are also said to `break camp' when they move off to feed at dawn. ([1874 Kennaway Crusts], p.113; Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement, p.54.)
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Date:  0/0/1952
Source:  My Yesteryears
Author:  BLAKISTON
Vol / Page:  18
Edition:
Quote:  Next morning we had to be up early to reach the tops before the merinos broke camp and started back for the country off which they had been mustered. ... At this stage, it was essential to get around the sheep before they broke camp, for to muster them again after they had begun to scatter would take many hours.
Notes:  [f. c1869]

Date:  0/0/1892
Source:  NZ Official Handbook
Author:
Vol / Page:  158
Edition:
Quote:  In the south, rough tramways are laid down in the bush, and the logs hauled on low carriages to the mills by horse- or bullock-teams. here the great round baulks of timber are `broken down' being cut lengthwise (by saws moving up and down vertically) into `flitches', which are passed over to the circular-saws to be ripped into boards and scantling.

break in
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: to train to be milked
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1856
Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author:  FITTON
Vol / Page:  218 and fn
Edition:
Quote:   ... milch cows, and heifers ready to be broken in for milking. [fn] A friend tells me the expression `breaking in' requires explanation. ... A young cow [allowed to run wild] when first milked is generally `baled up', that is, her head is secured between upright posts so that she can raise or lower it, but cannot turn round to use her horns. ... A pint or less of milk is considered a satisfactory result of the first attempt to milk an `unbroken heifer'. When a cow has submitted to this process a few times without much struggling, she is considered to be `well broken in to milk'. <i>Ibid.</I> 242 A well broken cow for milking generally sells for nearly [pounds]20.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1973
Source:  Wilson Family
Author:  WIERZBICKA
Vol / Page:  91
Edition:
Quote:   They put the cow into the bail today. She seems ... uncommonly quiet for a cow that had not been broken in.
Notes:  1874 J.G.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 191



break in
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: verb
Sense Number: 2
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  25/11/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Sheep dog</i>.- Dog to work sheep; <i>collie</i> (q.v.).<i> S.ds</i>. run naturally either to bring sheep towards you or to drive them away; and when a puppy shows his preference he is broken in for that work. The dogs that bring sheep are called <i>heading ds.</i> (q.v.) and most of these can be taught to <i>lead</i> (q.v.) if desired. Dogs which take to driving sheep away are broken in to <i>huntaway</i> and are called<i> htwys</i> (q.v.). Some dogs will both <i>hd.</i> and <i>htwy</i> and are called <i>handy ds</i>. They are not generally high-class heading dogs but very useful about hand and sometimes very useful mustering dogs. Some men have a special <i>slewing d</i>., but a well-trained,<i> hdg.</i> dog or <i>htwy</i>. will usually <i>slew</i> (q.v.). (C.)
Notes:   Acland Glossary

break out
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number: 2
Definition: [shearing] to open out the fleece of a sheep as it is shorn up the neck.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1955
Source:  Wool Away!
Author:  BOWEN
Vol / Page:  24
Edition:
Quote:  The next blow is from the off side of the brisket down to the opposite flank, and if possible, the belly wool is broken out. If this is found too difficult to break out, then leave it for the third blow.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  Loughnan Glossary
Author:  LOUGHNAN
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  break out: a machine shearer 'goes up the neck' with his comb flat on the skin. The shorn fibre usually remains attached to the tips. He 'breaks out' with a movement of wrist and forearm as they follow the handpiece.
Notes:

Definition: a sound of rushing air, attibuted to a phantom bird; or the bird species (hakuwai) that causes the noise
Origin: [none]

See: hakuwai

Citations
Date:  24/5/1844
Source:  Diary
Author:  TUCKETT
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  All the people frequenting this coast [sc. west coast of Otago] believe in the existence of an extraordinary bird, or phantom, which they can never see, but only hear rushing past them through the air with the rapidity of a falling rocket, and making a terrible rushing sound. The Maories declare that it is a bird possessing many joints in its wings. The whalers call them

<i>break-sea-devils,</i> after the name of an island where this phenomenon is of most frequent occurrence.
Notes:  1844 May 24 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 224

Vol / Page:  Web discussion

Notes:

Date:  22/9/2000
Source:  Taranaki Daily News
Author:
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:  Farming 2000
Quote:  Genetics providers used a figure called breeding worth to calculate benefits of genetics in dollar terms. BW is Breeding Worth, or worth for breeding, and is expressed in dollars. So a bull at 130 BW compared with another at 120 BW has $5/year/offspring more value for breeding, as only half is passed on from the bull.
Notes:

Vol / Page:  13

Nature be thanked, there is only one species of briar to punish invading man in the woods of New Zealand, but that one scratches cruelly.
Notes:  1844 Apr 24 and 25 Tuckett Diary in 1898 Hocken Contributions 212

Date:  0/10/2004
Source:  NZ Memories
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 50/50
Edition:
Quote:  [Hdg] Cross a Bridge ... to 'Somewhere' or 'Nowhere'. New Zealanders are skilled inventors of ingenious names, such as the 'Nippon Clip-on' for the extension lanes on the Auckland Harbour Bridge. Two other examples are the 'Bridge to Nowhere' and the 'Bridge to Somewhere', both of which have a somewhat similar history.

Notes:  (Thomson, Otago)

[26] Of this fish, Dr. Hector writes: `It has been termed brill on account of its being the only one of our flat fish with the eyes on the left side of the head; but it is small in size, and so full of bones, that it cannot be eaten with comfort.' <i>Ibid.</i> 304 <i>Pseudorhombus scaphus</i> Frost. Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author:  SORENSON
Vol / Page:  12
Edition:
Quote:  <i>BREAM OR BRIM</i> - A loose term for Black Bream (Auckland); small snapper at Nelson; and small Groper at Dunedin. <i>Ibid.</I> 45 <i>SNAPPER</i> (a) Scientific name: <i>Chrysophrys auratus</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Golden Snapper (c) Other common names: Schnapper; Brim (small snapper at Nelson); Tamure. (d) Principal localities where taken: From Nelson northwards to both coasts of the North Island.

Author:  PAUL et al.

Date:  0/0/1957
Source:  Sea Anglers' Fishes of NZ
Author:  PARROTT
Vol / Page:  99
Edition:
Quote:  The smaller speciments of Snapper are frequently called `Brim'.


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  PAUL
Vol / Page:  96
Edition:
Quote:  A sea bream (family Sparidae), not closely related to the true snappers of tropical and subtropical seas. <i>Snapper Chrysophrys auratus </i>... Snapper is often spelt schnapper; strictly, neither is correct. Small snapper are often called bream or brim, and the brightly coloured, medium-sized fish caught during the spring spawning season are often called school snapper.
Notes:

Date:  23/7/1986
Source:  Codes for Species in NZ Waters
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  [species name] brim (small snapper) .. [scientific name] -- [other name(s)] now coded as snapper

Pronunciation:
Notes: Referring to All Black Buck Shelford after he was dropped from the team. Originally used only in football terms with banners bearing the words appearing at rugby matches, now also in transferred usage e.g. "I wouldn't say "Bring back Buck" yet but.. in relation to suggestions that Ron Brierly should be brought back to replace Roger Douglas as head of BIL.

Briskula
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a Dalmatian card game
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/8/2004
Source:  NZ Memories
Author:
Vol / Page:  No. 49/49
Edition:
Quote:  There was a time when the game of cards, known as Briskula was king, If you did not play <i>Briskula</i>, you were not a Dalmatian, as it went with the breed. Every house and boarding hosue and club had its Briskula dens... In Briskula there were some distinctions - you led or were led. There was the traditional banging of fists and the cursing by all. If you won, you were great, if you lost, you were a fool and were abused by all, including your own... T heir fathers [50] didn't care much - they were out back drinking and playing cards - <i>Briskula and Treseta</i>, match-making, after all was women's work.

Date:  0/0/1868
Source:  Contributions to NZ Botany
Author:  LINDSAY
Vol / Page:  71
Edition:
Quote:  [<i>Coprosma lucida,</i> Forst.] The `Broad-leaf' or `Orange-leaf' tree of the settler; terms, however, which are probably not only applied to other species of the genus <i>Coprosma, (e.g. C. robusta,</i> Raoul,) but to species of genera belonging to very different families - and especially to <i>Griselinia lucida, (N.O. Corneae,) </i>whose foliage closely resembles that of <i>Coprosma lucida ... C. lucida</i> is also known to the Otago natives as `Kalamou' (Hector); and to the North Island Maoris as `Karamu', [fn] `Kakaramu,' or `Karangu,' [fn] (Colenso.) [fn] Also applied to <i>C. foetidissima. </i>
Notes:

broadleaf
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Griselinia littoralis, with foliage palatable to stock and with timber commonly used for fenceposts or battens. [occ. used for Gr lucida and some native coprosmas.]

Date:  20/7/1844
Source:  Nelson Examiner
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Perhaps the commonest tree [near Waikouaiti] is one that I was not aware of having seen before. It grows to a considerable size, but in a very twisted, irregular shape. Its leaf is of a smooth, glossy, green colour, about the size of the leaf of a Portugal laurel, but more heart-shaped. The native name of the tree is kapuka. It is commonly called broad-leaf by the white men there.
Notes:  1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 242

broadleaf
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Griselinia sp(p) esp. <i>G. littoralis</i>; a tree or shrub with large glossy leaves, often found epiphytic on other trees; also called kapuka, papauma, pukatea.




Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Vol / Page:  48

Quote:  In the autumn of 1874 ... Mr M.Grenfell was busy with a staff of employees erecting the Immigrants Barracks for the Government ... The first immigrants consisted of a number of workers with others, known as Brogdenites, who had been selected by Messrs Brogden and Co., the contractors for the Oamaru-Moeraki section of the railway. <i>Ibid.</I> 107 [At the Oamaru sports meeting c1880s] there were Chinese, Cingalese, Germans, ... shearers, gold miners, Brogdenites, sailors and swaggers; ... [108] COMMENCEMENT OF RAILWAY LINE/ The Brogdenites./ The [railway building] contractors, Mrssrs Brogden and Sons, had a bullock prepared [for the ceremony of turning the first sod]. The Brogdenmen were all there, and a very fine type of navvy they were.

broll
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a bran-like by-product of the wheat milling process, used for animal feed.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  22/9/2000
Source:  Taranaki Daily News
Author:
Vol / Page:  Farming 2000 Supp 14
Edition:
Quote:  Daily News Sept 22 14 we have gone on to broll, which is a by-product from the wheat mills. It's a sort of bran. We had been looking for something like a brewer's grain or broll for a long time. The main difference between broll and maize is that while they are the same in energy, broll has the highest protein content, and that energy is starch energy .. broll, if fed correctly, can have a huge impact on your protein test.
Notes:

broom
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: applied to indigenous genera Carmichaelia, Chordospartium, Corallospartium, and <i>Notospartium</i>; occas. to <i>Leptospermum</i> (manuka, tea-tree) as tea broom; and to various introduced genera (see 6 below) of brooms or broom-like plants.

[fn] The Mountain Lily is ... a buttercup, and the Edelweiss does not belong to the same genus as its European namesake. [fn 2] <i>Carmichaelia grandiflora</i>, var. <i>alba. </I>

These were the only two transfers of Brothers Island tuatara, directly from the island and from eggs hatched at Victoria University and raised at Nga Manu Nature Reserve in Waikanae.

Vol / Page:  221
Edition:
Quote:  <i>bro'Town</i> is very much a boy's world - the product of the all-male theatre ensemble known as 'The Naked Samoans.' [223] With a notion of open-ended kinship embedded in its very title - you don't have to be 'blood' to be a 'bro' - <i>bro'Town</i> points to the ways that art can serve as a much needed bridge from cultural specificity to universal humanism.
Notes:  -

Date:  17/10/2004
Source:  Sunday (Sunday Star Times Magazine)
Author:
Vol / Page:  29
Edition:
Quote:  Gleefully anti-PC - the boys are described as "dumb-ass P-heads and no-hopers" by Carol Hirschfeld in a cameo - <i>bro'Town</i> revels in skewering Polynesian culture, Auckland, single parents, smug Pakehas, gays, and Indian dairy owners in equal measure.

Date:  17/4/2004
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:

Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  17/301
Edition:
Quote:   <i>[Notho]fagus solandri</i>, Hook. f. ... <i>Myrtilloides cinerascens</i>, Banks & Sol., MS.<i> Cliffortiordes oblongata</i>, Dryander. Entire-leaved Beech. Black Birch of Wellington, Canterbury, and in part of Otago and Southland. White Birch of Nelson, and in part Otago. Black-heart Birch of Otago. White, Black, Red, and Brown Birch of Oxford and Alford Forests. A fine tree, sometimes attaining the height of 100 feet, but usually 60-80 feet, with a trunk from 2 to 4 feet or more in diameter.

(<i>Casarca variegata</i>); the grey duck, or Parera  (<i>Anas superciliosa</i>); the brown duck, an allied species or variety of the last; the Papanga, or `teal,' or `widgeon'  (<i>Fuligula N.Z.</i>), and some other varieties that may be imported birds, or crosses, or other native species.

Date:  0/0/1889
Source:  Catalogue NZ Exhibition
Author:  PARKER
Vol / Page:  117
Edition:
Quote:  There are eleven species of Native Ducks belonging to nine genera, all found elsewhere, except two--the little Flightless Duck of the Auckland Islands (genus <i>Nesonetta</i>) and the Blue

Mountain Duck (<i>Hymenolaemus</i>). Among the most interesting of the non-endemic forms, are the Paradise Duck or Sheldrake (<i>Casarca variegata</i>), the Brown Duck (<i>Anas chlorotis</i>), the Shoveller or Spoonbill duck (<i>Rhynchaspis variegata</i>), and the Scaup or Black Teal (<i>Fuligula Novae-Zealandiae</i>).
Notes:  1889 Prof. Parker `Catalogue of New Zealand Exhibition' 117 in 1898 Morris Austral-English 128

brown flat

Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:

Notes:
Citations
Date:  17/10/2000
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  Button mushrooms still dominate about 75 per cent of our market, but having arrived just four years ago, the brown giant with a cap the size of a mini-pizza is now muscling for space on every supermarket shelf... Actually, these "brown flats", "gourmet browns", "portobellos" (call them what you will) are nothing more than brown button mushrooms which have been allowed to grow up.
Notes:

Date:  16/7/1994
Source:  Listener (New Zealand Listener)
Author:
Vol / Page:  60
Edition:
Quote:  These big brown mushrooms... are an American strain of the standard cultivated mushroom <i>Agaricus bisporus</I>. In the United States, they are known as portobello. Here, Clive Thompson [of Parkvale Mushrooms in Carterton] chose to give them the traditional New Zealand name "brown flats".

Source:  NZ Geographic
Author:
Vol / Page:  49
Edition:
Quote:  NEW ZEALAND is home to two types of geckos, which have generally been described as green (<i>Naultinus</i> genus), and brown (<i>Hoplodctylus</i> genus) geckos. Genetic work may yet reveal the taxonomy to be more complicated than this, as brown gecko species have proved to be unexpectedly diverse.

brown skink
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a well camouflaged skink which lives in damp habitats in the lower North Island and the northern tip of the South Island; a sunbasker but secretive.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1997
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  At first glance the food mass in the weasel's stomach appeared blackish with numerous tiny yellow flecks. This proved to be the remains of a juvenile Whitaker's skink, which made up about 70% of the stomach contents. The rest of the stomach's contents were comprised of the remains of a juvenile brown skink Leiolopisma zelandicum and three tiny invertebrates (a spider, an isopod and a fly) that may have come from the skinks' stomachs.
Notes:  http://www.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/casn146.pdf 1997 Department of Conservation, P.O. Box 10-420, Wellington, New Zealand. Reference to material in this report should be cited thus: Miskelly, C.M., 1997. Whitaker's skink Cyclodina whitakeri eaten by a weasel Mustela nivalis. Conservation Advisory Science Notes No. 146, Department of Conservation, Wellington.

Date:  0/0/2004
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  We carried out captive-based behavioural comparisons between striped skinks and the common terrestrial brown skink (Oligosoma zelandicum). Brown skinks are of similar mass to striped skinks and overlap in geographic range and habitat, but are easily captured by hand and pitfall trapping in the wild.
Notes:  New Zealand Journal of Ecology (2004) 28(2): 267-278 New Zealand Ecological Society http://www.nzes.org.nz/nzje/abstract.php?volume_issue=j28_2&pdf_filename=NZJEcol28_2_267.pdf



Date:  31/12/2007
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  Since then four other species of skinks and geckos have been re-introduced to the

island, the brown skink has been re-discovered and the numbers of gold stripe gecko and the

equally threatened MacGregors skink were thought to have grown markedly.


Notes:  http://www.manaisland.org.nz/Newsletter35.PDF   Annual Report for the AGM of Friends of Mana Island Inc (FOMI) for year ending 31 December 2007

Date:  0/0/2002
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:  11
Edition:
Quote:  Brown skinks are now

present in the Taranaki area and the western half of the southern North Island, on

Kapiti Island, Mana Island .. and possibly on islands in Wellington Harbour.

Brown skinks are also found in the northern and north-western South Island.

Brown skinks frequently co-exist with common skinks .. and at a few

localities with spotted skinks. Brown, common, spotted and speckled skinks co-exist

in Marlborough Sounds on Stephens Island/Takapourewa and are likely to have once

done so in the Wellington area ...
Notes:  http://www.doc.govt.nz/upload/documents/science-and-technical/TSRP48.pdf North Island Oligosoma spp. skink recovery plan 2002-2012

Source:  Art Album NZ Flora

Vol / Page:  32
Edition:
Quote:   `Bucket-of-water-wood', <i>P. tenuifolium</i>, Maori Kowhiwhi or Maupariki - despised as firewood. ...  PITTOSPORUM TENUIFOLIUM (<i>Banks & Sol</i>.) ... This small evergreen tree, known by the native names of `Kowhiwhi' and `Maupariki', abounds on the eastern coasts of both Islands. ... Even as firewood it is despised, and bears the all too suggestive name of `Bucket of Water Wood', so little is it calculated by its combustive qualities to enliven the domestic hearth.

Vol / Page:  201

Quote:  Perhaps the most recurrent and universal of rough games in the early period was

<i>Cockfighting</i> (K-78). This was a free-for-all contest in which a smaller boy mounted on the back of a bigger boy and the two endeavored [sic] to dislodge all other riders by pushing or [202] pulling them over. ... Sometimes the game was known as a Piggy-back Contest or as Pulling Off. `One trick of the game was to "buck-jump" your rider, which consisted in jerking your elbows so that the rider was lifted over your head' (Naseby, Otago, 1905).

buckjumper
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: a low, springy bough, to straddle and ride up and down like a bucking horse (the fun was to swing up and down as far as possible without falling off).

buck-jumping
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: the violent bucking of horses
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  23/8/1856
Source:  Diary
Author:  W H S ROBERTS
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  BUCKJUMPING [title] ... August 23, 1856. I mounted my good mare `Lassie,' with the intention of leading the two packed horses, when to my astonishment her ladyship started buckjumping, and after a long fight, finding she could not throw me, suddenly stood on her hind legs and fell over backwards. ... Buckjumping is a horrid vice, although it is a very amusing performance - to the spectator. The horse tries to roll itself up into a ball, with all four feet close together, head down as near the ground as possible between the forelegs, tail well down, back stuck up like the hump of a camel when in good condition. Attitude is everything. Then commences the performance. With an active spring and rather a forward motion up you go in the air, and down again with a jerk, then up and down like an india-rubber ball, occasionally varying the action by jumping forward and kicking out behind with both legs at once, returning to the oval position as rapidly as possible, then turning round like a teetotum at
lightning speed.
Notes:  1856 Aug 23 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 35

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  History of Children's Play
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  112
Edition:
Quote:  Apart from simple climbing there was, for example, `crossing' the plantation on the treetops, and Rough-riding, in which one player sat on a fir tree branch while the others took the end of it and pulled it up and down and then let it go flying up in the air. The player who could stay on the longest was the rough-riding champion. Of a similar nature was Buck-jumping, in which individual players rode a macrocarpa or gum branch [113] to see who could rise the highest.

Quote:  <i>Buckley's </i>short for <i>Buckley's chance</i>, which is no chance; after mid-C19 Australian outlaw who was reckoned to have no chance of escape, though other explanations exist; eg `We haven't a Buckley's of winning the cup now Honk's had to drop out of the team.' ANZ.

Date:  0/0/1982

Author:
Vol / Page:  141

Quote:  <i>Buckley's chance n. Austral. sl.</i> no chance at all. Often shortened to Buckley's. [C19:
Notes:   [1986 NZPOD 91; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 62]

Date:  0/0/1936
Source:  Lauder Brothers
Author:  CLAPPERTON
Vol / Page:  10
Edition:
Quote:  I don't suppose for a moment I have Buckley's chance.
Notes:

Date:  27/1/1934
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  15
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Buckley's chance.</i>-A correspondent from Kirwee, the same as explained <i>Jimmy Woodser</i> for me, writes that Buckley was one of the earliest convicts (perhaps the first) to escape from Botany Bay and take to the bush. It was then thought impossible to do this and live, as apart from the problem of food and water, the blacks were numerous and savage and reported to be cannibals. Extensive search was made, but no trace was found of Buckley; and it was concluded that the natives had got him. Any other convict who talked of escaping was invariably told that he would have `Buckley's chance' - hence the saying. However, many years afterwards Buckley was found to be still living. He had managed to make friends with a small band of natives who were moving to a remote part of the country, married one of their gins, and lived their life. The convict system had by that time been abolished, so the Government granted him a free pardon.
Notes:  Acland Gloss

buckshee
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:

buckshot
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a settlers' term for granulated lava (always imbedded in sandy alluvium).
