buff weka
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a yellowish-buff subspecies of weka, Gallirallus australis hectori , taken to the Chatham Islands in the early 20th century to avoid extinction.

Vol / Page:  A11
Edition:
Quote:  The buff weka is a mischievous bird, inquisitive, noisy and with a sense of humour. It interacts well with humans. The buff weka roamed the east coast of the South Island and Central Otago but was a victim of predators and became extinct on the mainland in 1920.

bugger
Homonym Number:
Word Class: exclamation
Sense Number:
Definition: In various forms and expressions it is as widely used in NZ as elsewhere, and not popularly regarded as an obscene, nor even by many a coarse, word. Often used familiarly or friendly-like, but not as often in this sense as `(old) bastard'; cf OED: and OEDS In low language: A coarse term of abuse or insult: simply `chap; customer; fellow' (cf Baggage) Leic Gloss 1881 `this little bugger'; see esp. P: for various forms, and an interesting note; some expressions which are not (or not well) attested elsewhere follow. There is no claim that they are exclusively, in even predominantly, New Zealand English.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

buggy
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Orig. a US borrowing for a usually four-wheeled vehicle; thence any light passenger vehicle, as distinct from the main, light freight vehicle, the express wagon: applied (often humorously) to motor vehicles, before the term was specifically adopted in the 1960s for e.g., beach-buggy. loosely and humorously applied to any wheeled vehicle, whether horse-drawn or not
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Date:  0/0/1883
Source:  Bishop's Guide to Wellington
Author:
Vol / Page:  22
Edition:
Quote:  A prominent feature ... is the massive pile of buildings which forms the central location of the Civil Service of the Colony. `The Buildings', as they are locally designated, have the appearance of being thoroughly substantial and permanent in character, and it is not a little surprising to a stranger, and destructive of his appreciation, to find that the ponderous edifice is constructed of wood. It is certainly claimed for the structure that it is the largest wooden one of a permanent character in the world, but that is a distinction which, even if it is deserved, is one perhaps of questionable honor.

buist
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  30/4/1859
Source:  Puketoi Station Diary
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Duncan's flock buisted and ear marked.
Notes:

Date:  30/4/1859
Source:  Puketoi Station Diary
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Naturally Scoticisms are prevalent, but only one or two will be noted here. On April 30, 1859, we read: `Duncan's flock buisted and earmarked,' and thereafter the word `buisted' is often employed. I understand it is an old Scots term for raddle or for marking with tar, etc., or for any marking which was not burnt in by the process invariably called branding.
Notes:  1859 Apr 30 Puketoi Station Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 97

Date:  0/0/1947
Source:  Early Runholding in Otago
Author:  BEATTIE
Vol / Page:  85
Edition:
Quote:   In connection with stock the following terms were used: - `Let the sheep draw down to the Taieri'; `stags,' `crawlers,' `stragglers,' `a horse with couples in his mouth,' `the bull baked on the road,' `cut and tailed,' `lagoon washing,' `spaying cattle,' `killed a pleuro,' `herding lambs,' `buisting weaners,' `a camp for the cattle,' ...
Notes:  [1858-1869] Puketoi Station Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 85

Date:  0/0/1889
Source:  Forest Flora
Author:  KIRK
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:   <i>Nothofagus fusca</i>
Notes:  (Andersen)

Date:  0/0/1885
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  17/300
Edition:
Quote:  <i> [Notho]fagus fusca</i>,Hook. f. ... Tooth-leaved Beech. Black Birch of Auckland and in part of Otago and Southland. Black or Bull Birch of Lake Wakatipu. Red Birch of Wellington, Nelson, and in part of Otago and Southland. It is not so easy to see why any difficulty should have occured in the identification of this fine timber-tree apart from the misleading tendency of the common names generally applied. The thin yet firm texture of the leaf, the prominent veins, the sharply-toothed margins, are characters that can only be confused with those afforded by a careless observer. Yet merely owing to the use of common names based upon colour, and applied or rather misapplied to the leaves, bark, or wood at the fancy of the bushman, no species has been more misunderstood.
Notes:  (Kirk, NZ Beeches)

Date:  0/0/1902
Source:  Settler's Handbook of NZ, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  125
Edition:
Quote:  Bull-birch, of southern lakes district.

Author:
Vol / Page:  1/307

Notes:  (E. Phillips Turner) [Otago] see cit. 1 b. above.

Vol / Page:  404
Edition:
Quote:  Even in the North Island the average bushman will speak of the pukatea tree as "bucketeer", and not to call the poroporo shrub a "bull-a-bull" would be considered  affectation.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Oxford Book of NZ Plants
Author:  MOORE & IRWIN
Vol / Page:  168
Edition:
Quote:  <i>SOLANUM LACINIATUM.</i> Poroporo (bullibul) is a soft-wooded shrub ... Two species are called by one Maori name. Two Latin names, <i>S. laciniatum</i> and <i>S. aviculare,</i> are both more than a hundred years old but it was only in 1954 that Baylis defined clearly the difference between the two species and then the two names came into general use.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  NZ Medicinal Plants
Author:  BROOKER et al.
Vol / Page:  93
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Solanum aviculare </i> Forst.f. Common name: <i>Bullibulli </i>Maori name: <i>Poroporo, kohoho </i>... Some authors have identified `poroporo' as S. nigrum [Black Nightshade], a smaller, weedy plant, and it is possible that the Maori did not distinguish the species.

Citations
Date:  0/0/1970
Source:  Nomenclature of NZ Fish
Author:  SORENSON
Vol / Page:  37
Edition:
Quote:  <i>MONKFISH </i>(a) Scientific name: (i) <i>Geniagnus monopterygius</i> (ii) <i>Kathetostoma giganteum</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (both) Whitefish. (c) Other common names: (both) Monkfish, Monks, Stargazer, Flathead (also applied at times to export gurnard); Churchills, Toebiters, Bulldogs, Spotted Stargazer, Maori Chief (Dunedin); Muddies. (d) Principal localities where taken: Napier, Cook Strait, Nelson, Banks Peninsula, Bluff-Stewart Island. ... Monkfish is a general term for species of the Families Uranoscopidae and Leptoscopidiae.
Notes:

Date:  23/7/1986
Source:  Codes for Species in NZ Waters
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  [species name] stargazer .. [scientific name] <i>Kathetostoma giganteum</i> .. [other name(s)] monkfish, boofs, bulldogs, churchills, flathead monk, giant stargazer, monks, muddies, spotted stargazer, toebiters, whitefish, sandcod
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide
Author:  PAUL
Vol / Page:  118
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Monkfish Kathetotoma giganteum </i>... Also occurs in southern Australia. Known by a number of local names: giant stargazer, flathead, bulldog, boof, etc. The name monkfish is well established for this species in New Zealand, whereas overseas it is used for similarly shaped but unrelated anglerfishes.
Notes:

bulldust
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: euphemism for bullshit lies, rot, nonsense; boasting - as a noun or as an exclam. (<i>Bullswool </i>is another variant; the politest is the innocuous Bovril; cf. also bull, heifer dust).

bullhead
Homonym Number:  1

Sense Number:
Definition: a freshwater fish (?Morris Eleotris gobioides); ?bull-trout; ?bully @n; ?cockabully.
Origin:
Register:

Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1875
Source:  TrNZI
Author:
Vol / Page:  2/85
Edition:
Quote:  There are only three fish in the River Avon, sufficiently common to justify the supposition that either of them may be the adult form of the Whitebait; these are the Bull-head, the Silver-fish, and the Smelt. The name of Smelt is applied indiscriminately to the two latter fish, we will ... retain the trivial name of Silver-fish as a distinction. We may first dismiss the Bull-head ... It is an Acanthopterygious fish ... Head, large, one third of the length of the body ... [86] The Silver-fish again belongs to the

<i>Malacopterygii abdominales</i>, or fishes having soft fin rays, with the ventral fins placed below the abdomen. ... We now come to the ... fish ...called, by boys, the Smelt; but why a Smelt, I know not. ... the Smelt is a Galaxia ...




Notes:  (Powell)-

bullock dray
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a usu. four-wheeled vehicle, with a pole rather than shafts, drawn by a team of bullocks; a rough two-wheeled cart to which bullocks were attached by neck-yokes and chains (see Kennaway Crusts illustration),


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: cf. bullock wagon
Pronunciation:

bullock language
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1948
Source:  Julius Von Haast
Author:  VON HAAST
Vol / Page:  36
Edition:
Quote:  If the English sailors have acquired a not undeserved reputation for their curses, surely the New Zealand bullock-drivers must be reckoned superior to them in this accomplishment, for such an assortment of fantastic oaths from all kingdoms of Nature, Heaven and Hell I have never heard before from mortal lips. Astounded I listened to this blue-eyed son of Albion and was at last impelled to ask him why he cursed so horribly; it could serve no purpose and only made the beast more stubborn. `You don't understand, Sir,' the young man answered. `I'm only speaking the bullock language. The animal certainly wouldn't understand or obey me if I spoke to him as I would to my horse. The bullock has been brought up to carry in this way, and if I want to get on fast, I've got to talk to him like this.' To this argument advanced by the driver with a good-natured smile I naturally could find no reply. I refer it to the linguists to enrol this new language in the appropriate family of dialects.


Notes:  [c1860 <i>Weiner Zeitung</i> (Vienna) Nos 57-65 in German] in 1948 Von Haast Julius Von Haast 36



Date:  0/0/1886

Quote:  Bullock drivers are seldom choice in their language under the most favourable circumstances, but to drive a team with a load of firewood ..., from Papanui to Christchurch, was a work of so much difficulty, that the flow of bullock language was more than ordinarily profuse [March 1852].

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  History of Children's Play
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  64
Edition:
Quote:  Another play unknown at a later date was the widespread Bullock Teams: It was easy to make a team of working bullocks from pieces of supplejack, with their opposite branches doing duty as horns. The manufacture of yokes, substitutes for chains and model sledges gave a boy the pleasant feeling that accompanies successful achievement. Leading the team by a piece of string was the next step. (1870; Waipu)

Sledges were the [34] common vehicle of the earliest times, followed by bullock drays, and then, after the diggings broke out, by the long-bodied, four-wheeled bullock wagon and also by horse-drawn drays and wagons with greatly increased accommodation.

bullock whip
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  19/9/1856
Source:  Diary
Author:  ROBERTS
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The whip was rawhide plaited sinnet, about six feet long, thick at the upper end, where it was fastened to a handle as long as itself, but tapering nearly to a point, to which was attached a narrow strip of rawhide, called `the fall,' finishing off with a twisted `cracker' made of `weetau' or dressed flax in [43] place of whipcord, and was a powerful flagellator in the hands of an experienced `bullock puncher.'
Notes:  1856 Sep 19 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 42-43



Date:  23/9/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Bullock whip</i>.- Whip used by bullock driver. It was made with a very long handle (perhaps eight feet) and a long lash. `Come here' and `gee back' were the words the driver used to turn the bullocks left and right, accompanied by a crack of the whip on the opposite side. (C.)
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Date:  0/0/1939

Notes:
Citations
Date:  19/9/1856
Source:  Diary
Author:  ROBERTS
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  I yoked up the bullocks. The bullock yoke was a square piece of white pine smoothed and hollowed out to fit the necks of the two bullocks, with holes for the iron bows which went round the neck and through the yoke, being fastened above with a key tied with a bit of greenhide; in the centre a bolt with a ring called `the start' passed through the yoke, to which the chain was fastened from the sledge.
Notes:  1856 Sep 19 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 42

Date:  0/4/1861
Source:  Samuel Butler
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  <i>April</i>, 1861 - It is Sunday. We rose later than usual. There are five men sleeping in the hut. I sleep in a bunk on one side of the fire, Mr. Haast ... sleeps upon the opposite one; my bullock-driver and hut-keeper have two bunks at the far end of the hut, along the wall; ... The usual mutton and bread for breakfast with a pudding made of flour and water baked in the camp-oven after a joint of meat - Yorkshire pudding, but without eggs. While we were at breakfast, a robin perched on the table and sat there a good while pecking at the sugar.
Notes:  1861 April Butler's Note in 1919 Jones Samuel Butler - A Memoir 1/87

Date:  23/9/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Bullock-driver.</i> - Man employed to drive bullocks. The old nickname for him was

<i>bullocky, bullock-puncher</i> being a much later word. Bullocks on the road have to feed until about 10 a.m., so that bullockies were generally lazy, slow starters in the morning. They were famous for swearing, and the old story of the parson who said, `Even a bullock driver has a soul to be saved' is still told up country. (C.; 1898 Morris Austral-English) [c1962 One of the last bullock teams was driven (ceremonially) in Canterbury in 1962.]
Notes:  Acland Gloss

Date:  19/9/1856
Source:  Diary
Author:  W H S ROBERTS
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The whip was rawhide plaited sinnet, about six feet long, thick at the upper end, where it was fastened to a handle as long as itself, but tapering nearly to a point, to which was attached a narrow strip of rawhide, called `the fall,' finishing off with a twisted `cracker' made of `weetau' or dressed flax in [43] place of whipcord, and was a powerful flagellator in the hands of an experienced `bullock puncher.'
Notes:  1856 Sep 19 W.H.S. Roberts Diary in 1947 Beattie Early Runholding 42-43

Quote:  A <i>bullock-puncher </i>is a man engaged to drive bullocks to market or port. The expression is painfully true, as these men, who receive but very poor wages, and are recruited from the worst class, ill treat the poor animals by <i>punching</i> their sides with a pointed stick.

Vol / Page:

Quote:
Notes:

Date:  23/9/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:   ~ Man employed to drive bullocks. The old nickname for him was <i>bullocky, bullock-puncher</i> being a much later word. Bullocks on the road have to feed until about 10 a.m., so that bullockies were generally lazy, slow starters in the morning. They were famous for swearing, and the old story of the parson who said, `Even a bullock driver has a soul to be saved' is still told up country. (C.; 1898 Morris Austral-English)
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Hooking the winding rope on to suitable trees ... demands ... quickness of judgment. Wages. ... bullocky 10s to 12s a day, hooker-on 9s to 12s a day.

bullrush
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a children's game.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: Kingy-seeny; Charlie across the water
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1989
Source:  Kiwi Baby Boomers
Author:  McGILL
Vol / Page:  41
Edition:
Quote:  Bullrush involved as many of the school as possible, all at one end of the paddock, one person in the middle. At the cry of 'bullrush' we all ran and he had to catch one of us. It was also called Charlie across the water and kingaseeny
Notes:

Date:  15/4/1999
Source:  City Voice
Author:
Vol / Page:  19
Edition:
Quote:  In its simplest form bullrush involved one person standing in the middle of the field, then everyone else lined up on one side. The middle person would call someone's name (often in a rhyming way) into the middle. The object being of course to get past the middle to the other end of the field. If the runner was caught he or she joined the middle to call and catch more runners. Should a single runner get through there would be a bullrush, where everyone ran through the middle... These games had a thousand different names in earlier times: broken barley, king dick, punch king (where you had to punch the runner down!), goosey and so on... An excellent variation was.. cockarusha, in which everyone, instead of running, tries to hop through the middle.


Notes:

Date:  13/5/1999
Source:  City Voice
Author:
Vol / Page:  19
Edition:
Quote:  Life itself is like a game of bullrush. Maybe that's why it is now virtually banned in every school in NZ, its [sic] too rough... Hayley has fond memories of bullrush, "That's where you got your boyfriends..."
Notes:

Quote:  It's like a game of bullrush, in which the single-objective SOE rushes to the finish line, and everyone else gets a quick yank of the jersey if they're quick.

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Elver, The
Author:  SUTHERLAND
Vol / Page:  61
Edition:
Quote:   `Do you play Bull Rush at your school?' John asked. `Bull Rush?' said Ewan. ... `You get out on the field and draw a line at the ends. You pick someone to be He to stand in the middle. He calls out someone's name, and he has to get across to the other end. The guard has to try to tackle the runner and hit him three times. But if the runner gets across he calls out Bull Rush and everyone runs ...[sic]' `That's King-a-Sene!' said Ewan. `But we're only allowed to tag the player, we're not allowed to tackle him ...'[sic] ... `Do you play with the girls at all?' `Sometimes we play Drop the Handkerchief. The girls can join in. But most of the time they play Eely Ily Oh, or Queenie, or some cissy game like that...'[sic]

`Do you play shinty or football?' `Yeah. Football. And we play scrag in the winter and tippeny runs in the summer...'[sic]

Notes:

Date:  5/11/1999
Source:  NZ Education Review
Author:
Vol / Page:  00
Edition:
Quote:  Is there one single New Zealamnder who has not played bullrush in some form or other?... There are variations. The main one is the classic 'bar the door' (which for some phonetically evolved into 'barbador'), where the main difference is that runners line up at both ends of the field. These games had a thousand names in earlier days: broken barley, king dick, punch king (where you had to punch the runner down), goosey and so on... Kerikeri school banned it (they called it king asini) three years ago.
Notes:  check date and page

Date:  0/0/1972
Source:  Folkgames of Children
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  174
Edition:
Quote:  Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies ...

bullshit and kauri gum
Homonym Number:
Word Class: phrase
Sense Number:
Definition: usu. as an exclam., an extended variant of preceding phs influenced by one version of the story quoted under bovril : Englishman, New Zealander and Maori swapping tall stories. The Englishman rubs two sticks together: result, fire; the New Zealander rubs two kauri trees together: result, kauri-gum; the Maori, two bulls: result, bullshit.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  Animals of NZ, The
Author:  NATUSCH
Vol / Page:  226
Edition:
Quote:   The common bully (<i>Gobiomorphus</i> sp(p)) is plentiful at river mouths, and occurs also in some upland lakes like Te Anau and Alexandria. The giant bully, G. gobioides, grows up to nine inches long - three inches longer than the biggest common bully - and is most often met with in lowland lake, swamps and spring-fed creeks.

(<i>Gobiomorphus cotidianus</i>), redfinned bully (<i>G. huttoni</i>), and bluegilled bully (<i>G. hubbsi</i>). These are sometimes caught in large quantities by whitebaiters. The fishermen call them `Dan Doolin Spawn' or `Whalefeed'.

Date:  0/0/1984
Source:  NZ Whitebait Book, The
Author:  McDOWALL
Vol / Page:  21
Edition:
Quote:  Although whitebaiters know them by the name "whalefeed" they are in fact the young of several species of freshwater bully: the redfinned bully (<i>Gobiomorphus huttoni</i>), the bluegilled bully (<i>Gobiomorphus hubbsi</i>) and the common bully (<i>Gobiomorphus cotidianus</i>)... The bluegilled bully is dinstinguished by a steely-blue stripe on the gill membranes and its distinctly dark-spotted, almost leopard-like pattern on the head.

Quote:  Although whitebaiters know them by the name "whalefeed" they are in fact the young of several species of freshwater bully: the redfinned bully (<i>Gobiomorphus huttoni</i>), the bluegilled bully (<i>Gobiomorphus hubbsi</i>) and the common bully (<i>Gobiomorphus cotidianus</i>)... The third species referred to as "whalefeed" is the common bully. This rather drab fish is the most commonly seen bully.

Notes:

bully
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Cockabully; pl. occas. bullys.  usu. of ?<i>Galaxias</i> sp(p) or <i>Gobiomorphus</i> spp., cockabully, toitoi
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1967
Source:  Animals of NZ, The
Author:  NATUSCH
Vol / Page:  226
Edition:
Quote:  BULLIES: Sub-order GOBIOIDEA Bullies are not the same as cockabullies. The family these rather severe-faced fishes belong to is widely distributed over moderately warm and even tropical countries, and reaches its southern most distribution in New Zealand. The bully family is called Gobiidae by some writers, Eleotridae by others. Bullies are spiny-rayed fishes with the paired ventral fins placed well foward; they have a genital papilla for passing out eggs or sperms; and the males look different from the females. Two genera are recognised at present, <i>Gobiomorphus</i> and <i>Philypnodon. </i>

Notes:

Date:  0/0/1927
Source:  Natural History of Canterbury
Author:  spei
Vol / Page:  196
Edition:
Quote:  The whitebait runs begin definitely in August and continue through the two following months; but in November the shoals begin to include young smelts and bullies

(<i>Gobiomorphus</i>) which prey actively upon the whitebait, the bullies being particularly voracious. ... <i>Ibid.</I> Of the two gobies, more often called `bullies,' are by far the better known. <i>Gobiomorphus gobioides </I> is small, but active and voracious, and can be seen in all slender streams and watercourses darting across the bottom, for `bullies' keep low down.
Notes:  1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 196

Date:  0/0/1927

(<i>Gobiomorphus</i>) which prey actively upon the whitebait, the bullies being particularly voracious. ... <i>Ibid.</I> Of the two gobies, more often called `bullies,' are by far the better known. <i>Gobiomorphus gobioides </I> is small, but active and voracious, and can be seen in all slender streams and watercourses darting across the bottom, for `bullies' keep low down.

bulrush-pollen cake
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1978
Source:  Maori Food and Cookery
Author:  FULLER
Vol / Page:  28
Edition:
Quote:  BULRUSH-POLLEN CAKES (PUNGAPUNGA OR KONEHU RAUPO) ...

Next the flowerheads of the raupo were placed in finely-woven flax baskets and shaken over the mouths of the bags so that only the fine seed was collected. This pollen was put into smaller baskets and covered with rangiora leaves and baked in the umu until steam burst from the top, when the cakes would be cooked.

Vol / Page:  174
Edition:
Quote:  Marbles had a language of its own. There were names for the marbles, the games, and all the various aspects of the play. There were terms for marbles such as `taw' or `shooter', referring to the marbles used to fire with; `dubs', `dates', `stakes', `dukes', or `changers', referring to the marbles put down to be fired at. Then there were the terms referring to particular kinds of marbles: for example, agates, aggies, aggotties, American alleys, blood alleys, bomb-squashers, bonies, bonsers, bottlies, bull's eyes, bum-squashers, cat's eyes, chinkies ...

bung
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: adjective
Sense Number: 3
Definition:  in this collocation, often a mixture of senses of bung(ed). It can mean a `blind' (i.e., useless, ruined) eye, or and eye <i>bunged-up</i> (sc by a blow, or (a bung in the eye) or by infection). It is not clear to which of these (or both) the 1963 citation below refers. cf P: <i>bung-eye</i> Aust coll for and ocular inflammation caused by flies : late 19-20C.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1965
Source:  Speech and Idiom of Maori Children
Author:  ANDERSON & AITKEN
Vol / Page:  37
Edition:  1963
Quote:  [Maori child speaks] He's got a bung eye.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1974
Source:  Australian & NZ English [TS]
Author:  SYDER & HODGETTS
Vol / Page:  137
Edition:
Quote:  A part of the human body is injured, or in an unhealthy state. .`Bob would be a good man to call on for help, but he's got a bung arm. He's got it in plaster.' Thus, a `bung' eye may be either caused by a blow, or swollen or discoloured, etc. through sickness. .in 4;`He's got a bung eye.'
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1982
Source:  Collins Concise English Dictionary
Author:
Vol / Page:  145
Edition:
Quote:  <i>bung adj. Austral. sl. 1.</i> dead. <i.>2</i>. destroyed.<i> 3. </i>

useless. <i>4. go bung. a</i>. to fail or collapse.<i> b.</i> to die. [C19: < Abor.]
Notes:  [1986 NZPOD 94; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 63]

Author:
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Bungy</i>.-I understand from both West Coasters and North Islanders that this term is used throughout New Zealand (but so far as I know not in Canterbury) and that it is a corruption of a Maori word, <i>punga. </i>

Notes:

bunk
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a shelf-bed built against a wall (orig. nautical as far as NZ use goes, taken over by immigrants from sailing-ship experience (cf. berth n.), and used now esp. by trampers);

see also Maori bunk (trampers')


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: cf. double-bunking
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1845
Source:  Adventure in NZ
Author:  WAKEFIELD
Vol / Page:  1/205
Edition:
Quote:  ... a `bunk', or wooden shelf, supported Colonel Wakefield's bed. 1845 <i>Ibid.</i> 1/330

For the information of those who do not know what a <i>bunk</i> is, I must explain that it is a bed place built against the wall of a house or ship.


Notes:

Date:  24/11/1847
Source:  Letters to His Father, 1843-1851
Author:  H S CHAPMAN
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  The squatters' huts, [...] are native built whare's improved in their form and size by imitating our cottages. The sleeping place is a `bunk' or standing bed place as on board ship ... The whare consists of one large room with a bunk in each corner - a standing table between each pair of bunks and one large clay chimney.
Notes:  1847 Nov 24 H.S. Chapman Letters to His Father [TS,ATB] in 1958 Miller Early Victorian NZ 140

Date:  0/0/1851
Source:  Southern Districts of NZ
Author:  SUTHERLAND
Vol / Page:  8
Edition:
Quote:  On our arrival, the only quarters we could procure were two rooms of a weather-boarded house, ... The architect had probably been a ship's carpenter, for he had fitted up one of the rooms with tiers of [9] sleeping places of the form called by sailors bunks.

Date:  23/9/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Bunk</i>. A bed, whether made of wood in a hut, like a berth in a ship, or of fern and tussock in a tent. ([1874 Lady Barker Station Life], p.34)
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Date:  0/4/1861
Source:  Note
Author:  BUTLER
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  It is Sunday. We rose later than usual. There are five men sleeping in the hut. I sleep in a bunk on one side of the fire, Mr. Haast ... sleeps upon the opposite one; my bullock-driver and hut-keeper have two bunks at the far end of the hut, along the wall; ... The usual mutton and bread for breakfast with a pudding made of flour and water baked in the camp-oven after a joint of meat - Yorkshire pudding, but without eggs. While we were at breakfast, a robin perched on the table and sat there a good while pecking at the sugar.
Notes:  1861 April Butler's Note in 1919 Jones Samuel Butler - A Memoir 1/87 April, 1861 -



Date:  1/7/1861
Source:  Puketoi Station Diary
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Built grate in fireplace; put up bunk for bullock drivers.

Date:  0/0/1989

Author:
Vol / Page:  3/22
Edition:
Quote:  <i>bunk</i>: The name for a shearer's bed. Years ago shearer's bunks were often in three tiers and made up with straw filled palliasses for mattresses and borrowed woolpacks for warmth.

Notes:

bunk
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: to sleep, go to bed (with) (constructions: bunk with, in with, down with (a person);

bunk down, `go to bunk'); earlier literal use on sheep-stations and in men's camps: but modern (ca?1945) widened.

Bunking is when you hang around the square instead of going to school or home'.

Vol / Page:  16
Edition:
Quote:  Other well-known [drinking] games are Hokonui Swindle, Bottles, Fluffy Ducks, Bunnies are Hovering, Cardinal Huff, All Blacks, Matches, and The Amazing Grimaldi Brothers. All these games involve either a complicated intellectual exercise, tongue twisters, mathematical calculations or aerobatics in a confined space; High Candelabras for example, involves intoxicated individuals attempting to traverse the four walls of a room without touching the floor.

bureau manager
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the wharf labour system manager
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1948
Source:  Our Own Country
Author:
Vol / Page:  91
Edition:
Quote:  The Lyttelton waterfront has been working under the bureau system of engaging labour for nine years now. ... `And,' the bureau manager said, `the men wouldn't like to go back to the old way again.' Under the old system, foremen of the various shipping companies stood on a small platform or block with the men awaiting employment before them and nominated those they required to work their own ships. The trouble with this `auction block' system, as it was called, was that each company tended to give preference to a certain group of men. It engaged the same men first all the time and employed others only when the preferred group were all at work. This meant very often the available work on the waterfront was not evenly shared; and that's what the bureau system tries to avoid.
Notes:

bureau system
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a system for hiring wharf labour which replaced the auction block system.




Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

Under the old system, foremen of the various shipping companies stood on a small platform or block with the men awaiting employment before them and nominated those they required to work their own ships. The trouble with this `auction block' system, as it was called, was that each company tended to give preference to a certain group of men. It engaged the same men first all the time and employed others only when the preferred group were all at work. This meant very often the available work on the waterfront was not evenly shared; and that's what the bureau system tries to avoid.

burn
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: verb
Sense Number: 2
Definition: to fire (tussock grassland or scrub or fern country), to bring on new growth; to create feed by burning; to periodically fire pasture; burn off (the effect of the verb seems applied to the land or country rather than to the vegetation to be burnt); often in collocations to burn country, burn a run; (mainly or orig. SI)

Vol / Page:  3/271

Quote:  This river is fed by the Swine and other burns.
Notes:  (Beal)

burn
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: (an instance of) clearing bush, scrub, unpalatable grass, etc. from the land by means of fire to improve pasture or to bring into cultivation by clearing logs or bush.

(There seems a distict cleavage between early South Island and early NI usage, cf. burn v1. In the South Island `a burn' was a periodical burning off of old tussock to prepare the way for good crop of new grass. In 20th century usage, however, has been applied (e.g. in the Pelorus Sounds) to burning off noxious weeds, fern, scrub etc. to get a good growth of green feed (cf. match-farming). In the North Island, `a burn' was chiefly applied to clearing away (felled) bush by burning, a burning off (or over) of unwanted bush: that is, to clearing or bringing land into cultivation, not merely to improving pasture. burn off seems chiefly used in this North Island sense (cf bush-burning))

burn off
Homonym Number:
Word Class: verb
Sense Number:
Definition: to burn remains of bush, scrub and fern from land once timber or scrub has been cleared or to burn tussock on winter country, particularly in high country South Island.

burn-out
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: From the 1930s at least, according to W. Martin and Bob Adams of NZ Seamen's Union, a bad discharge from a ship, a transferred and figurative usage from stoking the furnace of a coal-burning ship. An inefficient or tyro stoker who built a bad fire had a `burn-out' in the furnace - i.e. the fire went partially out. He was allowed to get away with one of these, but on doing a second, was eased off the ship. Hence it came to mean a bad discharge in general.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Homonym Number:  1

burr
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a burr-bearing plant; in New Zealand, especially biddy-bid. 1. Native Acaena spp. esp <i>Acaena sanguisorbae</i>

biddy-bid, hutiwai; an almost generic term in popular usage in early 1840s-1860s usage;

replaced by biddy-bid, but still a usual general term in ref. to wool. a. Simplex : common bur(r); also native, New Zealand burr.

Quote:  But, as the mutton-bird seldom makes a new burrow, but returns to the old ones year after year, and as these burrows are nearly horizontal, the natives have made vertical openings into them, through which they extract the young one. burst
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a spree (esp. a drinking spree, often a spending spree), a bust

usu. constr. on the burst, on the spree, occas. early to have a burst; now mainly replaced by bust; an old word for a spree; burster, an old word for southerly buster. 1. a. A (protracted) drinking spree.


Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  20/7/1861
Source:  Letters from Canterbury, NZ
Author:  HARPER
Vol / Page:  64
Edition:  1914
Quote:  [The station hands] gravely plead that to `have a burst' is necessary for health after the long monotony of station life and fare. <i>Ibid.</I> 65 You may argue with them [sc. station hands], and they gravely plead that to `have a burst' is necessary for health after the long monotony of station life and fare, ...

Vol / Page:  167

Quote:  Once or twice a year, he went ... to Christchurch, - or to <i>town</i>, as it was more emphatically called, - and, like hundreds of his class, he went down with the set resolution<i> `to have a burst'.</i> ... While there [at the inn] he would spend every farthing of his year's wages, ...

Date:  0/0/1925
Source:  Random Recollections
Author:  BATHGATE
Vol / Page:  36
Edition:
Quote:  `He is a groom at the pub ..., and is a remittance man. Every now and again he gets a remittance from Home, and has a tremendous burst for a week or two. One not infrequently came across remittance men, generally on the goldfields, at some public house, employed as groom and general rouseabout, or perhaps cook.
Notes:

Author:  SCANLAN

Date:  30/10/1890

Author:
Vol / Page:  32
Edition:
Quote:  Our port of shipment in the early "fifties" was the "boulder bank".. to whence also came all the bullock drivers and shearers' cheques, to be "knocked down" on their periodical "bursts".


Notes:

Date:  5/7/1851
Source:  Lyttelton Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  7
Edition:
Quote:  (Torlesse's Report on Canterbury) The north-west wind ... something like the ... `hot winds' of Australia ... is almost invariably succeeded by one from the south-west, which in the summer time is a cool and pleasant guest, but in the winter season what is aptly termed `a burst', and sometimes lasts for two or three days, being generally accompanied by rain if not by snow and sleet. This wind is similar to the well-known `south-easter' of New Zealand, which, here, tends up with the land, and so has a south-westerly direction.
Notes:

Date:  20/7/1861
Source:  Letters from Canterbury, NZ
Author:
Vol / Page:  64
Edition:  1914

burst

Edition:
Quote:  coach a bagman `on the burst', with a candlestick, to bed.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1873
Source:  Station Amusements in NZ
Author:  BARKER
Vol / Page:  221
Edition:
Quote:  `Hisabella' had gone on the `burst', having bought, for some fabulous sum, a bottle of rum from a passing swagger.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1899
Source:  In the Shadow of the Bush
Author:  BELL
Vol / Page:  101
Edition:
Quote:  Though he could take his whisky regularly and freely, and did so, he had ... his periodically recurring seasons when he would get on `the burst,' and soak himself in it. ... O'Byrne took little notice ...; and Davie ... had thought it best on the one occasion in which Dan had `broken out,' to give him a wide berth. <i>Ibid.</I> 129 He then trudged off homewards, and ... went on the `burst' for a week.
Notes:

Date:  0/12/1904
Source:  NZ Illustrated Magazine
Author:
Vol / Page:  179
Edition:
Quote:  He would purchase half a dozen bottles of rum ... and go on a regular burst ...
Notes:

Date:  23/9/1933
Source:  Press, The
Author:
Vol / Page:  13
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Burst, bust.</i> Drinking bout. e.g. `He has been on the burst for a week,' `He has had an awful bust.' ([1874 Kennaway Crusts], p.167)
Notes:  Acland Glossary

Date:  9/6/1987

Vol / Page:  6

burst
Homonym Number:  2
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:  a (southerly) burster, buster.
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1851
Source:  Spring in the Canterbury Settlement, A
Author:  TORLESSE
Vol / Page:  9
Edition:
Quote:  The north-west wind ... somewhat resembling the `hot winds' of Australia ... is almost invariably successded by one from the south-west, which in the summer time is a cool and pleasant guest, but in the winter season what is aptly denominated `a burst', and sometimes lasts for two or three days, being generally acompanied by rain, if not by snow and sleet.
Notes:

Date:  5/7/1851
Source:  Lyttelton Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  7
Edition:
Quote:  The north-west wind ... something like the ... `hot winds' of Australia ... is almost invariably succeeded by one from the south-west, which in the summer time is a cool and pleasant guest, but in the winter season what is aptly termed `a burst', and sometimes lasts for two or three days, being generally accompanied by rain if not by snow and sleet. This wind is similar to the well-known `south-easter' of New Zealand, which, here, tends up with the land, and so has a south-westerly direction.
Notes:  (Torlesse's Report on Canterbury)

Edition:
Quote:  We had a favourable wind in the straits when all of a sudden.. an opposite burster came on in a manner so furious that the captain.. declared it was blowing a hurricane.

Date:  29/7/1857
Source:  Lyttelton Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  5
Edition:
Quote:  The weather ... was exceedingly cold, but has now changed to fine again, proving that the sum of a few `bursters' which blow from time to time, at long intervals, is our real winter; that as a season, we have scarcely one to be called.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1906

Author:  STACK
Vol / Page:  53
Edition:  1972
Quote:  Suddenly, with the violence of a whirlwind, the south-west gale [54] burst upon us, enveloping us in a blinding cloud of dust, ... which it had gathered up as it rushed along the plain.
Notes:  [an example of use of <i>burst</i> with a <i>southerly</i>] [c1860] a1906 Stack Through Canterbury (1972) 53-54

Date:  0/0/1863

Author:  BUTLER
Vol / Page:  110
Edition:
Quote:  The southerly `burster', as it is called, gradually creeps up and at last drives the other [NW wind] off the field. A few chilly puffs, then a great one, and in a minute or two the air becomes cold, even in the height of summer.

bush apiary
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a set of hives situated in native bush areas.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  15/5/1956
Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  425
Edition:
Quote:  The importance of bush apiaries in beekeeping.. Gradually through the years beekeepers have been discovering the value of bush apiaries financially and for the upkeep of their apiaries on clover lands. Today many commercial beekeepers have one or more bush apiraies established..Most beekeepers prefer to work hives of Italian bees and have used them when they have established their bush apiaries...Some beekeepers, however, prefer to keep a hybrid strain in their bush apiaries.
Notes:

bush baptist
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a person who has strong fundamentalist views but is not a church member; a person usually with no formal theological training, who is fond of publicly expressing strong, individualistic, and often evangelical, religious beliefs.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

Pronunciation:

Author:  SHARPE
Vol / Page:  32
Edition:
Quote:  In the middle of that cable there was a hell of a sag, and we could see no way to evade the tightening job. As equipment we had a `bush devil', a sort of wire-straining outfit on which two men are expected to apply a pressure up to twenty tons, and a massive wrench. Hooking the strainer on to the base of a handy tree we got its claws, or whatever you call them, gripped on the long cable, above the turn buckle, and worked the lever until the joined sections were slack.

Date:  0/0/1899
Source:  Ann. Rep. Dept of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  VII/87
Edition:
Quote:  [Hdg] "Tauranga" or "Bush Disease". This peculiar wasting disease, which is confined to the tract of land lying in the vicinity of Tauranga, and extending from there to Rotorua and Lichfield, was made the subject of an investigation by Mr. Park three years ago... It appears that both sheep and cattle will do well and put on condition for the first few months after being placed on this diseased country, but as time goes on a gradual wasting sets in, which ends in death if they are not removed to another district.
Notes:

Date:  15/8/1912
Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  118
Edition:
Quote:  All the evidence gathered points to the condition being one of malnutrition rather than of disease, properly speaking, and I have therefore adopted the term 'bush sickness' in connection with it, instead of 'bush disease' as heretofore.
Notes:

Source, use about 450mm of scrub then 150 mm of coarse shingle.

bush drive
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a method of treefelling where trees are part-scarfed in front of one or more that are fully felled, taking the part-scarfed trees down with them.

Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See: Taranaki drive
Pronunciation:

Citations
Date:  0/0/1997

Author:  HINDMARSH
Vol / Page:  162
Edition:
Quote:  A 'bush drive' was contrived by cutting the trees up the slopes only partially through, then the ones at the top on the ridges were felled completely and these would carry those below down the whole hillside in a spectacular fashion.
Notes:

Date:  3/2/1985
Source:  NZ Times
Author:
Vol / Page:  12
Edition:
Quote:  Those great crashing bush-drives, when one tree was aimed to hit another partly-cut tree, which in turn smashed into another half-severed tree, and so on smashing and roaring downhill to the gully's bottom, ... the bush snails dying, the woodhens confounded, the brown pebbled creek and all its reflections from the beginning shrinking back in dismay.
Notes:   (Jim Henderson)

Quote:  The Bush Falcon can be found in forest (including exotic pine plantations) and bush patches of the North Island and northwestern South Island.
Notes:  www.ranz.org.nz/raptor-information.

Date:  0/0/1985
Source:  Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Author:
Vol / Page:  154
Edition:
Quote:  <i>New Zealand Falcon Falco novaeseelandiae</i> GMELIN, 1788 ...[155] OTHER NAMES: <i>Karearea, sparrowhawk, bush hawk, quail hawk, eastern  falcon, southern falcon, bush falcon. ...  Bush falcon: In the North Island confined to the  main ranges, ... Eastern falcon: The main ranges of the South Island ... Southern Falcon:  Fiordland, the Auckland Islands, and Stewart Island. </I.>


Notes:

Whereever cover can be got, in attack and defence, under the canopy of heaven, there bush fighting can be practised, and it is highly useful to practise it as a part of army manoeuvres.

Notes:  Ruth Mason `Track and Trail'

bush flax
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: Astelia nervosa  (prob. from `growing in the bush A1, rather than from gen. Eng. `growing as a bush; bush-sized'); a tussocky, flax-like plant (astelia) with berries, red when ripe, found usually in bush; also called kakaha.

bush harrow
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: prob., `a rough harrow made from brush or bushes' (= shrubs) but with overtones of bush A1

(i.e., poss. `made of material from the bush': cf. bush fence, -pen) phs a borrowing of American or Eng. provincial bush-harrow for the more common `brush-harrow', or perhaps merely brush replaced by the more freq. NZ bush.
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

Source:  Diary
Author:  BEETHAM
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Oct.9th. Commenced hauling off logs with bullocks when the fellows came with their assistance made a bush harrow and saved all the land I had grubbed; ...


Notes:  1858 Oct 9 William Beetham Diary in 1967 Rickard Strangers in the Wilderness 98

Source:  Era of the Bush Trams in NZ, The
Author:  MAHONEY
Vol / Page:  46
Edition:
Quote:  Bush jiggers were the motor-driven creations used to transport humans along bush trams... Small hand-worked jiggers were used extensively on the NZR but they were not common on trams... The first bush jiggers were constructed early in the 20th century... The earliest confirmed jigger appeared in April 1908 when it was reported that a trolley had been built by Gamman at Te Ohu to convey 10-12 men to and from work... The principal use of bush jiggers was to get the bushmen to and from work. Compared to other options they were faster, safer,warmer, and drier. <i>Ibid.</i> 58 The development of the bush jigger spelled the end for most bush camps because they made it possible to travel to work over long distances in comparative speed and comfort.
Notes:

Author:
Vol / Page:  2/117
Edition:
Quote:  The Korari is the name of the flower stalk, often, but wrongly, used as the name of the plant. The edible root is the Aruhe. The word `Muka' is commonly applied to the dressed fibre; it is the correct name for the inner leaves. Cleared bush-land is suitable for the cultivation of the flax plant, and even swamp-land is improved by drainage. In the various flax swamps near nelson ...the finest plants grow upon the soil that has been thrown out of the ditch ...
Notes:  (Heaphy NZ Flax)

I recall his [the botanist-Inspector's] chuckle when we showed him ... the huge white caterpillar known throughout bushland [in North Auckland] as the `rata grub', so-called because it was always found at the foot of a rata and was supposed to be the origin [101] of the tree itself. It is a curious creature - a great caterpillar with a strange tree-like fungoid growth, growing sometimes to a height of several inches, from its body. I think everybody believed in the legend of the rata-tree caterpillar; ...

Author:
Vol / Page:  284
Edition:
Quote:  HOMESTEAD SYSTEM. Under this system the settler makes no payment for the land, the only cost to him being the expenses of survey. On the fulfilment of conditions, which are five years' residence, the erection of a house, and the cultivation of one-third of the selection if open land, and one-fifth if bush-land, the Crown grant is issued. `Do you own any land?' `Yes, three hundred acres of bush land.' `Have you any cleared?' `Sixty acres'. [ca1900]

Source:  Wild Will Enderby
Author:  PYKE

Quote:  A bush lantern is constructed by placing a candle within the neck of a clear glass bottle, the bottom of which has either been knocked off by a sharp scientific tap from a practised hand, or more artistically removed by pouring in a little cold water, and then thrusting the bottle end-wise in a fire

bush lawyer
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: Rubus cissoides, a tenacious vine of the spp. Rosaceae notorious for trapping and starving sheep.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]

Date:  0/0/1996
Source:  Anthony Wall, Settler of Porirua
Author:  KAY
Vol / Page:  39
Edition:
Quote:  The first 'bush license' at the Halfway was issued to John Lodge, who owned the third eight-acre strip of land there, alongside those of Anthony and John Whitehouse. Bush licenses were issued for the sale of liquor without any rules for accommodation. A Special Publican's License was issued to John McKain in 1849, followed by a 'bush license' a year later.

Domain: [none]

Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1900
Source:  Canterbury Old & New
Author:
Vol / Page:  184
Edition:
Quote:  The native fuchsia [fn <i> Fuchsia excorticata </i>.] - an exile from South America - and the fierce bush-nettle  [fn <i> Urtica ferox </i>.] are conspicuous amongst the undergrowth, together with the bush-lily  [fn Astelia nervosa.], but we see but few species of the characteristic New Zealand daisy-trees  [fn Species of <i> Olearia </i>.] or of the bushy Veronicas (koromiko), which are so conspicuous in other parts of these islands.


Notes:  Dendy

Date:  27/11/1997
Source:  Evening Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  C22
Edition:
Quote:  Astelia nervosa, kakaha or bush lily, has pronounced clear nerves running down the midribs of the silvery green leaves. These flaxy leaves may be up to 2.6m long and 10cm wide.

bush lokey
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1998
Source:  Era of the Bush Trams in NZ, The
Author:  MAHONEY
Vol / Page:  14
Edition:
Quote:  The typical bush lokey of this early period was the four-wheel direct-drive type imported from England weighing between 5 and 10 onnes. <i>Ibid</i> 79 A special type of bush lokey was developed to operate over these newer lines which were built far beyond the alignment limits of 'normal' railways. Because more power was required, the special bush lokeys were bigger than those used previously. <i>Ibid.</i> 83 The introduction of the first bush lokeys in New Zealand was concurrent with the initial railway construction boom and the first steam-powered mineral railways.
Notes:

Source:  Era of the Bush Trams in NZ, The
Author:  MAHONEY
Vol / Page:  58
Edition:
Quote:  A 'Bush mill' was timber industry vernacular for a sawmill sited close to the bush working rather than sited close to 'civilisation' - usually meaning the local town or at least the local railway station. The rationale for establishing a bush mill was economic.

Quote:  Not a week has passed without my having had to make communication to Europeans living at a distance from the Waimate; and whatever might be the value of what was to be sent, I had no hesitation in giving it in charge to a bush-native, accustomed to Europeans, but has all his life resided among his own people.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1843
Source:  Travels in NZ
Author:  DIEFFENBACH
Vol / Page:  1/86
Edition:
Quote:  ... from all I have seen in New Zealand, I am convinced that the formidable pictures of bush-natives which have been drawn are purely the result of imagination. The natives in general are much too civilised and social, and know their own interests too well, to live in a gloomy and inhospitable forest.

bush people
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  Speaking for Ourselves
Author:  OWEN & PERKINS
Vol / Page:  150
Edition:
Quote:  The way in which the bush people - the bushmen and their wives - stuck to one another is shown by the way they rallied round in the case of a family that was in need. A common method of raising money was called a `basket social'. A hall would be used for the function, and the people of the district would be invited to bring along baskets. Now these baskets were made of any material at all at hand, and it was remarkable the ingenuity and workmanship shown in making them. ... In the basket its maker put a supper, the food cooked at home ... [151] Now on the night of the basket social, all the baskets would be handed in ... They would then be auctioned, and the purchaser of the basket would have the pleasure and the honour of having supper with the provider of the basket. ... Now I've seen them pay twelve ... pounds in those days for a basket, just to make sure that the girl of the boy's choice saw that he really meant business. ... Every penny of that would go to the family in need ...
Notes:  (Joe Gasparich, Northland kauri country)

bush philosopher
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a self-trained philosopher living and working in bush; a moralising or philosophically inclined bushman (bush - may have a derog. sense as in bush baptist, carpenter 2,

lawyer; or merely a locative sense as in bush carpenter 1, bush doctor, preacher. That is it may mean `an amateur philosopher perniciously fond of moralising'; or `one who lives in the bush and is an amateur philosopher').
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:

Date:  22/3/1894
Source:  Richmond-Atkinson Papers

Vol / Page:  2/597
Edition:  1960
Quote:  He has had a rough time of it surveying a block on the ranges up the Wai-o-hine in the Wairarapa ...[sic] Once ...[sic] they had nothing to eat but a tui and a more-pork. ... They were stewing the two birds when a kuku-pa (bush pigeon) flew up and perched. Bob shot it ... This is not exactly what the Britishers call `sport' - but there is more of nature about it than 30 gents in pink and tops ... waiting for a wretched little fox who, when he is killed, is not equal for culinary purposes to a more-pork. Once coming up the Waikato in 1851 your Uncle James got a pot-shot at a lot of parera (grey duck) ...
Notes:  (C.W. Richmond)

Source:  New Zealand (various authors/titles)
Author:  TROLLOPE
Vol / Page:  47
Edition:
Quote:  The road [to Wakatip was] fairly good - for a "bush" road. The name must be taken in a colonial sense. There was hardly a tree to be seen throughout the journey but the word has made its way over from Australia, and the traveller when he is out of town is in the bush. A country road which is merely formed and not metalled is a bush road, though it pass across an open plain, or up a treeless valley.
Notes:

bush sickness
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a sheep and cattle disease caused by cobalt-deficient soil [known by several names such as Morton Mains disease, the skinnies, Hope disease, Tauranga disease, bush disease and Mairoa dopiness.]


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: Rural
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  15/8/1912
Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  118
Edition:
Quote:  All the evidence gathered points to the condition being one of malnutrition rather than of disease, properly speaking, and I have therefore adopted the term 'bush sickness' in connection with it, instead of 'bush disease' as heretofore.
Notes:

Date:  15/3/1956
Source:  NZ Journal of Agriculture
Author:
Vol / Page:  239
Edition:
Quote:  Later New Zealand investigations showed that similar-appearing diseases in this country (bush sickness, Mairoa dopiness, and Morton Mains disease) could also be cured and prevented by cobalt.

bush singlet
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number: 2
Definition: a black, working singlet; a thick, black, woollen, sleeveless singlet worn by bushmen and other manual workers (because it soaks up sweat without chilling the wearer, and does not show sweatstain and other grime).

Domain: [none]

bush telegraph
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: an informal but well organised system of word-of-mouth communication transmitting plans and movements of the police: grapevine 3. unofficial information: rumour; informal process of word-of-mouth communication, usually of rumour or gossip (cf. grapevine, jungle telegraph).
Origin:
Register:

Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

This was New Zealand's first steam-worked bush tramway and used a British 0-4-0 vertical boiler locomotive.

bush week

Sense Number:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An
Author:  McLINTOCK
Vol / Page:  3/689
Edition:
Quote:  In addition to the rock wren, there is another species, <i> Xenicus longipipes </i>, the bush wren or matuhi. This bird is also very small, of darker green colouring and with a white throat. It is found in damp rimu and beech forests on the West Coast of the South Island, and builds its nest in hollow trees and, like the rock wren, lines it with feathers. <I>Ibid.</I> 3/705-12

Wren, bush .. .. matuhi .. .. <i> Xenicus longipes </I>

Date:  0/0/2005
Source:  Internet - see Notes
Author:
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:  Toward the end these paddlers did decide to walk a rapid or two..we bush-bashed up the bank to the bottom bridge...
Notes:  http://www.huttkayakers.org.nz/tripIndex.php *Accessed 17/04/06. No date for site construction or posting.

Date:  0/0/1988
Source:  Hills, The
Author:  PICKERING
Vol / Page:  8
Edition:
Quote:  So to cope with the rituals of tramping, its pains and camaraderie, a slang language has developed to suit. Lots of quick short words to fit in the breathless pauses as you pant uphill. `Crud' (cloud), `bush-bash', a `gunn' tramper (which must have originated from Davy Gunn's famous trek up the Hollyford Valley to help victims of a plane crash in 1936; he travelled 40 km by rowing boat, horse and foot in 21 hours), `windfall' (a collapsed pile of trees), `pit' (the tramper's true friend, a sleeping bag), `pog' (porridge), `bastard grass' and `lawyer' (two unpleasant plants), `piker' (one who stayed home), `Huey' (all-powerful god of weather), and many, many more.
Notes:

Date:  15/3/2003
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  H1
Edition:
Quote:  All three of these intrepid suburban pupil-carriers can bush-bash with the best of them and I have to admit that I did get even the Lexus very dirty.

Quote:  ... the long grey moss which hangs in festoons and beards from some of the trees in the heavy bush [especially in mountain country in the North Island]. One kind of the moss ... is almost white and very conspicuous in the gloom of the bush. The settlers' name for it in my part of the country is `new-chum's pigeon'. It is so called because of the imagined resemblance of the mossy bunches to the white breast of the wild pigeon; ... I'm hanged if it would deceive any New Zealander country-born or bush-bred.

Quote:  It was the final weekend of my bushcraft course... It had seemed a good idea on New Year's Eve when, dancing on a barrel at a Greek restaurant, I vowed: "This year I will drink less, eat more veges, and join a bushcraft course."... So, with the jeers of friends and flatmates ringing in my ears (apparently "bushcraft" carries connotations of hairy legs, bushy beards and unsavoury hygiene), I enrolled for a bushcraft course.

bushfelling
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the falling or cutting down of timber trees or bush A1; =bush-falling (bush-falling is the common term; bush-felling is uncommon, and would seem slightly pedantic or `Englishy'.


Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]

Road-making on a 50/50 basis with the local bodies, ohu or mahi-apu [ed fn: A group of volunteer workers] in relation to scrub-cutting, bush felling, splitting posts and battens, gave ample evidence of self-help.

bushing it

Author:  TUCKETT
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:   ... the prevailing species of trees are remo [rimu], totara, and tall manuka, all indicative of inferior soil.... The bush-like woods on the east side are of white birch, likewise no recommendation of the soil, but the chief objection to the district is, that the prairie soil affords scarcely any food for cattle ... it grows only the wiry tree grass [tussock] ... and

<I>Phormium tenax</I> [flax], no aniseed, perennial groundsel, or milk thistle, and very little couch grass.
Notes:  1844 Aug 16 Tuckett's Diary in 1898 Hocken contributions 223-224



bushline
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: the timber-line; the upper limit of the growth of bush A1 on a mountain; height at which bush ceases to grow (cf. timber-line (OED 1835) is occas. used in N.Z; cf. and cp. snow-line, which is more often used in the SI mountain-country. Whether one uses bush-line or snow-line depends upon the locality of the speaker, or the point of view of the speaker, e.g. a bushman would be more likely to speak of the bush-line, a mountaineer of the snow-line. bush-line and snow-line are only occas. synonymous. e.g. in mountain-country, in the summer, when snow is lying high or has disappeared, the bush-line stands out clearly, but is often called (locally and colloquially) `the snow-line': (cf. also scrub-line).
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  13/2/1899
Source:  Taranaki Herald
Author:
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  Although above the bush line, there will be abundance of wood within convenient distance.

Quote:  There is any amount of bush all along this line. In fact, the line is generally referred to as the "bush line."
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1958
Source:  Tararua
Author:
Vol / Page:  23
Edition:
Quote:  We may speak of kauri forest or beech forest, but we get lost in the bush, fight bush fires, and climb above the bushline. The kauri forest, like the mixed podocarp forest, the sub-tropical rain forest, ... and such-like are terms that come from the botanist and forester, not from the layman - or from the bushman. ... Even those later scientists who use <I>forest</i> as a general rule usually write of <I>bushmen, bush tracks, patches of bush</i>, and the <I>bushline. </i><I>Ibid.</I> 24 <i>Bushline</i>, the upper limit of the bush, would be the <i>timberline</i> in North America. Hudson [G.V. Hudson 1890 TrNZI 2/181] used it in 1890 as if it were then well established. It does not seem to have been noted in any dictionary and is probably a word indigenous to New Zealand.
Notes:  Ruth Mason `Track and Trail'

Date:  0/0/1960
Source:  Good Keen Man, A
Author:  CRUMP
Vol / Page:  82
Edition:
Quote:  His place was spread against one side of a leading ridge, along the top of which was the bushline, with his boundary fence hard against the bush.

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author:  TURNER
Vol / Page:  160
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Bush-line</i> or sometimes [161] <i>forest-line</i> (for American<i> timber-line</i>, English <i> tree-line</i>  and Australian <i> tree-line or forest-line), bush-clad, bush burns</i>  (areas where the bush has recently been burnt off) are tramping as well as general terms, as is the use of <i> shingle</i>  for angular as well as rounded stones in <i> shingle slide</i> , or (earlier) <i>shingle slip</i> , also recently called scree as in Scotland and northern England.

bushman's singlet
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a black, working singlet; a thick, black, woollen, sleeveless singlet worn by bushmen and other manual workers (because it soaks up sweat without chilling the wearer, and does not show sweatstain and other grime).
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: bush singlet

woollen sleeveless garment that keeps the

called a "Jackie Howe."

bushman's sprigs

Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  Off the Sheep's Back
Author:  RICHARDS
Vol / Page:  61
Edition:
Quote:  A bushman always wore a special type of boot known as `ferntights', named because the upper part of the boot was sewn inside the lower leather, preventing sharp stakes from penetrating the seam and tearing the stitching. Round-headed hobnails were replaced with square-headed "bushman's springs" [sic].It was essential when standing on roots to have a firm footing and "bushman's

sprigs" helped to prevent us losing our

foothold on a slippery bank.


Notes:

bushman's staggers
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1984
Source:  Ngamatapouri
Author:  ANNABELL
Vol / Page:  51
Edition:
Quote:  About an hour after the second boil up for the day the affected person would feel an unnatural weakness stealing over him, his axe would grow excessively heavy, every blow would be an effort and a feeling of unreality as if working in a dream and a faint tremnbling of the limbs would assail him. Usually he would sit down and sharpen his axe for a minute or two then carry on chopping, the feeling slowly fading away in about half an hour. Among ourselves, to give this affliction an important sounding name, we always called it "Hydrophobia" but it is more generally called "Bushman's staggers," and is supposed to be caused by overworking the stomach at the same time as overworking the muscles.
Notes:

bushman's staggers
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:  1
Definition: a muscle weakness due to inadequate diet and over-exertion in bush-clearing.


Origin: [none]
Register:

bushmen's trousers
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition:
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1939
Source:  Tararua
Author:
Vol / Page:  5(12)/2
Edition:
Quote:  These are extra heavy underpants, dark colour, hip pocket, and cost 10/-. ca1954 R.Mason notes: `According to two old bushmen, Joe Gibbs and Sandy Donaldson, bushmen wore (and may still wear) long, red, woollen underpants at work. They do not get wet as quickly as trousers, do not flap uncomfortably around the legs when wet, and keep the legs warm. Trampers often do likewise in snow and in cold wet windy weather when it is too cold for shorts.
Notes:  check year

Date:  0/9/1958
Source:  Tararua
Author:
Vol / Page:  24
Edition:
Quote:  A <i>bushman</i> is one who lives and works in the bush, or sometimes one skilled in bushcraft. Judging by a remark in the <i>Tramper</i> of 1933 there were articles known as <i>bushmen's trousers</i> on sale. These were a type of garment pretty much the same as long woollen underpants, but made for outer wear and provided with pockets.




Notes:  Ruth Mason `Track and Trail'

bushranger
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: (Transf. or extended uses of Aust. bushranger-->; `bush bandit' [AND 1801];the primary sense (OED 1817), though widely known, was used infreq. in NZ contexts before the major gold discoveries, and then mainly referring to goldfields robberies (e.g. Maungatapu Murders  1866) of the "hold-up" type. The word has always been Aust. from c1806;. cf. Elder Goldseekers and Bushrangers in New Zealand.)
Origin:
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  23/4/1814
Source:  Marsden's Lieutenants
Author:  ELDER
Vol / Page:  54
Edition:  1934
Quote:  Great numbers of them [sc. Tasmanian aboriginals] have been shot like beasts of prey by our people, and the bushrangers who make their escape from the settlement have (for fear of being discovered by the settlers) killed them without mercy.
Notes:  1814 Apr 23 Kendall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 54



Date:  21/1/1817
Source:  Marsden's Lieutenants
Author:  ELDER
Vol / Page:  133

Quote:   He had been formerly amongst the bushrangers at Van Diemen's Land, and had of course nothing to say on his behalf.

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  NZ Wars, The
Author:  BELICH
Vol / Page:  213
Edition:
Quote:  At its fullest, the `bush-scouring' theory entailed a `flying column' of a few hundred men, untrammeled by a large supply train,hunting down the Maoris in the bush, and forcing them to fight by attacking their villages and cultivations. ... [214] Bush-scouring was not a panacea for all circumstances, based on the inherent abilities of settler-frontiersmen, but a military method appropriate only in a certain context ... One assumption behind the bush- scouring theory was that the Maoris were evasive guerilla fighters ... [215] Masking the <I>pa</I>, and bush-scouring against the Maori base areas ... would be a long and slow process.
Notes:

Quote:  The scorched earth policy of stripping the land of Maori houses and crops that had been applied since the beginning of the war in 1863 was supplemented by 'bush-scouring'. This startegy aimed to take the fight to the Maori in the bush.

When bush-shooting, you are usually sure of the locality of the deer, as the hill slopes give you an idea of his approximate location. Some days you may shoot several deer while bush-shooting, and at other times you may stalk for a full day and get none, ... <i>Ibid.</i> 119 When bush-shooting, one has [sic] to make sure of each shot, as the deer would be gone after the first shot was fired.

Quote:  bushwhacked - exhausted: eg 'No more for me. I'm utterly bushwhacked.'
Notes:

bushwhacked
Homonym Number:
Word Class: adjective
Sense Number:
Definition: occas. modern coll. from an extension of the orig. (widely known) U.S. usage `kill by ambushing' cf. similar sense and use whacked; of which bushwhacked in this sense, is phs an elaboration, e.g. I was bushwhacked on the question of 10 o'clock closing; to be, get (a person), bushwhacked, to be, get beaten (in argument, a contest etc); bewildered, puzzled (by a problem etc)
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:

bushwhacker
Homonym Number:  1
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: one who falls bush A1 for a living; professional axeman; bush-faller, bushman 2 (prob. taken from US bushwhacker , `backwoodsman' in a NZ - note there is no composition in the earliest uses of BUSH + whack). A timber feller; bushwhack, to fell timber.

Citations
Date:  0/0/1889
Source:  Colonial Couplets
Author:  WILLIAMS & REEVES
Vol / Page:  3
Edition:
Quote:  Then there's what we call a <i>gully</i>, which of course we take to mean/ Just a small and narrow valley, in which bush is sometimes seen;/ <i>Bushy gully</i> suits me better, serves my purpose just as well;/ ... <i>Bush</i>, too, means the native forest; you will never, I'm afraid,/ Hear a self-respecting bushman call a bush a leafy glade,/ ...
Notes:   (`An Old Chum on New Zealand Scenery')

When the cloud cap settles heavy rain always follows.

but
Homonym Number:
Word Class: adverb
Sense Number:
Definition: (at end of sentence) however
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  17/8/2002
Source:  Dominion Post
Author:
Vol / Page:  F9
Edition:
Quote:  I've grown fond of the innovative Kiwi "but" meaning "I must admit" at the end of a sentence. TV watchers must have all seen that high-country musterer detailing the delights of a new girlfriend, then reassuring his mate with, "She doesn't drink Speights, but". Now we have test driver Greg Murphy judging a new four-wheel drive after a spectacular run: "She's tough. But."


Notes:

Date:  0/0/1966
Source:  English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author:  TURNER
Vol / Page:  113
Edition:
Quote:  There is no local grammar. The local usage which comes to mind, and it is not widespread, is the use of <i>but</i> as an adverb at the end of a sentence, an equivalent of <i>however.</i> ... The man who took our luggage in the air terminal at Sydney ... agreed [the Sydney climate] was good, then added `We've got central heating, but'. I first heard this usage in 1945 in Auckland among students at a Teacher's College, where it was a bit of an affectation or craze rather than established unconscious usage, but.
Notes:

Date:  14/10/1983
Source:  Letter
Author:  C. CORNE
Vol / Page:
Edition:
Quote:   but - `though', sentence / clause finally. `Jeez, this is strong piss! Nice, but'. `X's are good cars, I wouldn't buy one, but' Whangarei, widely used in 50s and 60s. Also current in Hawaian Creole English [see also Beaton]
Notes:  (Auckland)

Date:  0/0/1986
Source:  New Outlook
Author:
Vol / Page:  21/49
Edition:
Quote:  [(schoolchildren's) as a sentence ending] I didn't believe it first time a Whistler kid said he had two mothers. It's true but. ... Caleb still caught untold kutus that year but.
Notes:  Macrae (The Kingsland Kid)

butcher bats
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a game with insects
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See: aka butcher boys, penny doctor beetles
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1972
Source:  Folkgames of Children
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  328
Edition:
Quote:  <i>Penny Doctor</i> beetles, also known as `Butcher bats' is a game widely reported by Wellington Training College students as being played in many parts of the North Island. In this game straws moistened by spittle are pushed down the hole of the appropriate beetle. The beetle seizes the end of the straw. When the player feels the straw moving he or she flicks out the beetle. The player who can catch the most beetles wins the game.
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1953
Source:  Unorganized Games
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  405
Edition:
Quote:  The most widely known game with insects is a game named variously by T.C. students as Butcher Boys (Gisborne, New Plymouth, Kaponga, [405] Te Pohu, Newall, Sth. Wellington), Butcher Bats (Ohau, Takaka), Penny Doctor Beetles (Tauranga, Pipiriki, Rotorua), or Fishing (Morunui). It is a game in which straws which have been suitably moistened with spittle are placed in an insects [sic] hole and are flicked out when the insect bites the end of the straw. Most of the reports of this practice come from the North Island, though it was known in the South as early as 1900 (Waikouaiti).
Notes:

Date:  0/0/1981
Source:  History of Children's Play
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  128
Edition:
Quote:  A universal animal play in the North Island, but known also in the South Island, was a game variously termed Butcher Bats, Butcher Boys, or Penny Doctor Beetles. In this game, straws suitably moistened at the end with spittle were placed down insect holes and flicked out when the insect bit the end of the straw. The player won who could flick a beetle up first.
Notes:

Edition:
Quote:  Catching butcher-boys was good fun ... You chose a piece of footpath where there was no tar-sealing and looked for little round holes in the earth. When you found a hole, you pushed the soft end of a grass stalk into it ... As soon as it moved you pulled it out and caught a small white grub clinging to the end with its nippers.

butcher's board
Homonym Number:
Word Class: noun
Sense Number:
Definition: a marble game
Origin: [none]
Register:
Register 2:
Domain: [none]
Region: [none]
See:
Pronunciation:
Notes:
Citations
Date:  0/0/1972
Source:  Folkgames of Children
Author:  SUTTON-SMITH
Vol / Page:  174
Edition:
Quote:  In the nineteenth century the ring game seems to have been the most popular marble game. (In more recent years marble games with holes have had the greater role.) There was Big Ring, in which a circle a yard or more in diameter was drawn on the ground; there was the mullibar variation, in which an outsize taw was catapulted amongst the marbles in this circle. There were Little Ring, Liney, Follows, Follow the Taw, Holey, and then, on a less important scale, Butcher's Board, in which the marbles were bowled through the holes in a board, Eye-Drop, Knock-Backs, Leggings-Out (or Leggin's-Out), Span-'Em, and Backits. The last was more usually a girls' game.
Notes:

Quote:  During Victorian times Ranunculus lyalli,

the Mt Cook or Mountain Buttercup, was

known in England as the "Rockwood

Lily."... The exact connection between

the "Rockwood Lily" and a Canterbury

sheep station presents an interesting

puzzle... Rockwood Station, owned by

Henry Phillips, was one of the earliest

established homesteads... However, the

precise connection with Rockwood.. has

yet to be discovered.
